reviewText:
Overall, I had to say that I enjoyed playing this game. When I first started it, I was encountering some crashes but someone's suggestion on the forum quickly cleared up anything and I never saw a crash since. Regarding the gameplay, I enjoyed it. The combat did feel grittier than a Souls game, and I like how the magic in this game was much more 'supportive' rather than primary, as it can be in a Souls game (as an aside, I feel like magic ruined Dark Souls 2, but that's just an aside).

The boss designs were decent--they could use improvement, but I did enjoy some of them. I also did enjoy all of the little details they put in the game, like different ways to defeat bosses, different ending paths based on choices (which did seem a little hardboiled at times but was still a nice effort none the less). The only thing that frustrated me from time to time was the level design, which seemed labyrinthine.

There's lots of weapons in this game, and plenty of loot. The armor and weapon design were all decent.

All in all, is it Souls-like"? Yes
date: it is. Do I care? No. It's not like Dark Souls was the first Action RPG. Is it a fun game? Yes
recommended: yes it is. Do I hope they make another one and improve upon the first? Yes.\n\nI think what sometimes people forget

reviewText:
Lords of the Fallen gets a lot of things right, but is also blasted by many people for not being as polished as Dark Souls, or for even trying to be like Dark Souls.  Wherever you stand on that issue, I personally think the expansion of that sort of gameplay into a proper genre is good for business overall.  I want more games like Dark/Demons Souls, not less.

If you can get over the fact that yes, the game is very similar to the Souls titles, I think you'll find it to be quite a good game.  It lacks some of the bells and whistles of the Souls titles, such as the persistent and interesting multiplayer found in those games, but I believe it totally nails the combat, and is absolutely packed with secrets, both of which are some of the top reasons I enjoy the Souls games.

The story is a lot more straightforward than those titles (Sorry for all the comparisons, but the genre is still in its infancy and there isn't much else to compare it to, and this game wears its inspirations on its shoulders.) which can be both good and bad.  Good because you have a fairly clear motivation, bad because, well, let's face it, the voice acting is pretty mediocre and the talking animations and lip synching are actually kind of embarassingly bad.  Characters gesticulate wildly when saying the simplest things, all while retaining their stiff, wooden, doll-like faces and flapping mouths.

The stilted facial expressions clash furiously with the rest of the visuals, which have a distinct Warhammer (read: big shoulder pads, intricate armor, you know whether you enjoy that style or not.  I do, but you may not.) feel that is very consistent.  Having a very solid art style and beautiful technical work and then seeing Playstation 2-level facial animations is jarring to say the least.  It's not too big of a deal, but they put it in there, so I figured I'd give my two cents.  Also I feel it prudent to remind people that while the Souls games had decent voice acting, the characters rarely ever moved at all while talking and mouths never seemed to move at all, so, uhh, just throwing that out there.

So, let's talk about gameplay.  This game is said to be easier than the Souls games.  I never found those games to be particularly difficult so much as games that forced you to be patient.  Few fights ever required a high degree of dexterity, just that you observe and wait for an opening.  I think this game handles that just right.  But I warn you: If you're looking for a challenge, choose something besides the Warrior play style.  That class is a lot like the spell-casting class (Noble, was it?) in Demons Souls, where it was basically an easy mode for new players.  Try weird weapons, if you feel too tanky, wear super light armor.  I say these things because if you want the game to be difficult, then the default selections are not for you.

The game has fairly lengthy attack animations, longer than the Souls games in many cases, but it also has a bigger impact.  With my great hammer during a well-placed attack I can physically knock enemies across the room, and when it strikes the ground the sound design and visual effects really sell that I'm swinging a huge, deadly weapon and that it is not to be trifled with, but it also takes timing and understanding of each type of swing at my disposal.  I can out-poise some enemies if I wear heavy armor and just swing through it, or to challenge myself I can wear very light armor and rely on timing above all else.

Enemies do have a bit of cheapness to them occasionally.  Not all hitboxes are perfect, you can get hit by attacks that appear to miss you by several inches, and sometimes enemies do a very familiar Dark Souls move of sliding" forward at the end of an attack to force it to connect

reviewText:
Short Version: Is it worth playing? YES. Is it worth the full price? HELL NO!

Long Version:

(WARNING: I will compare this game to Darksouls games a lot since it's obvious that it tries to mimic it's mechanisms and gameplay style.)

PROS: 1. Semi-Darksouls action combat - If you like the way Darksouls I & II handles combat chances are, you'll probably like the way this game handles it as well. The difference is that the combat in Darksouls is faster and more flashy.
2. Beautiful Graphics - Although the graphics are brilliant and beautiful (scenery, armor, weapons, you name it...) some of them are a bit samey". (More on that in CONS)
3. The story - Unlike Darksouls where you have to scrape the story from item descriptions and where most of it you decide and invent for yourself
date: the story here is way more accessible. You are a convicted criminal whose crimes are tattooed on your face and your mission is to redeem yourself by destroying a fallen god. Sounds fun! There are more hidden lore bits found out from the few NPCs and much more numerous log files.\n4. Performance - I only played the game after the latest patch and can confirm that on my system (i5 3
hoursPlayed: Nvidia 770GTX
voteText: 16GB ram
helpfulPercent: SSD disk
votesHelpful: every graphics setting maxed out) the game held a stable 60fps 99% of the time with maybe 2-3 times dropping to 45-50 FPS and only on specific places.\n5. Bugs - with the recent patches most have been squashed. Haven't really noticed any during my gameplay.\n6. Game Mechanics - There is a risk-reward system implemented in the game that works really well. The more enemies you slay before resting at a checkpoint the more it increases your exp. multiplier which in turn increases the exp. gain from other enemies. But if you are killed
votesTotal: that exp. will slowly drain away until you either collect it back or it drains completely. The only real big difference from the darksouls games.\n\nMEH: 1. Difficulty - Harder than most games

Want to role-play a squishy mage? Nope

reviewText:
Took me 20 hours.
In the 20 hours, I have:
- never had a single crash
- never seen a single bug
- never had a single framedrop

What I did have was a great fun. It is an easier game than Dark Souls (I finished both DS games), I finished most bosses pretty quickly. And yeah bosses are not as memorable as in DS games, mostly consisting of humanoid knights. But they were fun to fight anyway.
The level design is pretty good. I enjoyed exploring it and the graphics is amazing (played maxed, but without nvidia turbulence stuff since I have AMD 280X).

Considering the likely low budget and zero experience of the developers with this kind of game, I am super impressed with what they achieved and I hope they will keep this quality and improve upon in for the future games.

If there are some nitpicks..I did not like many invisible walls, and I am still not fan of the art style. I do not hate it, but I do prefer more realistic style of Witcher / DS games. This is subjective though.

As for the Denuovo anti-tamper, I had zero issues with it. Would never know it is there if it wasn't for the internet making a huge fuss of everything.

reviewText:
I played this game with low expectations since there are so many negative reviews. But you know what, I had a lot of fun and the game is surprisingly good.
It's not as good as DS2. Lords of the Fallen is much shorter, easier (specially towards the end), cliche story, a few problems in its battle mechanics, but definitely not as bad as some people have been writting.
I have to say I bought this game in a 75% off steam sales, but I'd say it is worth even at 50%.

Give it a go if you enjoyed Dark Souls and Dark Souls2, just don't expect the same level of game!

reviewText:
Lords of the Fallen is a third person action-role-playing game with heavy emphasis on melee combat mechanics and tactics.

The Great:

- Melee combat is exceptional and some of the best in the industry
- Significant weapon variety that leads to numerous differing yet satisfying playstyles
- Each weapon's unique playstyle feels great and is fun to experiment with
- Combat is timing and pattern based making each encounter important and fulfilling to complete
- Game is gorgeous to look at even with details turned down

The Good:

- Environments are beautiful and intricately crafted (if a little small)
- Enemy and boss designs are interesting and show creativity

The Bad:

- The story is forgettable, confusing at times and makes little sense given the scope of the game
- The side characters feel tacked on, tropish, and overall of little value or consequence
- The main character is meant to be a jerk, and there are few options to choose not to be a jerk
- I experienced several game-crashing bugs over 25+ hours

Conclusion:

The game is buggy, and the writing of the characters and story leaves much to be desired, but the combat in both its precision and variety is able to save this game from the trash pile and ultimately make it one of the best RPGs of the year.

9.0 / 10.0

reviewText:
Updated with more structure.

Why I wrote this rant:
It sucks to know so many people are being turned away from this game due to the top review (which isn't the top review now, but it was at the time of writing this) being so negative. I read through the entire review, and came to the conclusion that the guy didn't like the game, felt like he wasted $50 bucks, and decided to write his first review on a good game that he couldn't grasp around what it actually is, in oppose to what he wanted it to be, and it's turning away many people from it. I was almost one of them, but all I could read was someone complaining about everything that this game is suppose to be. So, I picked it up, I have logged 8 hours into it, and I think, personally, he was wrong, but those are his opinions.


Combat & controls rant:
This game is great, and it has very fluid tight gameplay that beats that of the Souls series. And if you played the Souls games you'll feel at home with the controls for Lords. I'm currently playing as a brawler. So I'm heavily focused on heavy CQC. You got a heavy attack, light attack, parry, block, barrel roll, and all the cool stuff like catching the little ♥♥♥♥ in an epic attack animation by catching him from behind. Attacking is damn near perfect, and every weapon I have used so far holds its own weight, and requires you to change up your strategy because one heavy weapon might be heavier than the other, and that might prolong the hit giving the enemy more time to counter. The lighter the weapon, the faster the hit, but the cost is of course dealing less damage, but giving you more reaction time is always a positive. Blocking actually feels like blocking, and to my surprise blocking while two-handing a weapon isn't going to screw you over. The hitboxes are on point, and you aren't left questioning how you're caught on a hit even though you are not in the line of attack.

Magic rant:
This game of course uses its share of magic, but I feel like it is a bit limited depending on the class you initialing picked. I am a brawler so I have four magic spells:

Prayer: You bring out a clone to divert the enemies attention while restoring some health over time.
Rage: Gives you more attack power, and removes energy restrictions.
Ram: Unleash a strong charging force that damages, staggers, and can knock down enemies.
Quake: Giant hammer that comes down and wrecks face.

Each spell is very useful depending on the situation, and can really save your ♥♥♥. I don't really have much input on the spells really because I'm still on my first playthrough of the game, and this is as much as I currently know.

Customizing rant:
The customization in this game is great because it gives you an assorted list of good weapons and armors that you can actually use due to interest instead of picking up a bunch of useless gear to toss out later. It features armoring feet, hands, chest, and legs. Weapons are of course in variety such as swords, axes, fist weapons, polearms, hammers, etc. One thing to note is the equipping runes in your gear slots. Runes help in terms of boosting defenses against elements, or adding elements to weapon properties. It's pretty good when you add fire to your projectiles. Nothing beats some nice damage over time on ranged enemies.

Leveling system rant:
The leveling system is the same as any Souls game, but with a twist. Gather experience to level up attribute points, or gain spell points, and if you die with the experience on you, you'll lose it all, but you can get it back by going back to where you died. The twist here is that the more experience you carry on you the better and more frequent the drops become in game from enemies. You also get on a killing streak experience multiplier if you hold on to your experience. The more enemies you kill, the more experience you get. When you die you have a matter of time to get to your experience to get the full value since it has a percentage timer that goes down the longer it takes you back to where you died. Really makes you question if you should use the experience before a boss fight.

Graphics rant:
The graphics are great, and can be taxing on your computer, but so far I have everything set on high, and haven't run into much issues. I've gotten some framerate issues in areas heavy with particle effects like snowy areas, and encounter issues in tight corridor places as well, but they aren't game breaking, but they can be annoying. I turn down my settings to low when I stream on twitch, and the game still looks gorgeous. I love the PhsyX usage in the game. Some particle effects just make me cream everywhere. I currently run two Nvidia 680 4GB in SLI, i7-2700K, and 16GB RAM.

Soundtrack rant:
I've had some issues with character dialog cutting out here 'n there, and in some places the music gets super loud for no reason, and it'll go back to normal randomly. Aside from that the soundtrack is great, and it draws you into this gritty world. For some odd reason it reminds me of Diablo 2. I really can't break down soundtracks and music, so yeah. That's that.

Story, characters, and enemies rant:
The story is lackluster so far. You play as Harkyn, a criminal who did a lot of bad ♥♥♥♥, and is looked down upon by everyone, but is freed by a monk who saw in him the ability to fight off the evil gods and their demons. That's as much as I know since I have yet to beat the game, but it's your typical story with a badass over-powered protagonist. But! I do love the characters in this game since they are so entertaining, and have their own unique humor, characteristic traits, and what not. The voice acting is pretty good though the lip-syncing is off. Enemy design is great and unique, the enemies all have their own characteristics that make them different from one 'n another, so it keeps it fun & challenging. One enemy will run at you with a constant barrage of attacks making you shield up, and go for the perfect backstap. Other enemies are a fortress of defense waiting for you to attack so they can parry, and wreck your ♥♥♥♥. The bosses are kinda repetitive in design, but hold their own challenge. I won't go far into depth on bosses because spoilers. If you are a master at these kind of games you will own them no problem, but with me I died a couple times trying to get down the right strategy.

Outcome rant:
The game isn't punishing like Dark Souls which can be a good or a bad thing depending on who you are asking, but I think it is refreshing, and gives the new IP good ground to expand to something wonderful, and make this into a great series of games. I have fully enjoyed everything I have played of this game so far. I have played both Dark Souls, and Demon's Souls, and awaiting for Bloodborne. Huge fan of these kind of games, and this game fits in its genre as a little more casual, but definitely a lot of fun. I'd say give it a go. A solid 8/10 for me. I'm not much of a reviewer, but this game does justice. I just felt the need to say it.

TL:DR~

Pros:
+ Great fluid combat, and spot on hitboxes.
+ Plenty of customizing and armory to fit your play style.
+ Leveling is easy to learn and use, and holds its weight in deciding how your going to progress through the game.
+ Graphics are splendid, and the world is gorgeous.
+ Soundtrack is empowering.
+ Majority of the enemies hold their own challenges, making you switch up your style of gameplay to put 'em down faster.
+ Most of the characters I have met in the game are pretty funny. Humor is always nice in anything.

Cons:
- The story is your typical save the world of mankind with a super strong buff dude who has to make up for his crimes.
- Magic spells in this game can be useful, but overall they are pretty boring and can be forgotten.
- Framerate issues here 'n there, but I'm sure this can be patched.
- Character lip-syncing is way off, and it just looks silly.
- Bosses are pretty repetitive.

8/10

reviewText:
TLDR: Overall, moments of entertainment locked behind odd design choices and unresolved glitches that makes it impossible to recommend.
EDIT: And I feel bad for not being able to recommend it because I did have some good fun and effort was clearly made.

First the good:
-The character/monster/environment designs are well done, it's all massive muscles, massive armour and massive weapons but if you don't mind that it's nicely done.
-When the combat works, it can be fun.

The mixed (subjective):
-The armour sets are well designed, as mentioned above, but the standard as you go through set progression is inconsistent. For light armour for example, you get the best designed armour about half way through then get sets that seem much more 'vanilla' or are (I believe) reskins of previous sets.
-The story isn't terrible, but I'm still unsure about the premise. Why exactly is Adyr the god considered a 'villain'? I may have missed an audio log that explains this, but then it is still missable.
-There is a universal cooldown on spells, use one and they all go on cd (at least the ones from the same school do, can't verify whether it applies to other schools). On some combinations this may make sense, on others it seems overly restrictive. Keep in mind that without massive xp investment into faith (magic), the mana cost of each spell is likely prohibitive of chain casting anyway. Not impossible mind you, but when you factor in the cast time of each spell and the likelihood of interruption by enemy hits, a gcd seems superfluous.
-Combat staggering seemed unpredictable across the board, both on you and the enemies. There seemed no way of knowing ahead of time whether Harkyn would get staggered by any given enemy's attacks or whether they would be staggered by his.
-Certain classes may seem underpowered, mileage may vary. Rogue class definitely could have used some life steal baked in to a spell.
-Majority of voice work is bland, not all but a lot of it.
-The rune/crafting system seemed inconsistent. The game features a system where you can invest xp into locked runes  to increase the likelihood of better quality buffs but the return on this seemed very disappointing. Possibly rectified with better 'Luck' character stats but that's uncertain.

The bad:
-The hit detection is suspect. Weapon strikes simply may decide not to land, spell hits may just not register.
-Enemy projectiles may not hit you when they should and may seek you out through walls.
-Equipment stats are confusing. You are given numbers without context. Conversely some items have only 'fluff' descriptions.
-The camera may decide to snap to a completely obscured perspective during 'backstabs'.
-Spell effects may also overwhelm your vision.
-The gauntlet is intrusive and frequently redundant. It seemed underpowered no matter which class or loadout was used, an enemy could always be reached to melee them anyway, using it costs mana that would 9 times out of 10 be better used on spell casting and it is unalterably bound to the stance swapping button which gets in the way during combat.
-The physics are unbelievable in a bad way. Enemies may do a U-turn mid leap, defying momentum. The enemy also has a bad habit of tracking your motion during weapon swings that would likely snap their bones, also rendering combat maneuvering futile. This becomes more of a problem with the more fragile classes.
-Pathing is incompetent. Enemies may get stuck on corners or non existent obstacles, may reset and speed off to their original point (no, not that one demon dog who is scripted to do something similar).
-Harkyn's magic is wildly unreliable. Magic may simply not do what it is supposed to. Direct damage spells may just not land despite hitting the mark. Buffs may drop off before their proper duration or not do as described. Bad pathing also applies here.
-Even after hours of play time, the cumbersome nature of the spell casting can still be infuriating. Enemy AI is unreliable as to attacking during casting, they may knock you out of it or stand there and wait. A hit the wrong side of a millisecond may interrupt a 'complete' cast.
-Controls are unreliable, Harkyn may simply ignore commands. The most frequent suspect for me was the running shield bash attack, it simply didn't happen about 40% of the time and would land Harkyn in hot water each time. Dodges may simply not occur either.
-Saves may not be complete, by which I mean you can save your progress at a checkpoint or even move to a new area and quit and when you reload, the game may simply not have saved to that point. On a whim.
-Desktop crashes. Frequent and exacerbated by the above problem.

Overall - Solid.

reviewText:
LotF is a game I won’t be revisiting in the long term, but I definitely enjoyed it enough for the time I have spent with it up to now. I’d love to recommend it, but it falls short of expectations.

LotF is a game that (predictably) uses a combat system similar to that in the Souls games. You control Harkyn from the 3rd person perspective and probe enemies for patterns & weaknesses before moving in to finish them off using a weapon of your choice. There's a relatively large selection of weapons & armour to choose from, with the game slowly allowing you access to more powerful items as you continue with the linear narrative. The combat is functional and usually fun, but can be a little clunky at times, and the spells are often completely underwhelming and are more useful for tactical purposes. If you like to play RPGs as a mage then honestly you should probably avoid this game. You have access to one long range weapon which you can use in a variety of ways, but I found it most useful for pulling single enemies out of larger groups.

The game looks pretty good with a very consistent art-style, and the two major areas had very distinctive visual themes. The enemies were well designed and the environments were pretty, even if you could tell how constrictive they were. The armour designs were not to my taste (far too large and “showy”) and were a bit reminiscent of the kind of over-sized armour you see on space marines from 40k. The enemy animation was good enough for me to easily distinguish between what attacks they were winding up which allowed the combat to flow. The sound was not up to the same standard as the visuals: the scripting and voice acting in LotF are simply atrocious. Conversations often have sentences that don’t really follow on from the last, being said in tones that don’t follow the mood, on subjects you couldn’t care less about. The poor voice acting really impacts on the narrative too, as it is delivered in a very obvious and linear manner through conversations and cutscenes. The story simply plods along from A to B with few surprises. The audiobooks add meat to the narrative and are delivered with far more convincing speech than that from actual characters in the game, without them the story would have been paper-thin and completely forgettable (which is why so little of this review is dedicated to the story).

I have a few more gripes about LotF as well. The biggest issue is that after finishing, not much changes in NG+ except that enemies have far more health, which really kills the replayability. My second largest issue is the scaling/levelling seems very oddly balanced: even when not using checkpoints for long periods of time to get extra XP, I rarely built up enough experience to increase Harkyn's capabilities in a noticeable manner; sometimes adding a point into Strength actually reduced the damage of my equipped Strength-scaling weapon and I have literally no idea why. Thirdly there are some technical problems: occasionally the game would outright crash, resulting in complete loss of everything you’ve done since last touching a checkpoint; the frame-rate would often bomb to unplayable levels; and sometimes the load times between areas would take unusually long.

It probably sounds like I’ve panned LotF, but I did manage to enjoy my time with it despite its failings. If you like 3rd person fantasy RPGs then this is worth the price of admission in a sale.

reviewText:
Finally! 60+ hours into the game and it's 100% completed. Although there is an obvious inspiration of Dark Souls in the core of this game, you'll quickly realize this is by no means a DS killer...far from it. It's still a cool alternative and change of pace though.

Pros:

Gorgeous Dark Fantasy setting
Overall character designs are top notch, especially armor/weapons
Combat feels smooth and fast. You really feel the weight of your gear clashing with the enemies'
Good voice acting
Music and sound design is superb
Cons:
Wants to be Dark Souls but isn't
Kind of an uninspired story, with a final encounter you'll see coming from a mile away
Too many weapons/armor. Although this seems cool, you'll ignore the vast majority of them
Both the controls and camera can be your worst enemy in some cases
Occasional crash
Short campaign

reviewText:
Originally the 'mixed' rating had put me off, but I decided to try this during a sale.

In a way that was a good thing, going in with low expectations and being pleasantly surprised.  The things that made me happy about it:

Good graphics
Gorgeous environments
Framerate not capped at 30 (ahem)
Difficult mobs/bosses
An actual storyline
I had a read through many of the negative reviews and a lot of it is down to personal frustrations.  While in some places the game is actually quite unforgiving, I didn't think it warranted such negativity - difficulty spikes and overcoming them are part of the excitement of playing games like these.  The lesson I learned here was to take these Steam ratings with a pinch of salt.

But to each their own, I will say - if you like fantasy-setting style games with difficult yet rewarding fights, try this out.

I would advise you to have a look at a class guide first - I went in as a Solace Rogue and had a very tough time at some places but did manage to complete.

reviewText:
Lords of the Fallen is the first true attempt from a Western developer to imitate and improve upon the formula established by From Software, and it's a mighty successful one. Though not without its shortcomings, the game fully delivers on its basic premise and it lays the groundwork for more games in the IP; with excellent graphics and solid action/RPG gameplay, fans of the genre should be pleased.

A disclaimer from someone who could never fully get into Dark Souls to others like me: don't dismiss this game just because of that. Lords of the Fallen does a better job to help newcomers; you'll die and hate it at first, indeed, but eventually you will grow to love it.

Read the full review at http://www.worldsfactory.net/2014/10/28/lords-of-the-fallen-review-trying-trying-again
voteText: 319 of 470 people (68%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Imitation is the sincerest form of flattery, and the developers of Lords of the Fallen have made it no secret that they aim to recreate the magic of the Souls franchise. A series defined by brutal difficulty, ambient storytelling and a constant sense of despair, fear, and loneliness; Lords of the Fallen set quite a high goal, and it’s sad that it seems they weren’t able to make it all the way there.

The story of Lords of the Fallen follows Harkyn, a gruff no-nonsense criminal released to defeat an invading enemy known as the Rhogar. Most of the game takes place in the Keystone Citadel, a vast castle set upon a snowy mountain at the peak of the world. The story seems ambiguous at first, with only mere mentions of Harkyn’s crimes and little backstory given other than the Rhogar seek to destroy humanity.

There are developments, a few twists and turns, but they ultimately amount to nothing. The world is fairly uninteresting, and little inspiration was taken from the Souls series in creating a world that makes you wonder why everything has fallen to ruin. I cared little for Harkyn, and even less for the characters in the game. There are a few NPCs scattered about and a couple sidequests to complete, but really, this is a game focused on combat first, story second.

As for the combat, it’s solid enough. You have a typical Souls control scheme, with light and heavy attacks, a dodge roll, a magic projectile-firing gauntlet, and the ability to two-hand or sword-and-board. Backstabbing is still the name of the game here, although the equipment and armor allow for a more tank-oriented player to hunker down instead of dodging and utilizing invincibility frames. Magic is also a tool at the player’s disposal, though the variety is rather interesting.

There are three trees of magic you select from at the start of the game, focusing on certain strengths. All three trees receive Prayer, which spawns a decoy that any enemy, bosses included, will blindly attack instead of Harkyn. I only ever found use in the Brawler tree, where the abilities seemed extremely overpowered. Ram is essentially a fireball that goes through enemy shields, Rage allows unfettered use of an unending pool of stamina, and Quake is just straight-up a lightning bolt that wrecks everything in eyesight. There’s really no room for subtlety or complexity in this magic system, a plus for some and a minus for others.

To be honest, most of the game’s combat feels much like the magic system: there is a sense of mind-numbing difficulty, but streamlined in order to not deter players who aren’t used to this sort of punishment. You’ll be challenged, but rarely punished. There’s a variety of approaches, whether you choose to strip off your armor and go fast and quick against the mightiest of bosses, or want to spam Ram on every minion in sight, and every strategy is viable.

The trade-off is that there is little of the depth or complexity that enraptured Souls fans in the past. There is little variety in weapons, outside of the addition of gauntlets. Gameplay is interesting, but you won’t see as many gimmick builds or min-maxing as you would in a Souls game. This is furthered by the fact there is no multiplayer in any form; the lack of invasion gameplay and one-on-one duels means that your primary means of perfecting combat is against minions and bosses.

Bosses are a major factor in any character action game, and even more-so in Lords of the Fallen. After facing encounter after encounter, your prowess and mettle is tested to the fullest by these monstrosities. The bosses are definitely special encounters, and stand out compared to the common fold of enemies. They’re difficult, and you’ll bang your head against the wall a few times trying to pass them.

To be frank, the bosses of Lords of the Fallen are just not memorable in the slightest. It doesn’t help that they’re given little to no backstory, and labeled simply as “Commander” or “Worshipper” or “Infiltrator.” Souls games often had memorable encounters, heightened by the lore leading up to them and given meaning by the events of the game; battles against titans like Sif, Gwyn and Artorias have meaning behind them, and are a culmination of the player’s actions. The Rhogar bosses feel arbitrary, as do the rest of the bosses in Lords of the Fallen. They act as an end goal, a finish line, but signify little more than that.

Lords of the Fallen can’t be painted over as simply a Souls copy, however. It does a few things to expand upon and innovate the mechanics of the pseudo-genre, and it does these well. The experience system of Lords is similar to the soul-collecting mechanic, where experience is earned from enemy kills and completing objectives, and dropped on the ground upon death.

You not only have to recover these after your respawn, but you only have a certain time-frame to do so. The experience will gradually decay after some time, and eventually disappear. You also gain experience multipliers and extra loot the longer you hold onto your experience, at the cost of potentially losing it. You can “bank” you experience at checkpoints, but even this has it’s own set of risks. You can apply experience towards either a point for your stats or a point for your magic. These mechanics create a constant risk-reward balancing act, and is very fulfilling. I often found myself questioning whether to bank my XP into that spell point I was aiming for, or potentially lose it all in an upcoming boss fight where I wouldn’t have a good opportunity to reclaim my points.

Graphically, the game is beautiful on high-end PCs. Console versions suffer from framerate issues, but on the standard gaming computer, this game will run at a clean 1080p at 60 FPS. The kicker for PC users is that they should prepare to deal with a wealth of bugs and glitches. I had several game-breaking bugs, which lost me massive amounts of progress and several chunks of hair. Also, camera control is abysmal in most hallways and corridors. While you have control of the camera, the automatic pans and swings around for backstabs or dodges are really annoying to deal with while you’re managing a million other things on-screen.

Overall, Lords of the Fallen captures the Souls essence in a base sense, and provides a nice entry point for those intimidated by the series’ infamous difficulty. Where it failed to capture its inspiration’s essence was in the lore and storytelling, both of which fall flat in Lords. This is an enjoyable romp through a series of difficult bosses, and it does a nice job of making you feel like you’ve grown from a measly warrior to unstoppable force by the end of the game. Just don’t expect the same depth that inspired the fanatical cult following of the Souls games.

reviewText:
Praise the  sun  \0/

Review in Progress : will add on more

Lord of Fallen is a beautiful third person hack and slash game that  is grim, challenging and reminds me of a of  Dark souls  with different hit mechanics, better graphics,  enemies with more abilities and a more articulate  plot.

StoryThe game plets player assume the role of Harkyn as the words a different time and war pop up after the cinematic. Apparently, he is on a journey with another man traveling to a  monastery and has lost many men on the way. Only on arrival and opening the doors did they see that the monastery is completely empty and bodies' litter the entire room and demonlike enemies starts attacking....

ClassesThree discipline  type for magic: Deception, Brawling, and Solace of magic to choose from and three equipments type to start off, Cleric, Warrior, and a rogue type class.
Brawling is focused on offensive magic. Solace is focused on more protective and healing while deception is focused more on more of a mix of imparing and debuffing enemies.
Variety of spells seems limited in this game for all 3 tree has similar spells.

Controls
The various attacks that can be performed are  weak and strong attack, rolling, running, jumping, back stepping, parry, frontal kicks, and dodging. The invincibility frames, however, are completely different and more precise when evading. There is a Magic and a Stamina bar so running, attacking, or evading use stamina while magic of any sort from spells to the gauntlet uses the magic bar.

The initial layout for the controls is almost exactly the same as DS, if you know the controls, you'll understand this game right away. The only difference is the use of items and cycling it since it has to be favorite set or used from the inventory screen.

When attacking you can chain combos with your weak and strong attacks, How hard you hold down an attack will cause it to use up more stamina so technically both your  strong attack have additional stronger attack. Included in attacks is also dual wielding or single weapons with both hands wields depending upon the weapon type. Later in the game players will discover a gauntlet weapon that will allow different type of attacks with spells such as range, aoes etc that uses magic. Runeslotting begins later on changing up items.

The keyboard controls are bindable and the default is really decently bound through for this. The gamepad layout is similar to DS.

EnemiesEnemies in the game starting off are a bit unpredictable due to having various attack patterns and having the ability to swing in various radius and also turning around. Some enemies such as bosses will have numerous fighting patterns that switched up depending on how much you damaged them. Stealth dispatching of enemies exist if you walk up to them slowly. Don't always depend too  much on trying to attack or evading from behind because you can still get hit from enemies when they swing their weapons near your character and they respond really fast

Some of the AI is really stupid. I have seen my character stealth past them right in the front just by walking and not a single reaction from their line of sight at all and being able to do a stealth attack to kill them.

Gameplay:
After defeating  the first boss It seems that the points can be stored towards attributes or spells, Not storing can cause perma loss, but if you don't save or use your points  you can gain more experience and earn with higher kill streaks by playing on. Saving requires save shards nearby and going across the character development screen and where exp points can be banked. Upon dying players will have a limited time to gather their lost experience floating around that looks like a wisp which will need to be grabbed or you'll lose it.
Most of the areas  of the game and map are open or enclosed  where enemies are plenty an ambush you along with  certain unique monsters hidden throughout that can cause your downfall so thread carefully, when enemies are encountered  lock on, swing and chain combos or your choice on bypassing them if you want. if you die or use a  save shard they will respawn most of the time. There
are plenty of areas and chambers to explore.
Combos are important for the play if one wants to master more damage and mastering them can be quite tough. Using your experience to upgrade your stats is also as important in order to do more combos, take more hits and gain more stats in surviving this world.
During the story there will be certain choices players can take which are either evil or good. There are also dialogue options to help players better understand the story and situation at hand.

Stats in the game fall under strength, vit, faith, endurance, agility and luck
Strength for str weapons and to carry heavier gear, vit for health and potion effects, faith for mp pool and weapon magic damage, endurance for carrying more and stamina, agility for damage with fast weapons and energy, and luck for better items from enemies along with crafting material finds.

There are also three types of armor in the game, Light medium and heavy, which affects your character in variety of ways with your stamina and movemen and def. Most equips found are part of set until next playthrough

The maps are dark but extremely detailed with destructible about such as barrels, book cases, benches, etc. with  decent physics. There are potions,chests, portals and  items hidden throughout and audio scrolls that tells the story of the game.

Graphics Looks amazing and well done, graphics are gorgeous and really detailed, many destructible all over the environment. Game runs at 30 fps for me for some reason. Trying to push or uncap for more. The interface is completely different in the inventory though and seems more sleek and clean. The game lighting is great, and the effects are top notch. The art reminds me of warhammer and the enemies   bodyparts/armor chips away as you fight them. The animations are seriously well done though sometimes I notice my rogue doing some really weird glitch through on attacks and hopefully that's a bug that can be fixed.

Opinion?Game is awsome so far and borrows from DS well and DS borrows from Monster hunter well, Ds didn't invent the manual camera control style combat folks I've got games predating before DS.
I also like the precision of hit boxes though it can be wonky at times, the challenges and boss fight  to this game along with the immersive  graphics, Movement feel so fluid with the character, though more work needs to be done to iron out the bugs. Many are going to compare this to dark souls because it's very similar with the camera style and controls, but yet it's different in mechanics  especailly enemy targetting. The game is ok overall and difficulty starting off seems really hard as a rogue class as in omg i am getting my face ripped.

Pros so far+ Graphics looks amazing and really detailed. The Physics looks great when chipping at enemies.
+ Dark soul's layout on controllers, the keyboard and mouse are really well bound and plays a bit differently
+ Destructibles and physics DX 11 effects.
+ Interesting classes to mix up, though spells are limited
+ Great Voice acting and music scores that remind me of lord of the ring.
+ Immersive environment, Blowing winds, snowfall, Shadows, Lighting etc.
+ Enemy armors and weapons break as you attack them


Cons- No multiplayer
- Optimization on this game right now currently is. Completely WHACK and first game for me to have frame drops at the wierdest places had to turn off some options to get it to run well.
-The lip synching animation is horrible
- Spells lack variety
- starting  Bosses could be a bit challenging for some people.

Yt video - Working on it, too busy playing the game.

reviewText:
First of all, I really wanted to like that game, but it made it more and more impossible the more I played.

From the beginning to the second boss, I enjoyed the game and thought it is a nice souls clone. But after that I started to notice issues that annoyed me the more I played.
First, the enemies. While they are not really hard, there are enemies that take minutes to beat just because they are behind a tower shield. That would be no big problem, if your shield break and/or kick could shove the shield aside to make it possible for you to hit them. That won't work. Only thing that works is running shield bash, and even with that it takes way too long to kill them. The most stupid thing is that the enemies with the big shields have an shield bash + sword slash attack that is faster than anything you could do, even the light class + dagger doesn't offer that. Also, hitting enemies with big weapons doesn't seem to stagger them. There are unarmored crossbow wielding enemies that keep firing arrows at you while you hit them with a freakin'  hammer that has an attack animation of a train... The enemies are all very similar. The mutant knights you fought at the start keep appearing through the game with just more health and damage. That is true for all enemies.

Next, the boss fights. I haven't finished the game yet, but what i have seen already makes me sad. The bosses are really easy, because they have 3-5 types of attack they repeat. A LotF boss battle follows always the same pattern. Get away when they do attack a, b or c. Roll away from attack d and attack for 1/1000 damage to their health bar. Repeat 10-20 minutes, you win. :(

The area is relatively small and feels uninspired. At first sight, the game looks awesome and it does really have nice graphics. But later it is just repetitive and uninspired somehow. Also, after the second boss you don't know where to go. I went everywhere, beat the big shield guys near the back entrance and gone through the graveyard to the catacombs". The NPC weren't at the place he supposed to be to let me into the other dimension/world. After I got out there i where supposed to go through the catacombs again. Also
date: catacombs is no area name but is the quest location. Confusing. Levers and that kind of stuff is hard to make out from the background of rubbish and debris.\n\nThe checkpoint system makes the game unnecessarily easy. The enemies only respawn after you die
recommended: so you can replenish your health and vials infinitely while progressing through the area. While the bonus exp system is there to balance that
hoursPlayed: it doesn't work. The bonus is just not enough to make it worth to "gamble" for it with less healing.\n\nThe character development and crafting is very disappointing. You choose one of three classes and then stay with 4 more or less useful spells. Crafting is not existent. There are runes you can put in some of your weapons and armor
voteText: but they are only a few and not really interesting or game changing in any meaning. Also
helpfulPercent:
you do get the ability to put runes into your stuff only after the second boss. ... if you found the right way directly. A little bit late for my taste.

The story and NPCs are not overwhelming but also not bad. Standard mediocre medieval monster stuff. Nothing impressing or interesting.

The whole game feels slow. Really slow. Take Dark souls and make it 3 times slower. I don't see any gain from that. I want slow attack speed with ultra greatswords but not with small axes. Also
votesHelpful: fast roll feels slow. Moving is slow
votesTotal: magic and shooting is slow. Not really fun to play like that. Souls gave you options
votesFunny: LotF gives you nearly nothing. Of course there are differences between light and heavy armor
commentsCount: but it's just too little in my opinion.\n\nThe controls are badly programmed. Locked on an enemy

too. The lock-on is clumsy and sometimes just annoys the ♥♥♥♥ out of you.

Conclusion
*First impression is nice

reviewText:
Deserves better reviews than it has. Apparently was riddled with bugs when released (lots of crashing, poorly optimised), but I had no problems running it on high settings with a modest mid-range rig (i5 3570k, AMD 7870, 8GB RAM). It also gets compared to Dark Souls a lot, and rightly so, but I don't think any game should be negatively reviewed for being 'not as good as Dark Souls', as that's a pretty high bar. So without further ado, lets dive right in and compare it directly to Dark Souls!

Similar to Souls:
Checkpoint system, red floating crystals instead of bonfires. Replenish HP / MP / potions, enemies respawn.
Melee combat mechanics - parry (only with subset of shields), backstabs, stamina management, dodgerolls, staggering, light attack, heavy attack, running attack etc. Similar range of weapons. % Equipment load determines movement and dodgeroll speed. 'Weighty' feel to larger weapons.
Weapons (but not armour) have stat requirements. Some weapons scale with their relevant stat.
Loot - set loot gained through chests, enemies have a chance of dropping 'runes' (for upgrades) or equipment (rare). No duplicate armour / weapons.
Level design - sprawling areas that loop back into each other by unlocking shortcuts. Lots of secret items and areas.
Leveling - bank experience at checkpoints to level up attributes / spells, each subsequent level requires more.
Upon death your exp is left as a 'ghost' with a timer on it, or until your next death.
NG+ and NG++ for multiple playthroughs.
Decimate furniture by rolling into it
Different from Souls
No fast travel from checkpoint to checkpoint, not a massive problem because;
Smaller world, fast traveling would have been nice at times, but overall not a big problem.
Shorter game, could be finished in maybe 8 hours if you don't explore much. Personally it took me around 15 hours.
No invincibility during dodgeroll that I am aware of. Causes some moments of anger if you're used to Dark Souls, but you get used to it.
Magic - each class (warrior, thief, cleric) has a set of 4 spells that can be unlocked and leveled up at checkpoints, separately from attribute points. There is also a gauntlet that has 3 modes of fire (basically different ranges), which gains power with more Faith (cleric / magic build). Both share an MP pool.
Much more straightforward story, quite typical dark fantasy stuff, not too abstract or anything.
Equipment upgrading is done through a 'rune' system - you gain sealed runes from defeating enemies, and unlock them to reveal type (eg power / fire / luck), runes range from 'lesser' to 'flawless' and can be attached and detached at will from equipment that has slots.
No multiplayer aspect
Other notes: The game looks great - dark atmosphere, good enemy/boss design, weapons / armour look suitably fantasy, so you get that extra bit of satisfaction from new gear. The melee combat is heavily emphasised, ranged combat is minimal (pretty much limited to gauntlet). Many weapon types have very slow attack speed, which can take a bit of getting used to, but there are claws and daggers for faster attacks (this is how I played) which are perfectly viable. It is not as big or complex as Dark Souls, but still holds it's own as a solid Action-RPG with dark fantasy flavour, good melee combat, and some side quests and extra exploration encouraged to flesh out the experience.

All in all I really enjoyed my time playing Lords of the Fallen, and seeing as you can get it for disgustingly cheap when it's on sale these days, I don't see why you shouldn't pick it up.

reviewText:
(TL;DR? This review is also available in video format for your convenience below.)

With the recent success of the Souls franchise and its emphasis on precision timed combat and high difficulty it was only a matter of time before imitators would listen to the herald of success.  Lords of the Fallen brings its own take on the punishing hack n slash genre.  While there's no hiding its influence from Dark Souls, it doesn't manage to improve the formula enough to justify its own existence.

The differences between the two titles will be immediately apparent.  You'll be moved throughout the game through a much more direct plot than the subtle nuanced on-goings of the Souls games.  You play as Harkyn, a prisoner released by Kaslo, to hold off an invasion from the imposing forces of Rhogar who are subverting the natural order of things in his world.  The story is rather empty and predictable for the most part and is told through clumsy character animations with flat voice acting.  It manages to do little else other than keep things moving along through the 12-20 hour campaign.

The visuals are solid for the most part and offer well lit, moody environments to explore.  Initially, the world feels large and expansive with a host of optional areas to explore but you'll soon come to realize most of these areas will require you to delve into them at one point or another throughout the story, making the interconnected albeit small castle that you spend the majority of the game in feel limited.  There isn't a huge variety in locations either as you'll generally be exploring the snowy exterior of the citadel or its gloomy interior.  The whole thing feels pretty underwhelming by the time you finish it all.

Game play is very similar to the sword and board melee combat of Dark Souls but with a much more limited assortment of spells available to its three classes.  You'll also be welcomed with a large pool of life, a recharging mana bar, and a steady supply of healing potions that make the encounters considerably easier than its counterpart.  Bosses are intended to offer unique fights but by the end of the game you can overcome some of the more difficult bosses by simply buffing yourself with magic and pulverizing the boss to death before they can inflict enough damage back to offset your relentless assault.  The camera can also be a bit irritating as your battles can be hidden by hanging banners and other furniture with dips in the frame rate being commonplace. Enemies also tend to offer little variety with only around a dozen types with the shielded ones being the most annoying to fight since they rely on blocking a little too much causing conflicts with them to become prolonged and irritating.  All of that being said though, while not meeting the standard that Dark Souls met and being a little slower, it still manages to be competent enough to enjoy the game's short duration.

The items that you acquire are all well designed and offer a much flashier aesthetic than what you'll find with most of the armor and weapons in the Souls games.  While you can upgrade gear and items with its rune system, you'll be frequently re-socketing pieces as replacements since upgrades will come frequently.  The soundtrack holds its own but doesn't manage to leave any lasting impression as is a common theme with the game.

One of the cooler aspects of Lords is the risk/reward mechanic behind its gameplay that rewards you for holding onto a larger amount of experience that can be cashed in with a multiplier that rises with each enemy killed, although it unfortunately only caps at 2.  You'll also be urged to return to your body quickly as the amount of experience you regain is based on the speed at which you reclaim your corpse.  Although the lack of overall difficulty in this compared to Dark Souls trivialized this aspect a bit as I was always able to run by enemies and regain my corpse quickly on the few occasions that I died.  Upon completing this game you'll be rewarded with a New Game + option that raises the difficulty and unlocks more spell trees but that's if you're able to get to the end which leads to Lords of the Fallen's biggest problem, game breaking bugs.

While clearing out the missed collectables and locked doors throughout the world that I hadn't gone back yet to open just before the final boss I fell down a hole which killed my character.  Instead of respawning at my last visited checkpoint, the game quick saved and spawned me at the bottom of the hole which I was unable to escape from, or reload a previous save.  So with that, I had gone as far as I could without restarting the game on a new save file and playing through the entire game again to finish the final act.  Glitches like this are inexcusable in a finished product and should've been tested out before release.  Luckily, I wasn't too wrapped up in the story to care that much of whether or not I saw the end.

Lords of the Fallen manages to feel like Dark Souls Lite, it offers similar but simpler, slower combat.  An interconnected but small world when compared to vistas like Lordran, and a risk/reward system with little actual risk.  In addition to all this it lacks any of the creative multiplayer features found in the Souls games.  If you're looking for something to hold you over until Bloodborne, Lords of the Fallen offers a strong initial impression that can scratch that itch for a very brief period of time.  Just be sure to watch your step and go into it with much lower expectations.


This review is also available in video format:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hONZT8hmPXc


Pros

+ Solid yet borrowed combat
+ Makes a strong first impression but loses momentum quickly
+ Good soundtrack

Cons

- Game Breaking Bugs
- Short length compared to Dark Souls
- Linear with the 'optional areas' not being optional.
- Does nothing original


If you enjoyed this review, feel free to follow me as a Steam Curator: http://store.steampowered.com/curator/4886473/

reviewText:
Ok, ok, this review has gone through a few iterations so bear with me people.

When I first played LOTF, I absolutely despised it.  Being a big fan of the Souls games, I was looking forward to some Souls-esque but-without-getting-stomped-by-overpowerd-invasions fun.  But dang, Harken was slow and seemed to spend about 10 seconds winding up his attacks before actually throwing them, and I quickly grew bored of this game and its unresponsive controls.  So, my first review was rather scathing, and lo many a fan boy/girl posted some rather immature and insulting comments, most of which have been deleted.  I’m a stoopid noob and I should go back to candy crush saga, apparently.  I also need to 'git gud' even though the difficulty of this game (which isn't much) was never an issue...

Being a cheapskate and wanting to get my money’s worth out of the game, I forced myself to complete.  And you know what?  LOTF is not a bad game.  I might even have enjoyed it a wee bit.  But I would not recommend this game unless it is on sale – because there are much better games (i.e. Dark Souls) which do everything LOTF does only much better.

Still, LOTF is bloody gorgeous, looking like Todd Macfarlane and Warhammer Fantasy got together to make a Cannibal Corpse album cover.  The armour and weapon designs are so ludicrously spikey and evil that I want to break out my old Slayer albums.  Sound is also great, with satisfying clunks and crashes giving combat a satisfying feel.  The bosses are super cool too.  I also particularly liked the system up upgrading weapons and armour with runes, which is very simple but kinda nice anyway.

However, I found the controls to feel really unresponsive.  No matter what class you play as, there’s a significant lag between actually hitting the attack button and Harken swinging whatever oversized spike metal thingy he is carrying.  It lead me to a lot of frustration, as I signed in vain while the enemy would rush off for a cup of tea, do the washing, then come back and put their shield up in the time it takes Harken to wind up his attack.  Second, the game is not really challenging, and it doesn’t have difficulty settings.  Most enemies can be overpowered just by circling endlessly and button mashing, and many of the bosses can be easily beaten on first try once their attack pattern has been seen a few times.  I understand that NG+ is more of a challenge, but I’d already lost interest by then.

In summary, my opinion, which you don’t have to agree with, is that LOTF is an ok Dark Souls-lite game, but I wouldn’t recommend it because Dark Souls, even Dark Souls 2, does EVERYTHING infinitely better aside from graphics.  Furthermore, if I’m in the mood for some fantasy hack and slash and I’m not in the mood for Dark Souls, I’d play Devil May Cry, Darksiders 2, Dragons Dogma, Revengence or something long before I’d go for LOTF.  but hey there seems to be a lot of ppl who really loved this...what does a stoopid noob like me know anyway? git gud or go home...

Edit - Now that Dark Souls 3 is out there is no need to even contemplate this game.  Or go with Salt and Sanctuary if your a 2d indie hispter - that said, if they make a sequel i'd give it a look as, if they got the gameplay right, this could easily be the Slayer album cover made flesh the never-dying 12 year old inside me is always looking for.

reviewText:
It's pretty hard to launch an all-new triple-A game nowadays due to the huge risk, the adversity towards it by the current video games industry, as well as the pretty finicky nature of actual players, who might judge things a bit too harsh.

Even so, Polish studio CI Games, formerly known for the Sniper: Ghost Warrior titles, together with German developer Deck13 Interactive, decided to bite the bullet and roll out Lords of the Fallen, a brand new role-playing game that features big characters, huge monsters, and tough combat, not to mention some pretty impressive visuals.

Lords of the Fallen follows the adventures of Harkyn, a prisoner whose crimes are written on his face. While the world is busy finding ways to vanquish all evil, an ancient god awakens and sends his Rhogar Lords to destroy it. As you can imagine, Harkyn is apparently the only man fit to go up against those demonic legions so he, together with mentor Kaslo, go on an epic quest to stop them from crushing the world. They get to explore a fair amount of environments and interact with different characters. Unfortunately, while you can make quite a few choices along the way, many don't have consequences and quite a few of the supporting cast members either use stereotype attitudes or are undeveloped. Plot moments are kept to a minimum and cut scenes do a decent job making things clear, without wasting time on things that don't immediately matter to the player. The world of the game gets fleshed out a bit more thanks to the audio diaries, but not many players will actually pay attention, which is a shame, as Deck13 and CI have done a great job in terms of world building.

Lords of the Fallen tries to combine the traditional role-playing mechanics with those seen in hack and slash titles, delivering a result that works pretty well. Harkyn isn't remotely as agile as Devil May Cry's Dante, but his moves are pretty swift and his blows pack quite a punch, depending on the equipped weapon type. You can pick between three classes – Warrior, Cleric, and Rogue. Each has its own magic category, relying on spells to buff survivability and damage for the warrior, healing and enemy manipulation for the cleric, or stealth and critical hits for the rogue. Leveling allows you to spend points in either the stats category, thereby boosting your health pool, your damage, and other such things, or the magic one, where you can unlock new spells to unleash, depending on your available Faith level. The combat relies on regular and heavy attacks, with the beefier ones requiring a few moments of build up before they're ready to go. Without a doubt, fans of the Souls games made by From Software will feel right at home, but there are quite a few more elements added on top to draw in more people.

Among them is the XP multiplier system. Each kill results in Harkyn getting more experience. When you reach the bonfire-like checkpoint, you can opt to use those points, thereby losing your multiplier, or you can keep going and see it increase exponentially. This high-risk, high-reward system is quite good, and if you die, you have a set amount of time to get back to your XP pile before it vanishes forever. The loot system is quite well done, and besides offering better and better armor or weapons, it also allows players to collect runes that can be used to provide great bonuses to your existing gear. These can often make or break a tough battle, so spending some time to analyze their pros and cons is essential. Unfortunately, you need to wait until you get to an NPC that can unlock the runes, so at least in the beginning you can only open certain chests with them.

The environments look quite impressive, but they don't vary all that much, as you'll often be fighting through ruined castles or snowy areas. The world of Lords of the Fallen certainly looks amazing but it's not explored all that much. What's more, the lack of a map or at least a semblance of a waypoint system means that you might end up going down wrong paths filled with enemies only to encounter closed doors and other such things. Thankfully, the enemy variety is quite solid, with a decent amount of monsters wielding different weapons, spells, and attacks going up against Harkyn during the campaign. Some of the Rhogar Lords require quite a bit of out-of-the-box thinking, but sufficiently leveling up certain skills, especially on the warrior, make a few of them die rather easily.

Of course, like in Dark Souls, the difficulty, at least in the beginning, is grueling, so expect plenty of deaths and other such things. Unfortunately, until you start leveling up your attributes and spells, you'll have a really tough time, especially when you go up against enemies that know when to use their shields. Some of their attack patterns are also erratic, so don't be fooled into thinking you've memorized their moves. Enemies are also quite agile, and in some cases, this exposes a few problems with hit and collision detection. Speaking of problems, you'll also find that there are no difficulty options. This means that experienced RPG fans might soon feel like their version of Harkyn becomes a bit too powerful towards the end stages of the game. There is a New Game + option that buffs difficulty but also allows your character to unlock a second type of magic spells from another class, so things get even easier if you make smart choices.

It's also worth noting that, at least right now, the game is quite unstable on the PC platform. It crashes in all sorts of moments and the framerate spikes when transitioning from inside areas to exterior ones. Enemies will sometimes freeze in place, and if you attack them, they'll immediately fight back in a flurry of frenzied blows.

Lords of the Fallen is a gorgeous experience in terms of visuals, delivering realistic graphics but with plenty of rich colors. Provided your computer can run it, turning on all the different effects makes the whole experience look even better. Character models are sharp and textures look amazing in quite a few situations, although in some things get blurry. Animations, unfortunately, are a bit erratic, especially when characters talk to one another, as they flinch and gesticulate even when they deliver regular sentences. Also, expect a lot of clipping when it comes to your character's cloak and shield.

Lords of the Fallen is a decent role-playing experience with some innovative features but it's weighed down by the balancing problems and the technical issues. After a few updates, it might become a good and challenging RPG, but for now, it falls short. It is still very much worth playing, so don't hesitate to pick this up on a sale.

Recommended
Be sure to check out Nerd House Gaming for more reviews!

reviewText:
Faulty's scorecard :-

1) Essential purchase
2) Recommended purchase3) Recommended purchase during a sale
4) Not recommended unless heavily discounted
5) Not even recommended for Steam game collectors

It was always going to be just a matter of time before another development house would try and take a stab at the Demon\Dark Souls blueprint that has brought From Software so much fame and success of late with its avant-garde gameplay that rewarded players by virtue of being cautious and patient and severely punishing those impatient fools who refused to play by the games rule book. Outside of Rougelikes, with its perma-death, the loss of ones in-game mortality has held little to no consequence in the modern day game ceasing to exist as nothing more than a source of annoyance and hindrance to its players rather than the learning aid it was originally intended to be. From Software was successfully able to remedy that indifference by imposing a series of penalties to the very lifeblood that makes up the modern day RPG - the experience or ability point that enables character progression. It was a bold and exciting move and something I am surprised to see so few games in the genre adopt. They say imitation is the sincerest form of flattery and now we have Deck 13, creators of Lords of the Fallen, on hand to shamelessly plunder the Souls treasure chest in a bid to steal away some of its lucrative bounty but does a developer from the west, a small team located in the very heart of Europe (Germany), have the verve to take on the Japanese at their own game?

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=385197764
Unfortunately no! However, with that being said - Deck 13 does display a certain level of mastery with Lords of the Fallen that while it never quite matches the heights set by its muse, does manage to replicate a fair bit of the essence of what makes a Soul game, a Soul game even when their own game lacks its own distinct personality. While playing Lords of the Fallen one is never quite able to shake the feeling that you are playing nothing more than a lite version of the original series but that shouldn't deter you from purchasing and playing Lords of the Fallen if your hold a strong affinity for this type of game. While the canvas may be smaller in ambition and scope (probably due to budgetary constraints) with fewer options available to its players (you can only select one of three magical paths - warrior, cleric, rouge), and you are stuck with your hurly-burly Gears-of-War type character (Harkyn) whether you like your Muscle Mary's or not (I am afraid there isn't even an option to change the characters sex) it still ends up being a blast to play. I chose the rouge magical set (something I felt more comfortable and at home with considering rouges are my RPG stable) and found it to be quite a bit over-powered once maximized which made the game a lot more easier than I had anticipated. It's also important to note that the selection of any one of the magical classes does not in anyway automatically place you on a predetermined path - you are still freely able to equip whatever armor and weaponry you want as your selection only affects your magical ability.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=366005027
Much like what you would encounter in a Souls game, when it comes to combat you will need to measure and time your attacks carefully. Many enemies have the ability to break your combat motion so learning when to attack and when to block or defend is paramount to your surival and you will need to quickly learn enemy attack patterns so that you can use it against your foes. Combat felt a little more sluggish and slower than what I was initially used to but it didn't take long before I settled into a rhythm (light armor for more flexibility) of my own. Should you perish at any given point in time, Harkyn will drop all accumulated experience points as he is returned to the last checkpoint activated. You are then given a set time to reclaim what has been lost (your spirit) before it decays completely (shown through the use of an onscreen timer). Should you not return to the site of your death during the given interval all experience points dropped are then lost. You can also only cash in these experience points at the various in-game checkpoints where you can either bank them into physical attributes or push them into your spell skill tree. Doing this, however, resets a multiplier which grants you more experience for every kill you clock up without using the checkpoint. For those of you that are more adventurous, this risk vs. reward mechanic can drastically alter how you play the game and opens up many different types of challenges. It's a great feature that is immensely fun to play around with.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=384978909
Lords of the Fallen also features a selection of end-level nasties that will be needing removing. Killing each boss results in Harkyn claiming their souls for himself, gaining massive amounts of experience points to utilize for character or spell advancement in the process. None of the bosses are particularly challenging with most of them relying on big, sweeping attacks that are easily blocked or dodged depending on the weapon and armor set you have equipped. While the bosses in Lords of the Fallen are certainly fun to engage with, very few of them employ an arsenal of attacks that isn't telegraphed from a mile off giving you more than ample time to calculate how you will respond. Graphically, Lords of the Fallen looks stunning with complex volumetric lighting and shading being utilized provided you have the juice to power these options. Playing Lords of the Fallen with all the bells and whistles blaring is a gorgeous experience. While the areas crafted for you to explore look like they come straight out of Fantasy 101 they still manage to look stunning even when that feeling of having seen this all before sets in. Lords of the Fallen comes with the stock standard orchestral soundtrack that accompanies most fantasy based games and while it never quite stands out it does the job. I played Lords of the Fallen with a Xbox 360 controller and the layout seemed natural for this type of game. I can't speak for playing this solely with the keyboard and mouse as I did not explore that avenue preferring my trusty old controller over the mouse and keyboard any day.

All things said and done, as a first stab at replicating the magic that is the Souls series, Deck 13 have done a commendable job with Lords of the Fallen and I look forward to seeing where they take the franchise from here now that a sequel is in development. Lords of the Fallen ends up emerging as a competent action RPG that should satisfy most who play it. A little more ambition and distinct personality the next time around should see Deck 13 inch that little bit closer to From Software's crown.

If you enjoyed reading this review please follow my curator group at:-
Curator Rater

reviewText:
Game is underrated because of somer players experiencing crashes. Those negative experiences are greatly overshadowing the people who are in game enjoying themselves. To people who are experiencing crashing: I was one of those people. An AMD Catalyst update fixed the issue for me. I'm running HD Radeon 7xxx series in crossfire and Windows 8.1.

Please stop giving a negative review of the entire game because it's crashing for you. Every game release has issues. If the developers were ignoring our experience that would be one thing. But the developers are constantly replying in the discussions and releasing patches in order to solve the issue as best they can. It's too early to determine whether we've wasted our money. If you're still crashing then enjoy something else in life and check back later. You can't review a game you haven't played. Yes, you've spent your hard earned money. But. You. Have. Not. Played. The. Game. There's proof the developers are working and some people's crashes (mine included) have been resolved.

EDIT [03/03/2015]:

Interesting. I happened to check back at this review and saw all of the negative comments, which I can only assume are the same people having issues.

Should the product have been a better quality upon release? YES. But the reviews people left gave a horribly false impression that the developers were not responding AT ALL, which was FALSE.
This is where I had a problem and felt the need to write a positive review. My review offered what I thought was important to tell people that was lacking in other reviews (i.e., nothing explaining for the umpteenth time that it's a Dark Souls clone. Seriously, how many reviews do you need explaining that?). People were focused on negative experience of the game crashing; therefore, my review focused on the opposite side of that. My patience with the developers, WHO HAD RESPONDED to the crashes with attempted bugfixes, is not apologetic. I saw complaints. I saw responses attempting to address those complaints. That's progress in the right direction. And realistically, that's the best that can be done because magic doesn't exist. NO EXCUSE for a faulty product, but at the same time, leave a fair review noting that developers are responding.

TL;DR (for the lazy ones): You have a right to do what you want with your money. Leaving a negative review because a game doesn't meet your expectations (e.g. doesn't work) within a certain timeframe is COMPLETELY FAIR. Just make sure you say THAT in your negative review. It is UNFAIR for EVERYONE to a write negative review suggesting development just isn't responding to problems. This is what my original review was targetting: the people writing negative reviews because they were crashing and claiming development was unresponsive. Some of us have been on both sides and would take a responsive development team fixing a faulty product over a decent product but unresponsive development team any day. I hope everyone is now in a position to enjoy the game. I won't be reading any further comments.

reviewText:
UPDATE:

After approximately 10 hours of play, I have to say that Lords is surprisingly well put together, fun to play, and perhaps most importantly (at least it was for me), LOTF FEELS like Dark Souls!

-Blocking, movement, rolling, armor weight plays a role in your roll... Familiar and comfortable - which is good, because LOTF's combat is (dare I say it) deeper than DS!
-The classes dictate your gameplay - the rogue is VERY different from the warrior, who is also very different from the mage.
-Ph4t l3wtz r ph4t. A great RPG inventory, which leads me to...
-Stats page!

I don't want to spoil the game or the story for anyone, but everything here is a lot of fun. I've got 3 of the big bosses down and the game is still mysterious but scattered with lore" drops that unlock more of the story.

There have been a couple of side quests
date: and a Dark Souls-eque decision I had to make regarding an NPC (help him or harm him). I look forward to NG+
recommended:
which I haven't said about a game in a long time.

8.5/10

Buy it for sure
