reviewText:
Length of Game: 10 Hours

Optimization: Awful, worst port I've ever played,

Difficulty: Difficult at first, far too easy 3 hours in.

Design Choices; Bad

Don't buy this game.  Don't support the developers and don't think twice about it.  To detail why I don't think this is a good puchase, I'll start with the enemy variation.  This game does a good job initially at giving a wide variety of enemies to fight.  They all have unique ways to kill them and they stick out pretty well.  A few hours in, you will not only be fighting these same monsters, but you will get a few more that are anti-fun to deal with.  It's not that they're difficult, it's that you either have to wait forever for an opening or they have mechanics to bore you to death.

Allow me to explain, using 2 enemies as examples.  There are very large soldier looking characters with a big shield that will block all your attacks.  You can't kick their shield out of their hand so you're left with two options.  Wait 14 years for them to lowe the shield to attack them or sprint at them and bash them with a tower shield.  Once you do option 2, you realize EVERY enemy is weak to that.  How very exciting, eh?  Second horrible mention is the mages that not only explode when they die, but pretty much have a kill move if you attack them during a certain period where they put white sparkles around them.  They do a TON of damage as well, which isn't necessarly horrible, but it's very cheap when you're beginning the game and when you kill them, they explode and kill you, forciing you to keep doing it until you figure it out it.  And while this wears its novelty off fast, you will encounter these things when you have plenty of health and they don't hurt you, but they still knock you down every time they explode, making it increasingly annoying.

Let's move to bosses.  4 of them will most likely be somewhat difficult for you, probably.  I killed them in one go, and those first four bosses is the hardest this game will ever be.  The rest of them you either have too much equipment, or they just don't have interesting enough mechanics to worry about avoiding.  It becomes a mess, where your character is so Godly unstoppable that you juts completely wreck everything on screen.  It might be fun for some people, but given the way the combat system works in this game...it feels very cheap and hollow.  The reason for this is, you have a stamina bar, so you're not just going to wrack up tons of kills altogether, you STILL have to wait constantly for that to recharge, but without any challenge or thought as you progress in the game.  Rather than having to deal with difficult situations or enemies, you're dealing with boring enemies that you meet in the first 3 hours of the game, and bosses that die in a few hits.  It's very flat and not fun.

Graphics are great, they look nice and have an art style that anyone who plays World of Warcraft would most likely enjoy.  They are not, however, optimized, and you will crash more than a blind person in a food store.  You will find enemies later will explode, which is a boring as ♥♥♥♥ mechanic by itself, but will often cause the game to crash to desktop.  This happens REGULARLY on the most annoying ♥♥♥♥ing stage in the game.  There's a maze like area later in the game in which you have to pull 3 switches and these fire dogs are EVERYWHERE in it, and ONE of them will crash your game.  This is ridiculous beyond belief, there's not way this should have gotten through Quality Assurance.

While the game has just released for almost a week now, the developers are trying to show care and fix their game up, but I feel the damage has been done and hurts their credibility.  If they cared to fix the game up, there's no way they should have had so many game breaking bugs, bad balancing and generally boring gameplay.  If you're looking to scratch that Dark Souls itch, I highly recommend playing Dark Souls 2 on NG+. as they add completely new monsters to areas, and add more boss mechanics.  Or whatever your favorite game is, don't let me tell ya how to think.

Thanks for reading!

reviewText: Genre - Dark Fantasy Action RPG\nSo this game is like Dark Souls, not as good, but in the same league. Dark Souls fastly became one of my favourite game series after a bit of trial and error. This game follows a similar format, fight monsters in third person with melee and a few spells (no ranged in this one I'm afraid). The combat flows quite well, although it could be a bit more accurate on registering a hit sometimes. The mobs are quite varied and will need different tactics to defeat. The same can be said of the bigger bosses. You also might need to grind a bit (not too much so far though) to beat some enemies, but this doesn't feel like a chore. You grab armour and weapons and can customise them with different level gems. The story is standard fayre but it seems to keep the game flowing. You only get the one male character model to use but with three different classes, sorry girls and girl wannabes. I have basically used this game after finishing Dark Souls 2 to give me a break before I jump into the next New Game +, and this game does the job nicely.

reviewText:
This is a mere first look review, as a dad and a gamer my time is very limited (sad face).  However I put a good almost solid 7hrs or so in it so I can at least give you all an idea of what to expect and how it plays.

First of all, do I recommend this game?  Sometimes this can be a tough question, however Lords of the Fallen is very well built fundamently enough to give an absolute yes.  If you love the Souls series you will get a more refined experience of risk and reward.  Is is better than Souls?  I feel the two have their own place and one does not outshine the other.  However Lords of the Fallen has a loot based gameplay which does drive you to go onward to see what else you can find and being able to switch gear and adapt to what you want to play as for that specific boss or sceniro is greatly appreciated.  I'll break down things in categories to give a better understanding of things.

The Story
Run of the mill and not very interesting in the least.  The characters you meet you will not give two ♥♥♥♥♥ about as they don't even seem to have a personality.  They are nothing more than virtual mannikins.  However the lore (audio logs you can find around the world) and atomsphere is something to behold.

The Combat
This is where I feel the game shines.  The combat is very fun and engaging, there is no animation waitout so if you are mid-swing and need to dodge you can do just that.  You can react to your situations with near instant input reaction.  You can also play to your style and not be punished for it, sometimes on the Souls series there were bosses and encounters that pretty much required a shield build to stay alive (or praise the sun for some god damn luck), this game allows you to play to your strengths with the build you want.  You have stamina which will affect the amount of swings you can do before you have to take a breather, which adds some strategy in the way you will be attacking your enemy.  You have mana which allows you to use your abilities and guantlet to shoot enemies from afar.

The Bosses (Lords)
The absolute best part of this game is the boss fights.  Not only are they scripted to do different things for each phase but the complete strategy you had planned out will change drastically.  This gets more and more apparent as you progress throughout the game.  You will feel as you are fighing epic bosses and feel accomplished after defeating them, much like the Souls series you will die and die alot.  Each boss plays on the area that they are in, what I mean by this is they sort of interact with their surroundings and you need to use it to your advantage.

The Loot/Equipment
There is chests to find and loot off of enemies and Lords.  There is legendary versions of items as well which normally has to do with defeating a Lord with a certain condition or challenge.  The loot seems to be varied and happens enough to where you want to keep going into your inventory screen and seeing if what you got is better.  The equipment comes in 3 classes (light, medium, heavy) and has a weight value which will help you determine if it is right for your build or not.  Obviously if you want to be a rogue you would want light armor to help you roll and dodge with no restrictions.  However you can mix between light and medium to find a perfect middle ground, much like how you would avoid fat rolling" in Souls.

The "Level Up"
So the unique thing about this game is that there is a risk vs reward
date: one that capatilizes on what the Souls series did but takes it one step furthur and makes it attractive to hold on to your xp.  The system is designed where you accumulate xp by defeating enemies
hoursPlayed: if you die you lose your soul and you have to go back and get it to get your xp back much like Souls.  However the cool thing here is
voteText: the more xp you carry with you the better the loot drops and the better the xp bonus.  For once a system that rewards the risk.  If you care not for the risk
helpfulPercent:
you can bank your xp at a crystal in which you can transfer it to spell points for your abilities or stat points which allows you to ramp up your base stats.  This system is by far what makes this game interesting and questions "Is it worth trying to beat this boss with my 10k xp?"

The Controls
I feel these are refined and really excellently laid out.  There are toggle keys to switch your weapon types
votesHelpful: spells
votesTotal: and consumables on the fly.  This is the first game in a long time where I felt the keyboard setup was actually more usable than a controller.  That is normally a huge flaw when it comes to action games
votesFunny: this however just works and works well.  After trying a boss with the controller just to see if it was an easier experience
commentsCount: I quickly switched back to the keyboard.  I'm a keyboard and mouse guy
column16: with Souls I had to use the controller since the input lag was horrid
column17: but with this game I am happy to say
column18:
awesome keyboard and mouse controls.

The Graphics
Very well made textures and models.  It is a very beautiful looking game.  There is interesting set pieces and things out in the distance to catch your eye.  The snow falling
column19: the wind blowing
column20: all great stuff.  However the game does seem to randomly slowdown in certain areas for little to no reason other than unoptimize graphical elements.  The snow falling and looking in certain directions can cause your frames to drop quite a bit.  Hopefully they fix this soon
column21:
a smoother experience is always a plus.

Overall
Lords of the Fallen is a satisfying experience overall and I highly recommend it to any Souls fan.  It has its kinks and issues

It is a rare occurance was only able to do it once.  Have fun killing the Lords!"

reviewText: Short version: I recommend this game, it is fun but don't constantly compare it to Dark Souls instead keep your mind open.\n\nLong Version: Pretty good, I find it more difficult than dark souls as timing is even more important due to the speed at which most weapons are swung.  This may be a con for some people but I do not mind it as it is much more realistic.  Also unlike dark souls where you can dual weild greathammers larger than your character this game has much more realistic human abilities.  Some of the very large weapons must be two handed to even use (I like this, some may not).  Also just an fyi, armour is much more important in this as opposed to Dark Souls.  I was finding the game borderline impossible because I was barely armoured and getting 1-2 shotted by most everything.  Once I started wearing some heavier gear though it became much more possible.  As of right now (2 days after launch) the game has major crashing issues and I am upset that this is taking so long to patch as this should be a day one patch.

reviewText:
EDIT 2:  End-game, some bugs
EDITED: Read bottom for help against stutter and potential decrease in crashes!

After an hour of gameplay there ain't much to say. But the game is awesome so far, controls are a bit different than Dark Souls but there actually is alternative controls which makes it EXACTLTY the same. The game itself is amazing, love the graphics and the combat is brutal and realistic, get caught in a combo and you're dead. Much like souls, exp drop on death and is reclaimable, but there's some other things too that is different and maybe a bit more... Creative?

For souls fans, I really would recommend. There's no customization (sadly) other than new armor/weapons (looks amazing though).

Edit 2: End-game, some bugs

Alright, so I have reached the end of the game and I'd like to share my complete opinion.

The game is still really good, I freakin love the various, enemies, bosses, armors and weapons throughout the game. Having said that, there's still some bugs and the game is... Resource heavy. My rig (GTX 780, 16GB RAM, i7-4790K CPU @ 4.00GHz) crashes after a while of playing and I get a message about my graphics card crashing, probably overheating. I'm no expert, but I'd say the game needs some tweaking, because there's obviously something wrong.

Some bugs I've discovered: http://fextralife.com/forums/p686398/bug-report-various-bugs-big-or-small/#p686398

Edit: Stutter and potential decrease in crashes!

Got some more time in now, the game is really good and the bosses, storyline, creatures and equipment are really interesting. The only problem that seems to bother people are lots of crashing and I experience them too. Hopefully this will be fixed ASAP as announced by the developers.

Things that might decrease the crashes and stuttering:

-Turn off Nvidia Turbulence and/or Vsync in the Advanced Display Settings in-game (Announced by dev, might help).

-Optimize the game with Gforce Experience!

- Might help to configure the PhysX settings in the Nvidia control panel: Changing processor from auto to CPU helped for some (in my case it got worse, I use my GTX 780)

reviewText:
Hello all, first off, i haven't played dark soul so this review will be for the standalone game and no comparison between it and DS.

The game remind me a bit of bound by flame, or even darksiders 2. The sad thing about is that most of the game, the stamina bar only feel like it is there to slow the action down. I can understand the wish for realism, but getting winded in 3 swings to instantly recover 2 seconds later.., i am not a fan of the mechanic as a whole. The game rpg roots are solid, using xp for ability and spells investments rather than actual level up (each investment count as a level up and require more to increase as you do it). Along with that you have a gamble mechanic where you can lose XP. Being defeated drop a xp ghost that you have to gather back or recover using items, otherwise the xp is lost. The more enemy you kill in a row without stopping increase the reward gained which is enticing, as some players may want to challenge themselves and end up with 40 levels worth of upgrades sooner than expected.  The bosses tend to be challenging and require patience or varied approach as your game play style can greatly vary depending if you're the heavy armor self healing type or the nimble rogue-style stabber.
The game visually remind me of dark fantasy settings and is passable. At launch the game had a few stability issues, but they have since been fixed, for me at least. most of the few bugs i have seen weren't game breaking.

The rest of the game is a rpg experience that focus on action and combat rather than storytelling, which may be something some players are looking for these days. It is not my best rpg of the year but, with the replayability, i am still glad i bought it.

Have a nice day all!

-Lost

reviewText:
Interesting combat, beautiful locations and character designs, although buggy and a poor story.

I really enjoyed Lords of the Fallen. I've never played Dark Souls, although I have heard there are many similarities to those games, so if you've played those I suspect you know what you're in for. Fans of the Dark Souls games have criticised Lords of the Fallen for being too easy. This could be true, I certainly didn't struggle for any amount of time on any boss fights, although there is a level of challenge to learning how to fight effectively and to levelling your character up. Plentiful health potions and several of your spells can make the process feel easier than it may have been without them, and the dodging system is generally fairly generous in what counts as a hit or a dodge.

The story is fairly standard fare, with no surprises and some terrible dialogue. It hits a few tired cliches along the way too, such as 'man is the real monster' and characters that are clearly going to betray you 'shockingly' betray you at the opportune moments. Having said that, the story worked enough that I wanted to continue playing and see it through to the end. The environments are beautiful, and a real draw. Set in a mountain monastary, I enjoyed unlocking the various areas and whilst there's a lot of back-tracking, it didn't take too long to reach anywhere else, with some areas feeling like hubs that you can branch off from. I've heard complaints of the areas not being distinct enough, I'm not sure I agree personally; there's some real variety, and the alternate 'rhogar' world you visit is quite striking, I feel there's enough variety without feeling like the game goes through a cartoony 'theme' for each zone.

The game is relatively short (I completed it in about 15 hours), although it offers New Game + and New Game ++ modes for those looking for more, apparently offering a little more story and new treasures to discover. The game does have quite a few bugs, notably the game crashed completely on me three times in my 15 hours. Some enemies would bug out and stop moving, and I died for no apparrent reason a couple of times too. All that aside, I still really enjoyed the game, and if you're looking for something fun and not too shallow but not too deep, I'd recommend giving this a try.

reviewText:
To preface this review, I beat lords of the fallen in 7.5 hours. on my first and only character.
As a massive fan of dark and demon souls(well over 200 hours combined) I was very excited to bite my teeth into something even resembling dark souls. the beginning of the game is a blast, difficulty is on the low end and you are just murdering everything. first 2 bosses are a joke and took very little thinking to kill. about 1/3 way into the game, for no apparent reason their is a difficulty spike. the same brain dead enemies you were killing now have 4X health and damage. this ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off more than anything some enemies are much more stronger count parts of them self. yet the game doesn't give you a visual queue or even a different enemy model / weapons to show this difference. you will go into a room with 1 strong and 1 weak version of the same enemy, this can offset your play style and often can result poorly from you thinking 1 of the enemies is a weak version instead of a strong version. once you are past the difficulty spike which isn't terrible it just really came out of no where, its a complete breeze again.

HEAVY ARMOR RULES EVERYTHING
all I used was heavy armor in this game while 2 handing my weapon. beat the game using the codex.
3 enemies coming at you? who cars just face tank right through them and you'll win.
about the 5th or 6th boss? is the one with 3 legs and my god that boss was a joke. I literally just stood in front of it casting rage and destroyed the boss only drinking a single healing potion. it had mechanics I could see but why play around mechanics when you can just face tank something and win?

RAGE IS OP
warrior spell rage allows you to use your weapon with 0 energy cost, holy ♥♥♥♥ is that powerful and super OP
if you're in heavy armor have a relatively heavy weapon and use RAGE you will kill anything
shield bros? no problem use rage break their guard and kill with your infinite stun lock you have on them
bosses? no problem slap on rage and get an easy 1,500 damage at the cost of taking a few hits
you literally don't need to worry about enemies as long as you keep up a constant assault on them, since heavy weapons often do mini stuns you can combo and enemy or boss to death by just using combos with infinite energy.

BOSSES
bosses are for the most part a joke in this game.
the only boss that I died to was the one where you travel dimensions and you have the option of fighting him in the open area and he uses 2 swords. forgot his name, but thankfully you had to do a little bit of thinking to kill him and it took me 2 tries to kill him
every other boss I downed in the first try

Now this all may seem like a lot of negatives, or positives if dark souls was to hard for you. But, somehow I had a reasonable amount of fun playing this game. graphics are superb if running on max settings. (ignoring the frame rate issues, crashes etc.) it was a decent hack and slash game. I enjoyed breezing through all of the late game content face taking and murdering everything. difficulty wise the game is not there but its a good amount of fun to load up and kill some stuff in. I plan on beating it on NG+ and NG++, to see if there are any interesting armors/weapons. lords of the fallen is the toddler version of dark souls, yet I still managed to have a good bit of fun being a dark souls vet.
is it worth the 50 dollars? - probably not but I plan on speed running this game seeing how broken I can make it
is it fun? - despite its issues and shortcoming I had a good deal of fun with the game
recommend? - can't beat dark souls - start with this.
dark souls vet? - pick it up and see how fast you can wreck everything in the game
it's a good bit of fun, id advise everyone just to try it out.

reviewText:
Lords Of The Fallen Review
I personally really like this title. Now, before I dive deep into this review I just want to clarify a few things.

I had originally played this around November of 2014 on Xbox One. I think it ran at about 15 - 30 FPS. So I didn't see it worth it on Console.
I never made it past the second boss a.k.a Commander" while playing this on console because there was no difficulty option.
I have waited until 2016 to pick it up because I bought a GTX 970 paired with my AMD FX-6300 so I can play it on PC.
I haven't completed the game
date:
because I am taking my time with it and exploring everywhere I can.
Pros:
Beautiful graphics.
Good level designs.
Sounds! The sounds are amazing in the game. From the footsteps of your plated boots hitting the ground to opening a demon chest and hearing it "roar" until completely opened.
Options menu. I would have liked to see more
recommended:
but what they have now is fine
The "Feel" of the game. I love how heavy you can feel when wearing heavy armor and how light and agile you are when wearing cloth "rouge" armor.
Weapons. There are plenty of weapons to choose from and having certain runes slotted into them makes the weapons more deadly!
Looting. Oh man
hoursPlayed: looting in this game is so much fun! From looting armor
voteText: weapons and runes I can't get enough!\nMixed:\nCombat. While the combat is somewhat balanced

reviewText:
Game isn't perfect, but it received a patch (that cleared most/all issues i had) within 24 hours of release. some might argue that it should have released like that... smarter people might realize the sheer scope of different hardware, etc. and how most other developers don't respond that quickly.

On to the game itself. the difficulty is that of Dark Souls (duh) but not in a bad way. each enemy is different, requires different movement/weapon choices. the character voice animations are pretty bad, but the textures are beautiful, and the combat feels fluid and dynamic. story seems interesting, albeit short and to the point in delivery.

Would give 8/10 and shall recommend. (if you liked souls, then try this. it is a lot of fun, and refreshing to see a positive take on said gametype)

reviewText:
If not for near release day crashes, performance issues and negativity for copying Dark Souls.  It's a pretty decent game. (Patch 1.2 improved the game greatly, just completed first playthrough.  Highly recommended as of now)
Supposedly the companies first big budget title (can't confirm or deny).  I for one, welcome our new western dark souls overlord.

Pros:
-Plays like a slower version of Dark Souls (Combat wise) (Huge perk imo)
-Neat moveset variety (Per weapon, One handed, two-handed/duel wielded and a magical gauntlet)
-Everything feels like they have weight to it (Heavier weapons will feel heavy, large shields will be near impenetratable)
-Amazing graphics and breathe-taking views.
-Replayability due to different playstyles, magic selection and NG+ (up to 3 times)
-Decent upgrade system via runes (Discovered some weapons can change if you use the proper runes on them)
-Lore is available if you want to look for it
-Very fluid combat (Any attack into any attack)
-High risk, high reward style of play is rewarded (Obviously, by name itself)
-Intense moments where it's either kill or be killed
-You can spec heavily into your playstyle (be it heavy weapons, a flurry of lighter blows, turtling
-Enemies all have a niche, although sometimes shared (Immortality until you obtain their heart, two lives, tanky/high threat)
-60FPS/1080P or potentially beyond ( I can now run max settings with almost no fps problems )
-Most cons can be easily fixed with a patch (They have just done so)


Cons:
-Randomly crashes, one known to me with the fire-fiend explosive enemy(ies) (FIXED)
-Major performance issues outdoors (FIXED / IMPROVED GREATLY)
-Upgrade system is small and could be expanded upon (four choices with different rarity/power)
-Once you know an enemies' weakness you can easily exploit it for a quick win
-Heavy armor is easy mode and basically required unless you drag a fight out (Rephrase- more forgiving than relying on dodges alone which can be difficult)
-Sidequests can be cut off by progressing too far into the main story
-Most of the lore is hidden within discriptions and items you randomly pick up and not get a prompt to delve into.
-You can't tell if you're going the wrong way until an enemy wrecks your ♥♥♥♥
-Reused areas and replaced mobs when you defeat a lord (Game always has you returning to places you've been (zzz same environment)
-Borrows heavily from Dark Souls (Combat, some boss moves (I.E. Worshipper's ground spike move reminds me of Gravelord Nito's blade dance/scream)
-DON'T LOOK AT THE BLOODY SUN, OH GOD MY EYES, LENSFLARE EFFECTS
-Blotchy snow sticking to camera" effect
date: bland hexgon like shapes.\n\nProtip: This is an opinion
recommended: please don't argue it.\n\nEdit: As of a couple hours ago patch 1.2 rolled out
hoursPlayed: I can now highly recommend this game as the crashes I have encountered have been fixed and outdoor FPS and other performance issues are a lot better.  A week from release and they fixed their game pretty damn well."

It's unstable and crashes all the time. I'll update this to positive and write about the good aspects of this game if it ever gets fixed. At the moment it's defective and shouldn't even be for sale without a warning that explains as much.

Edit: to add more details for those wondering;

I have left my PC running at times as I do other things, I've probably played under 10 hours. I'm not saying this is a bad game or not worth looking into, especially if you love the souls games as I do. What I'm saying is buying this game now may severely reduce the potential enjoyment you can get out of it. I've lost progress from crashes, I've had crashes halfway through boss fights 3-4 times in a row, I've had to save my game reducing the XP multiplier out of fear of losing progress because of crashing, I've had to reduce graphical settings in the hope of reducing crashing despite spending thousands on a beast PC which can run this game with max settings. That's why it deserves a negative review. I bet a lot of people put a lot of effort in to making this game and I bet one or two a**holes forced the release before it was ready for reasons that are anti-consumer. I estimate I've played 10 hours and crashed 25 times. My PC is fast, extremely stable, runs cool, is up to date with no beta drivers.

Play this game.

If and when they fix it.

reviewText:
At the time of writing this review I have still not played very far into the game, but I feel like I need to add a positive review among all the negative ones.

First, I have played both Dark Souls and Dark Souls II, and I enjoyed them a lot. The second game wasn't the same blast as the first game, and that's why Lords of the Fallen has felt like a very refreshing change for me.

The game is beautiful and modern in a way the Dark Souls games aren't, if you care for that kind of thing. The combat is in many ways very similar, but still has it's own feel with weapons, animations, movement and so on.

So far I have beaten three bosses, and I got to say the game feels very cinematic in a way the Souls games aren't. The battles are dramatic and hard, and while I beat almost every boss in Dark Souls II on the first try, it felt good to get my ♥♥♥ kicked for once. The same thing as in Dark Souls apply though, that when you learn how the game works and the pattern of the enemies it becomes a lot easier.

I have had a few crashes, and the game could be better optimized but I haven't had any big issues that most people have. Then again I have a GTX 980 and i7 4790K, so keep that in mind.

I will probably update this review later, but I personally really enjoy this game so far and encourage you to watch some streams on twitch and make up your own mind. I can't understand why there are so many negative reviews, really.

If you like hard games with a fantasy setting this is for you.

reviewText: If you like dark souls then you will probably like this game.  There are several problems with it though.  First off there are definetely performance issue which I suscpect are present because this game was written mostly as a console game which both consoles use radeon, and I use a nvidia card.  Also in regards to the gameplay I have found it to be much slower combat than dark souls.  In dark souls I often found myself going without a shield, carrying a big damage weapon and rolling to avoid most damage.  I do not really find that strategy to be all that effective in this as the enemies have more health and also seem to hide behide shields.  This isn't nessesarily a bad thing, I view it as kind of the opposite direction of where bloodbourne is headed as they are going for a more offensive playstyle.  The weapons in this game I think really need balancing.  The weapons you expect to deal high damage (clubs, greatswords, ext.) do far less damage than the staff weapon which attack much faster and consume less stamina.  Maybe I am missing a gameplay mechanic here but I really think axes and the like should do more damage than staves.  Something that I think is a huge streagth for the game is the magic.  The spell are so different from the ones in dark souls and it is something new.  I hope this is the first in a number of games that follow this dark souls like formula, a genre of fantasy rpgs with combat that doesnt suck.

reviewText: Not sure what graphics engine they used, but this game was pretty.  I really enjoyed my play though with this game.  Some frustration with slow attack animations, but nothing game breaking.  I had read sites saying that this game considered easy mode Dark Souls, and I would have to agree.  Although it was still challenging at times, I did find as you got new gear the difficulty went way down.\n\nLike most games, you will get a feel for a certain way of attacking, certain combos, and spells to use.  Once you master your technique this game is not very challenging but still wickedly fun.  This title may not have the depth, challenge, and longevity of the souls games, but for someone looking for a moderately challenging and beautiful ARPG this is a worthy pickup.  I would suggest anyone who is not familiar with action RPG titles play this one before attempting Dark Souls to understand some of the battle mechanics and frustrations that come with ARPG games.  Most definitely recommended.

reviewText:
BEWARE: The game is currently optimized pretty poorly and has a lot of technical issues for some people. Be sure to check the forums to see if they have been fixed!

Lords of the Fallen is a western take on Souls franchise. It borrows a lot of things from Souls and tries to explore the possible developments of the genre with a couple of new features.
The game immediately feels like Souls game, yet there are enough differences to justify its existence.
The biggest thing about LotF is that if you are looking for the complexity and difficulty of Souls - you won't find it here.
This game is much simpler and easier.
But if you always wanted to play more of that fantastic Souls combat without suffering horrible through each encounter - this game is for you.
Combat is extremely close to Souls and quite enjoyable to play.
Well, may be aside from ranged combat and magic spells that are pretty basic in comparison to Souls games.
The world is as well much smaller than those offered in Souls. And since game is quite simpler, you can beat it in ~20h or so. Which in my book is pretty much good for a $60 game.

The game does have some issues with balance: spells are overpowered, there's no way to use spell points once you'd level all your spells up to max, UI could be a bit better, world could've been a bit bigger, targeting autounlocks from time to time which is annoying.
But most of those are pretty minor and don't stop you from enjoying a good combat, fantastically looking world and cheesy storyline.

More detailed look and gameplay in the video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jOY8dwpJSjk

reviewText:
I hereby crown this October 2014, Broketober, because the must-buy releases just keep coming (Alien Isolation, The Evil Within (if you can run it), Wasteland 2 (I know, that was September) and now this beauty!

**After 5hrs+:
Still continues to deliver, a bit of long loading at times during travel transitions (40-60secs) occasionally and sometimes the locking system (like other games of its type) will get you killed but the game continues to be interesting, challenging and rewarding as these games should be. Go with a 8-8.5 out of 10 thus far.

**Early days but I like to give a first impressions when I hit the 2hr+ mark and will update as I go along:
Great game for me so far. It is without doubt heavily inspired by 'that' game series (you know which one) right down to the control system with only the primary buttons differing slightly (and you can actually pause the game).

Everything controls really nice, the combat animation is smooth and varied (you seem to be able to use different weapon types earlier the DS), the risk / reward system of the xp drop is interesting as you have the risk of losing it all but keeping it going while killing nasties means more xp faster via a multiplier and better loot drops (I think I was at 1.40x when I first hit the outside and got a 27 damage butcher knife (most start stuff was 16 I believe and DLC stuff 19-26) which was a pretty damn sweet payoff, I think that's how / why I got it, I could be wrong though).

Difficulty (using the rogue with 2nd / green tier magic option) is nicely balanced thus far for me (with the first boss taking me 4 attempts due to my 'one more hit' greed) but the game does a great job at giving you the base game dynamics info in-game rather than leaving you to have to potentially go online or work it all out cryptically.

So, so far, so great.

**Technical issues / notes:
-Playing on everything maxed except textures with is on 2nd highest (high as opposed to very high). I had about 40mins fluffing around with settings because the options menu contains no info on settings so it's pure trial and error for the most part.

-Anisotropic filtering seems to stay on 4x when I change the setup to custom. I also had one crash but haven't had any issue since (did set the game exe to Admin rights just in case so that may have cured it).

-I'm assuming setting Texture setting to Very High requires graphics card ram of 3GB or more since it goes really, really slow in places with it 'on' on my 2GB NVidia gt750 ti.

-Camera can be a bit whiley-fox / hyper sensitive at times but not a major issue, just worth mentioning

-Also it seems a lot of the negative reviews for this game are stemming from technical issues so I will update if I experience anything game breaking / stopping and give my full spec as to help those that are unsure their system will be ok with it or are having trouble:

GeForce GTX 750 Ti 2GB, 8GB Ram, AMD FX 4100 Quad-Core 3.6 GHz, Windows 7 (64Bit) @ 1920x1080p

reviewText:
I am a fan of the Souls series, and when the gameplay trailer for this game came out, I was excited.
A similar type of game but with way better graphics.
Gameplay is smooth and fun. Combat feels very realistic as I can feel every swing of the sword or my characters hammer.

Boss fights have been fun and a bit challenging so far. But when it comes to difficutly, Lords of The Fallen is nowhere near the punishing difficulties in the Souls series.

The games exp and loot system is interesting. More like a gamble... If you decide to collect your exp without spending them on any attributes or spells, your exp multiplier increases. Thus increasing  your loot quality and luck.

So it is up to the player to decide.

I would give it a 4 out of 5.

RPG and action game lovers would definitinely enjoy this game. So too for Souls fans.

reviewText:
I'ts Hard to do a proper review on this game.

First of, this game doesn't have any major flaw on tha game itself.

Gameplay is great overall and the story match the game pace quite well. (not anything spectacular, but worth a generic A-RPG)

Mostly of the issues of this game are related to game optimization.
I had my own crashes and issues back when I played. But I've played the game normal.
At the same time I know people that had to literally re install their windows to remove it from the computer (shenanigans).


I recommend this game for:
- Fans of Dark Souls that are looking for the same gameplay experience.
- People looking for a less flashy eye candy A-RPG with more serious-looking PvE

I do not recommend this game for:
- Players chasing the same difficulty levels as DkS. This game is far from being hard. Something around medium difficulty depending on your build choices. Still it's the hardest ARPG released at Q3-Q4 of 2014.
- A story worth of Square in the 90's. Seriously guys, stop chasing ghosts of the past.



Some Tips for starters:
- The gameplay is NOT sluggish. Every weapon has at least one attack thatss faster than the moveset that works as a opener. Make sure to study the whole moveset of your weapon instead of just spamming R1 like DKS.
- Heavy Armor = easier game. Playing on Light armor may surprise even experience gamers. It's your choice.



So far, assuming that the game loads on your computer without any let downs, I don't see how you wouldn't like this game.

reviewText:
Just finished a playthrough and started new game + on my cleric. The game fairly long, standing at 15 hours with almost everything explored. As many have said, it connects dark souls-combat (albeit heavier) to a diabloish universe. The monster and item design was cool, and the numerous hidden secrets make for an interesting experience.  Many of the boss fights were lovely, although the damage I inflicted upon them felt neglible and the overall length of the fight was very long, boss kills ranging from 3-10 minutes. However, seeing that the game itself focuses even more on windows of opportunity and the rare occasions of being able to load a combo (which many weapons have, interesting mix-ups of light and heavy attacks) on an enemy. The level design is also solid, feeling threatening, seeing closed portculli and doors right and left, only for you to find that it was a shortcut to the section or activated by a pressure plate. The entire scenario is very much a mix-up of the Painted World of Ariamis and the third act of Diablo 3.
I will be honest in my opinion that there was room for improvement at times, regarding the story, characters, overall itemization  and ranged combat. Most of the times when I hit a brick wall in terms of multiple monsters or a strong individual one, I resorted to spam projectiles with my gauntlet (which uses mana as a resource and allows you to deal dmg from afar, and through a shield in most cases) killing them as easily as a ranged fighter in Souls games in general.
The game left me asking for more, even though the ending itself was quite weird and basically left a chance for a season pass to come, and there still are several things I want to see regarding hidden gems like alternate boss kill challenges and what happens if I choose otherwise at sidequests.
The game was very stable on me, and I only experienced minor lag during a session of multiple hours, although the loading screens and transitions were quite long.  I will be on lookout for the announced puzzle-oriented Library DLC, and wish the best for those who have poor experiences with the game regarding performance issues.
Overall, I rate graphics(played on high with a stable 30-40 fps) 9/10
Story and characters 6,5/10
Gameplay 8/10
Souls feels 8/10 would bang
bringing the total score to 8/10

reviewText:
Very Early Review, only a few hours in so far with the first 'Boss' down, and I have to say I'm loving it so far. As a huge fan of the Soul Series and From Software ingeneral, I feel this game is going to fill 'Dark Souls void' until Bloodbourne comes out.

The game engine is very smooth, attack animations are very fluid and the sounds to go with are amazing and very immersive. If you're a fan of Dark Souls  PVE   than you will not regret this buy! Will post more as I play through.

Playing through abit more one of my complaints would have to be the camera control or positioning at times, it can feel kind of buggy at times and lead to a few irritable deaths. You'll also notice how heavy of an influence the weight of your armour makes on the speed of your dodges, again like in dark souls. But I feel you're more penalized for using heavy armor in this game, atleast early game.

Pros so far:
Immersive Enviroment
Destructable Enviroments
Soundtrack & Voice Acting
Fluid Gameplay Mechanics
Intense and long lasting Boss Fights with some awesome mechanics and attack animations
Gauntlets (A Shield/ Magical Projectile item)
Lots of lore filled items and audio logs
Optimized very well for PC, no crashes and consistant high frame rates
Replayability with new game+ and different classes
Attacks feel 'real' a 2handed power attack takes a decent ammount of time to follow through giving the attacks a very real feeling with a tactical approach

Cons so far:
No Character Customization
Camera controls/angles
Game pace is very slow
No mini map or quest markers which can lead to getting lost quite often
No Co-op
No multiplayer / PVP
3 Classes (Warrior/Cleric/Rogue)

My PC Specs and Settings:
Intel Core i3 3220 3.3ghz
16 GB RAM
GeForce GTX 750 Ti SC (Overclocked quite abit)
Running on High settings with x16 Anistropic Filtering

reviewText:
If you miss dark souls 1 style gameplay and want your dark souls 1 fix without going back, then this game is perfect for you.

Im going to make this review short as my last review was rather long

The gameplay is reminiscent of dark souls 1, you can't walk around in full heavy armor light rolling with a great shield and heavy weapon unless you fully invest into weight carrying. Enemies know how to get around shields and they know how to use shields, you have to learn their weaknesses. Boss design is well done, i'll admit after the first two bosses being guys with tower shields i was worried, but the bosses get better from that point on. One thing i personally liked about the bosses is that they each seem to excel versus certain types of characters while being weak to others. As a rogue i had issues that i saw knights just breeze past and vise versa.

Gameplay is heavier than dark souls 1 and it is fulfilling, armor designs are a little more stylized but in a good way. While the general enemies are not exemplary, they never felt out of place and they were spaced out logically, i was never swarmed by one enemy type.

Anyways this review feels incomplete but i said it would be short so all i have to say is this game is very much like dark souls 1 except with new story and visuals, gameplay is fun and i will probably be playing alot of it until bloodborne, if you like DS1 you will most likely enjoy this game, and if you want to get started into games like the souls series this game is a friendlier version for new players.

reviewText:
UPDATE: Yes, i know this game crashes alot and it even crashed for me but its still a good game! Just wait for the fix!

Lords of The Fallen is an ARPG with gorgeous graphics, superb sound design, and great music. As a lover of Demon Souls, Dark Souls and Dark Souls II, I can only recommend this game as its gameplay is the same as the Souls series only more fluid movements and animations. You can basically choose between 3 different play styles, though you are free to mix and match as you desire:

Heavy armor with slow powerful weapons
Medium armor with magic and mid-weight weapons
Light armor with fast weapons

Each has their own style of gameplay, with weapons that feel and play differently. Just like in the Souls series you have to earn experience (souls) from slaying monsters. You use them to level up your character and learn new spells. There are 4 for “class” chosen at the start, and you can unlock a second and third set on your second and third playthroughs respectively. If you die, you respawn at the last save point, dropping your experience. Just like souls, in order to retrieve it, you have to make it back to the point you died without dying. The longer it takes you, the less experience you recover, and once you’re there, you can choose to leave it on the ground temporarily in exchange for a few buffs that might help you defeat a difficult enemy. This game is as hard as the Souls series and Bosses even drop different bonus loot depending on how you killed them and what weapons you used, or didnt use during the fight.

It’s safe to say that this is just Dark Souls with a more linear level design, though not by much. The story is very clearly told, though it isn’t very compelling. But really in a game like this, who really cares?
voteText: 12 of 17 people (71%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A Dark Souls clone?

Thats definitely not it, its far from similar to DS in terms of atmosphere and the overall experience. Its just the mechanics that have been 'borrowed' from the souls games. After playing the game for ~2 hours i can tell you that its definitely a game worth giving a try, although dont expect a literal Dark Souls clone, its a game of its own.
The one thing i can praise the devs for is the combat system which feels waaaay better than the one in Dark Souls, im not really a fan of the armor and weapon design, if someone digs 100% fantasy design which would more than likely never work in real life then thats the game to look out for.
Onto the graphics, the game looks aesthetically pleasing with well designed locations and great attention to detail, the places ive been to actually feel like they have been abandoned just a few moments ago.

Positives:
+Satisfying combat
+Great atmosphere although could've been better
+Their XP system is a nice addition (the more you kill the more XP you get, untill you go back to a checkpoint which works like a bonfire, then the multiplier resets)
+Pleasing graphics
+Really well designed locations
+Soundtrack, although might sound a bit generic, works great.

Negatives:
-Overdesigned weapons and armor
-Interface could've been improved in many ways.
-Pretty linear
-Voice acting is rather poor
-So is lipsync and the gestures
-Inventory window looks all nice and dandy, but id prefer it being more useful than looking 'nice'.
-Not impressed by the boss fights so far
-Not really challenging, at least in the 4 hours of playtime i have.

Summary: If Dark Souls was a genre of its own, then this would be just another game in that genre, its not necessarily a clone but at least a 'heavily' inspired game, its trying to be a Souls game without being one, if that makes any sense.
Graphics: 9/10
Sound: 7/10
Gameplay: 8/10

If you can get it for less than 30€, give it a try.

reviewText: What can I say about Lords of the Fallen. It's a solid game for a Dark Souls clone or inspired game if you want to call it that way. It's obvious for anyone who played LotF that this game has a lot of similarities with Souls series. The similar combat style, the similar experience loss on death, health and stamina management is also here. But it doesn't mean the game is a blatant rip-off. The developers took some interesting ideas and mechanics from Souls series and created this game. But unfortunately taking something good doesn't mean the final product is going to be good. The story is here and they are trying to tell it to you but after all I'm stil not sure what happened during the game. Combat system is slow and in most situations forces you to play defensively. And to be honest it's way to easier to play with huge sword and tower shield than trying to roll and dodge. At least for me. The game is also pretty short. 11 hours to complete NG seems just not enough for a game like this. I know there are NG+ and NG++ but I don't see the reason to complete them unless you're aiming for achievements to unlock. I heard right after the release people had some technical issues and crashes with this game. But it seems the game works fine now after they patched it a couple of times. Well at least I didn't have any problem with it.\nAs the final verdict I'd say Lords of the Fallen doesn't worth the full price unfortunately but if you managed to get it during the sale you can have some fun with it. 7 out of 10.

I completed the game within 12-13 hours as a rogue and spent 6-7 hours messing around on other classes at the beginning of the game, so an average of 30 hours played which nowadays is pretty good for a £30 single player game. As someone new to this genre I was disappointed that there is no way to view/keep track of active missions/quests and I got turned around and confused on where I was meant to be going and doing.

The graphics for this game are amazing the voice acting on the other hand... could use work in places, the combat felt very well polished with a decent control layout and the NPCs behaviour felt really well done. The inventory menu is easy to use although something where I could store gear I am not using would have been nice instead of it always being in my inventory an having to scroll through like 20 different weapon to find the new set of daggers I got.

reviewText:
From what i have played so far the game is brilliant, the combat system is very much like Dark Souls. If you did not enjoy that kind of combat then do not buy the game. There are a few key features that i like about the game and a couple that i anoy me a little.

To start with the game has a brilliant combat system that has improved on the dark souls style. there are a few little things that just make it a bit more skill based and less luck/bruit force. there is a much better stagger effect that requires the player to time blocks on bigger enemies, this is not as hard as parrying and you have a much bigger window to do so. i feel that it just adds an extra mechanic to the game, your now thinking if its not worth trying to parry a super fast enemy at lwast i can try to stagger them.

Another aspect that seriously made the game for me and i love it to death is that you now have a gamble when you gain XP. basically, you kill a monster and get xp, at these shine things you can Bank the XP and save it up to level up so that when you die you don't lose it. HOWEVER if you keep the XP on you, you get a higher chance of better item drops. I love this mechanic in the game and it seriouly makes you think.

there is not much about the game that annoys me besides one thing that i think is worth mentioning. Tutorial. the game is quite heavy in the menues and can be a little confusing to start with. i feel that the game doesnt explain the menues well enough but this is nothing that time cant heal as you will learn as time goes on.

If you are using a game pad (you should be) navigating the menues can be a ♥♥♥♥♥, i dont know if this is just me but having one of those circle menues that you rotate the analouge stick to get around is very annoying when you want one of the diaginals AAAAAHHH, i waist so much time on it.

Other than the few very minor bad aspects of LOTF the game shines through brilliantly, graphics are amazing and the game runs so smooth for me, besides the loading screens but who cares.

There is one last thing but if no one else is having this problem it must be my computer. the game has crashed a few times for me and im recieving graphics error reports. im running a pretty good GPU so i need to do some reaserch to see if others are suffering.

8.7/10 Love this game, feels like a new take on Dark Souls combat that does not fail to impress

reviewText:
I'm not huge on Dark Souls, and I've heard that Lords of the Fallen is supposedly much easier and more forgiving than Dark Soul, so keep that in mind if you're a super veteran who can complete Dark Souls 2 without dying once. But for people like me, it's a decently challenging game where you'll die a few times here and there until you recognize the pattern and master the control, and beat your enemy down with a small portion of your own health remaining. Then you kick open some chests and find some more badass loot, you move on and get your teeth kicked in by the next big bad monster. It's satisfying all the way through.

The game looks great and sounds great, though the voice acting leaves much to be desired. The running, dodging and weapon wielding animations look fantastic, making you feel just how heavy each swing of your massive hammer is. There are some minor issues with some of the animations, and the game tends to have serious issues with cloth and armor pieces clipping through your shield and other parts of your armor. It's not a big deal gameplay-wise, but for a game that otherwise looks this good, it does put a dent in the overall presentation.

Overall, it's a fun game. And I think it's the perfect gateway game for people who want to get into challenging action RPGs, but are intimidated by Dark Souls' notorious difficulty. Lords of the Fallen isn't a perfect game, but it's quite a bit of fun and well worth the money.

reviewText:
Taken on it's own merits, LotF is great fun so far. I'm enjoying the combat system quite a bit, and the sound and animation do a great job of lending a visceral feeling to the game. Heavy weapons especially have a great sense of impact and power.
I enjoy the art direction quite a bit (armor and weapon models are particularly impressive). There's a good use of color and contrast, and the game is vibrant without being cartoony or sacrificing a gritty feel. Overall it's gorgeous and runs smoothly on my mid-level system. No crashes yet (running the newest nvidia drivers).

It's hard to avoid comparisons to Dark Souls. The mechanics are so similar. Personally I prefer the combat system here, as it feels more fluid. That being said, the game is a little less challenging and combat so far hasn't provoked that same rush of anxiety that I get when playing DS. I'm still having a great time with it, and I really enjoy the way they've tweaked some of the other systems like magic, leveling, and reincarnation.

Bottom Line: Fun combat, great weapons/armor, well done sound and art direction. If you can play it without wishing it were Dark Souls 3, you'll have a great time.

reviewText:
As one bad Dark Souls fiend, I was a little sceptical about this game at first and didn't expect much. As soon as I had watched the trailer, I thought, 'Well, alright, a game inspired by DS that seems decent, why not give it a try?'

I've purchased the game right away upon release. It was somewhat obscure in the beginning - but I believe one has to develop certain habits and earn some experience to start steadily progressing in a game like this. I've only had a couple of crashes - and pretty annoying they were - but with release of 1.1 they were gone as soon as I disabled the Nvidia Turbulence setting.

There is no multiplayer and there isn't that much content. But the existing content is gripping and full of secrets for the ones who love to explore. I've barely managed to stop playing the game to continue on the other day.

It's not Dark Souls, but it's great in its own way. I would give Lords of the Fallen a 8.5 out of 10.

reviewText:
I definitely enjoyed Lords of the Fallen.  It took just under 15 hours to complete on my first playthrough, having missed some sidequests.  If you've never played a game like this, it may be difficult and it may frustrate you.  Even if you have played a game like this it may frustrate you.
I got lost mulitple times, not sure where to go to progress, but always eventually found the way.  If you're a Dark Souls fan, you might be annoyed at some of the less polished enemy and boss patterns, but the game controls just like Dark Souls...only slower.  At least with a strength build.  Using daggers or staves make you attack very quickly.
The weapons feel heavy and satifying, making combat addictive and fun, once you get the hang of it.  Audiologs, weapons, runes, and armor are hidden throughout the world to find.  You can mix and match the armor and most of it is pretty awesome looking.
This game is not as fun as Dark Souls.  But it is a fun action RPG with enjoyable combat (most of the time) and high replayability.  There are faults, but I found it easy enough to push past them and have a great time.

reviewText:
First off, this is a good game. Everything is very well polished, it looks good, the story is decent enough, most of the combat is fair if not easy. There is a decent amount of mix and match with armor to stay at your desired weight level.

Unfortunately it is pretty short. I've got 14.3 hours on it and I have beaten it. My actual play time is only 12h59m because - and this is the worst part by far - crashing. It's ridiculous how often this game crashes. There is some optimization issues present when booting up and every once in a while when loading between worlds/zones there will be some framerate drops.

Lastly I just want to point out that this is not Dark Souls; it is much easier. As long as you do not go exploring areas that you are not ready for (Catacombs before closing the Portal) you will not experience any difficulty at all. I've heard and read that playing the rogue (as a rogue) makes the game a decent challenge but I feel that each class should present their own challenges which they do not.

Overall though I think it is a decent start for the studio and hopefully a long line of Dark Souls hopefulls. If you come in expecting a 10/10 Dark Souls clone you are going to be severely disappointed. If you come in with the mind set that this could be an enjoyable experience that takes many elements from a game the devs love then I think you'll be satisfied.

reviewText: The whole experience is kinda strange. The mechanics are pretty good mostly because they almost directly copied from Souls series, which is actually pretty nice for I like Souls series. However, things that were taken from other games or made by the developer are not polished and kinda look like the game demands bigger budget than it actually had. The animation is pretty bad, the plot is scarce to the point of nonexistence. And it is not like in Souls where there is a nice setting and you can actually explore it, here the game is pretty linear despite the player being able to go back and forth throught the locations, and actually seems like it was supposed to be story-driven. But the player ends up hacking and slashing the enemies mostly just for the sake of hacking and slashing. The whole game seems like a start, a pretty good start, but that is just it. Even though i recommend the game. i cannot say that it is worth 60 bucks. And I would not have bought it for these money.

reviewText:
Game was extremely frustrating at first, only because I'm not used to playing this type of combat style. This game actually got me to play Dark Souls just to see the connection everyone was talking about, and I'll agree it definitely was inspired, but its so different from DS that honestly the only relevant link I can make between them is the combat style. A few key things to note about this game would be:

- Every action you take animation locks you. Light weapons like daggers/fists are very short locks if you don't get snagged in a combo attack, and larger weapons like greatswords and maces have a longer lock (approx. 3-4 seconds per special attack swing). This is also effected by the type of armor you're wearing. Wielding Heirloom (elemental hammer) and wearing all light armor I was able to swing and dodge attacks significantly faster.

- Know your enemies! This game is 90% about knowing your enemies and how to handle them. This isn't the type of game where you get in and steam roll through trash mobs to the boss. You need to wait for your enemies to give you an opening and move in for the attack. The more you play this game & the more you die, the more you'll get better at noting openings in your enemies. Once you get the timing down to make hits in the sweet spots, the enemies drop like flies.

- Leveling. I found it insanely helpful to level grind for a while in order to progress to the area past the 3rd boss easier. The good news is that there's an experience modifier you gain from killing multiple enemies in a zone without going back to the crystal and healing. This modifier makes it insanely easy to level up and I recommend taking full advantage of it. (side note: bank your experience when you get the chance, it won't reset the modifier and you'll be thankful you didn't have it on you when that 1 mob decided to eat your face off in an area way far off from your last crystal touch).

Things I would like to see them improve on with this game:

- Combat system: swing/hit lag. There's been numerous times in a fight where I got hit by a swing that was actually 4 feet away from my face, as if the weapon has an invisible hit box on it that extends past the actual model of the weapon. There's also the enemies that swivel around to cornhole you when they should be stuck in an animation lock.

- Combat system: heaviness. I enjoy how heavy combat feels here, but to an extent. I've fought quite a few enemies wielding a huge great axe with a heavy shield on that come at you swinging a mile a minute AND have time to swivel on a heel turn and block your attack with that big shield that begs you to question why this is kosher when it takes you 3-4 seconds to make that swing and sticks you in a deadly animation lock. If combat is going to be this heavy I would highly recommend making sure all the monsters suffer the same penalty.

- Expansion to multiplayer/co-op. I really, really hope to see this game develop further into a state of being where other players can come in as other characters and assist. I realize at the moment everyone plays as Harkyn, so it's a bit unlikely, but this game has a ton going for it in all the right places and I would love to get the opportunity to play it with friends instead of having them watch me play. This game starts out a little raw in the beginning, so it'd be nice to have the ability to walk through it with a friend that's new to it and encourage them to keep going/show them the ropes.

- Map. This game would have benefitted GREATLY from a map or at least a compass that points you towards lost experience points like the loot compass if you're really against maps for forcing exploration (I'd argue there's no reason you can't just have people unlock the map by exploration as they go though). I had no problem memorizing where to go and how to get there after a few runs of zones, but whenever I died I wasn't particularly paying attention to the exact location I was in and I'd have to run around for a while to figure out where I dropped exp. There was also a time where I died at the entrance and dropped 6k, but when I respawned the experience wasn't there, even though I still had 100% (6,438) on the screen waiting for me to pick it up. I had to just take a dive because I had no clue where it put it.

Comments:

- I would have loved to see the story developed a little further. We know very little about Harkyn, but are continuously reminded of his reputation. This may be intentional, leaving the player to their own imagination, but it makes it feel a bit impersonal. Also, the ending was....disappointing. I just wasn't really ever sold on this game story-wise. I played it for the challenge and the audio clips were intriguing to say the least, but that was about it. It could have benefitted from a little more world immersion, cutscenes, and an ending that's better than just a re-cap of what you accomplished and a snippet of story about Adyr.

The ending feels rushed honestly, or like someone got burnt out and just needed to meet a deadline. It bums me out because of how awesome the game was otherwise -- but perhaps we'll see more great titles that improve upon this? :)

I would love to see some worthy content addition that adds more areas to play in so we're not stuck in just this one castle. While there is one other area you gain access too, most of the game is played just in a single area with multiple zones you're entering into. It's huge, don't get me wrong, but I would love to see more.

TLDR: I highly recommend this game and will be continuing to play with ng+ and ng++. It frustrates the crap out of me when I die but, I'm constantly challenging myself to beat bosses without taking any damage at all or meeting legendary requirements to make it harder on myself and taking advantage of every slow-mo death blow I deal while adding a BAM" vocally for enhanced enjoyment
date: as is mandatory. Game takes a while to warm into if you'r'e new to it's kind
recommended: but stick with it and you'll get your monies worth."

reviewText:
I haven't completed the game yet but I really like it. It seems like the perfect middle ground between a normal RPG and Dark Souls.

The big problem though, and I mean BIG problem, are the crashes caused by this game which are unlikely to ever get fixed at this stage. You'll know thier sting when you get the Beast down to it's last few hits and then the game freezes. That literally just happened to me about 2 minutes ago.

It's not the first time it's crashed, there have been many.. but never at such a pinnicle moment before.

I have crashed more times than I have actually been killed in LotF. Unless you're prepared to troubleshoot a list of 30 possible fixes for this game's problems with no guarantee any of them will work, expect it to crash from time to time.

TLDR: It's worth playing but get it on consoles if you can to avoid issues.

reviewText:
Solid combat on par with its obvious inspiration Dark Souls / Demon's Souls

Feels uniquely heavy and arguably more realistic. Reccommend a first playthrough is done with heavier armor until you get used to it however. Light armor results in getting hit being brutally punishing.

Highly reccommend learning how to use the sprinting shield bash well to help with handling the more tanky shield-toating enemies most people have loved to complain about. I found after some practice I was able to make quick work of them when at first they were genuinely difficult to handle.

Also a huuuuuge note to those who might have crashing issues and feel they can't properly challange themselves due to being unable to use checkpoints to save the game and risk losing their exp multiplier: The multiplier is not based on how long it has been since you have use a checkpoint. It simply gives you more exp based on how much you are carrying on you. The only thing that will reduce this is if you use a checkpoint and actually BANK your exp into your AP or SP pools. So long as you are holding XP that you would drop on your ghost if you died, you will continue to build up your multiplier.

The story is forgetable but enough to give some context to your actions. I'm more in it for the gameplay personally so this doesn't really affect me too much.

The in game areas and vistas are incredibly beautiful and graphically this game is very much a looker.

You will need a fairly beefy rig to get the best out of it, but after the latest update allowing you to disable the nvidia specific effects, it seems to run a lot more reliably and much more steady framerates.

With Vsync turned off my rig runs this at around 60 - 70 fps, usually around a steady 70 fps in most areas. This falls a fair bit when first loading into new areas via a portal, but quickly evens out after just a few moments.

Overall I highly reccommend this game to any veteran of the Souls series who is in it just for the extremely satisfying gameplay. You will feel some real accomplishment as you go from struggling to kill most foes to finding ways to easily dispatch them, and conquering some genuinely interesting boss fights. You won't find your intriguing and wonderfully subtle story line, but you'll find a generic fantasy plot decent enough to give you an excuse to slay more demons.

reviewText:
Il start by saying that i enjoyed playing LotF until the end without any issues and 2 crashes only, mostly bc of problem i have on my graphic card (Sometimes stop responding), its a very entertaining game with interesting story with 2 key points that change the outcome of the ending you get.

Im not going to make Dark Souls comparations, first bc DS didnt invented the wheel, only shapped to better what other games like Darksiders or Fable The Lost Chapter for instance, had already tried to achieve.

Its very easy to fall into making new games rip off of others, but i think most have their own identidy, for instance i find the combat in LotF more polished that DS, but being more easy in term of challenge and specially bosses fights.

The graphics and sound are very good and the story is interesting enough to keep you playing, the voice actors do decent job but sometimes lack ability to create link with the player but nothing special.
The gameplay is fun and requires a little understanding on how to use things, and the game does a good job on that if you read the hints carefully at tutorial.

Overall i find LotF good enough to make me wait for a sequel that is already confirmed by the Dev, there is still a DLC coming for this game with the last PC patch, but even without it i already made my purchase worth while with 30h of gameplay and half way out of the second playthrough, wich show that the game have some replay value, something that most games miss out now days unfortunatly.

reviewText:
I'm going to do some comparison between this game and the Souls series because of how similiar their core gameplay is. So, brace yourself.

Lords of the Fallen is a short but fun game. Its core gameplay mechanics are highly similiar to the mechanics found in the Souls series. The difficulty and depth, however, aren't on the same level. I would describe it as a dumbed down version of the Souls series, but that would imply that it's a clone of that series. Which it is not.

Story:
The story is about an outlaw called Harkyn, who is freed from prison to help fight the invading rhogar. Not everyone is happy about this and you will notice it when you talk to certain npcs. As the story progresses, you will fight the leaders of the rhogar, the rhogar lords.
The story is presnted clearly, with cutscenes and as background lore which is found in audio logs that you find as you explore. The audio logs are played in the background and they aren't intrusive.



Gameplay:
Gameplay is, as stated before, very similiar to what you find in the Souls series. There are backstabs, parries and ripostes as well as light and strong attacks. The overall pace of the fights feels somewhat slower than in the Souls series though.
The control scheme on a controller is super similiar to the control scheme of the Souls series.

You will start the game by choosing a magic school out of three different options. One provides stealth themed spells, while another provides defensive magics while the last provides offensive magics.

Then you proceed to pick a character type out of three different options. There is the warrior, that starts with heavy armor and is strength oriented. Then there is the rogue, that starts with light armor and is agility oriented. And last but not least there is the cleric, that starts with medium armor and is faith oriented.

Note: Nothing is bound to your starting character type. Any type can use any type of equipement, provided that they meet the neccesary requirements. However, you are not able to get any magics from other spell schools than the one you picked at the start.

Your character has a variety of different attributes which you can improve with experience(exp) gained from killing enemies. This exp will be lost upon death if it hasn't been banked at a checkpoint. When you die, you leave behind a ghost that contains all the exp you had on you, and it can be retrieved by getting to it and activating it.

This exp on your ghost will start to deplete over time so getting to it as fast as possible is essential if you wish to gain the most of your exp back. The ghost will provide you with a slight health regen when you are near it, possibly aiding you in a place where you previously died in a tough battle. This bonus is lost when you pick up the ghost.

Your character is able to wield a shield and a weapon, dual wield small weapons such as daggers and shortswords and two-hand bigger weapons like greatswords and greataxes.

You will also gain a gauntlet which is your primary source for magical or elemental damage. The gauntlet has three modes:
Projectile, which shoots a long distance projectile.
Blast, which is a short range blast that knocks most enemies to the ground while dealing minor damage.
Explosive, which basically throws a magical grenade.



Graphics, Visuals, Art:
The graphics are nothing especially amazing, but they are good enough. The art style wasn't to my liking, but I didn't really dislike it either. Come to think of it, I found the monster desing and the overall art style to be somewhat reminiscent of Diablo 3. Anywho, in my eyes, the game looks good enough.



Music & Sounds
I haven't really got anything to say about the BGM. I think the BGM is nice and quiet by default, since I can't remember hearing it too much. Heh. As normally I have to tone down the music volume so that the BGM doesn't get intrusive. No such problems here. The voice acting is decent. Could be better, yes. But it gets the job done, with a static decent quality.



Afterword:
It took me around 15 hours to finish my first playtrough, but that's not that bad since the game has the New Game Plus (NG+) option. I haven't tried the NG+ yet, since I decided to make a different type of character to find out my favorite playing style, but I'm hoping that the difficulty will spike up in the NG+.

Overall I would recommend this game, but not at full price. Especially fans of the Souls series should wait for a price drop, imo. And those who never touched a Souls game or found them too hard or difficult to grasp, this game might serve as a good introduction to the gameplay mecahincs, as it's less in depth and thus easier to grasp.
