reviewText:
I don't know how far I'm into Lords of the Fallen yet, but I feel like I should write a review because it's still fairly new and there's probably a lot of people thinking about getting it. I'm a big fan of the 'Souls' series by From Software, as many of the reviewers on here are. However, as Lords of the Fallen's story hasn't really caught my interest, I'm just going to review the combat mostly.

Combat
The combat, at first, feels slow and clunky.

-Armor makes or breaks how combat, for you, will flow. I fell into heavy armor very quickly, finding that the increased defence and poise made it so I could tank many hits while swinging around a big weapon. Once I got the basic understanding of how they wanted someone in heavy armor to approach fights, it stopped feeling slow and clunky and started to just feel meaty. In comparison to any of the Souls games, heavier armor makes a significant amount of difference in whether or not you can take a hit and how much damage you'll take. I like this, personally, as it means that armor is as big a decision for you as your weapon choices.

-Weapons are fairly varied, but rather than directly upgrading any weapon with a moveset you like, you have to find better weapons that do the same thing. It's more of a traditional RPG setup, where finding better gear is important. The weapons, however have fairly limited movesets based on type and some weapons are very ineffective against certain bosses. Overall, I'm fairly unhappy with the weapon options, with the faster weapons feeling weak and having very little advantage against the heavy hard hitting great weapons. There is one advantage Lords of the Fallen has, most weapons have a very satisfying weight to them that is missing in other games. Few things are as satisfying as crushing something's head with a big hammer after you've died to it a few times, and the weapons allow this.

-Stamina and Power Attacks are very interesting. Stamina recharges quickly, and only when you really invest in attacking or block a lot of attacks that you perhaps should not be do you feel like you are running out of stamina. Speaking of investing in attacks, your Strong Attacks can be charged up in Lords of the Fallen, making them more powerful. I like this a lot, as it adds a big dynamic to how much time you're going to invest in a swing which makes a world of difference in the combat in Lords of the Fallen. Another great system is Perfect Hits, which are performed when you hit the attack button just as your last hit finishes, conserving more stamina on the next swing allowing for longer (or improved, in the case of dual wielding) combos. The changes to how you can use your stamina are really interesting, and add a new layer of depth to a system that I feel like I knew well.

-Magic is fairly uninteresting. The spells are mostly buffs or light AoE attacks, and although these buffs have very powerful  effects and can be used in combat I found myself forgetting about them more often than not. The cast time for spells is long, meaning you have to find openings to cast effectively. Even when I did cast, I found myself more often than not focusing on using a single spell before a fight or when a boss was doing an action that allowed me a few moments respite. Magic adds to the meaty combat, making you feel more powerful when you use it, but it lacks in variety. The Gauntlet is very cool, however it is difficult for me to find it's place in the meaty melee combat of Lords of the Fallen.

One other thing I would like to note before I wrap this up is that the game itself is very pretty. I'm not a big fan of the design choices for how the enemies and the main character look in armor (shoulderpads bigger than your head and spikes!), but the rest of the game looks beautiful. My computer can normally run games on max settings, but I find Lords of the Fallen on even mid-low settings is fairly clunky in terms of FPS and whatnot.

Overall, I would recommend Lords of the Fallen. It's fun, meaty, and so far a great time sink. As a Souls player it took a bit of getting used too, but the ability to take hits from enemies and not worry means a lot after playing the Souls series, where I used to try to dodge everything. I feel like it doesn't have the same challenge as say Demon's Souls or Dark Souls, but it is overall fair and it doesn't need to be that difficult. Both seperate and compared to it's spiritual predecessors, it stands as a overall decent game.

reviewText:
TL;DR: Dont expect Dark Souls, but if you like Dark Souls you might like this game, too. It has a more traditional approarch to storytelling and a different, slower combat system. These things arent better or worse, but some people might be upset about that. In the first part of this review I will list the differences to Dark Souls, after that I will tell you what I think the game does good and bad.

Differences to Dark Souls:
- combat is slower and less responsive, which isnt a bad thing. In Dark Souls when you press attack, your character immediately attacks, even with heavy weapons. The heavier your weapon the attack costs more energy and also your character needs longer to recover after an attack before you can dodge or attack again. In Lords every attack, even with light weapons, has a wind-up kinda. So when you press attack, your character starts swinging his sword so the attack hits the enemy very late in the animation and after the animation your character has a long recovery time before you can block again, but you can attack very quickly after the first attack. Because of this making combos is much more effective in Lords than in Dark Souls. Another difference is that you can dodge ANY time while you are attacking, which means you can also cancel your attack animation.

- dodging is different. In Dark Souls when you dodge your character jumps" away very fast (depending on your gear). While you are dodging you are invulnerable for very short time even if the enemy attack hits you. In my experience with Lords there were 2 situations were dodging behaves different. When you are in a defensive position and the enemy attacks and you dodge

recommended: especially because your character rolls much slower than in Dark Souls

reviewText:
Screw the haters.
Okay, here's the deal: the game is a Souls ripoff. It's also nowhere near as good as the Souls games. Does that mean it's bad? No.
Lords of the Fallen takes the Dark Souls formula and twists it a bit. You got interconnected areas to explore, you got respawn points to find, you got deaths to do, it's all there, but it's got its own additions to the system. It does magic really well - even the gimmicky-looking but fun spells like Mimic have use - and it has a really cool attitude to subquests: yeah, they're there, but forget tracking and a journal - you remember to do them, or you don't. This may sound annoying and backwards but given the rather small size and huge interconnection fo the game's world, it opens a lot of rewards for exploration: you get this mysterious item, wonder if that guy who alluded to it has something to say about it, better go talk to him - on the way, oh look, secret switches I missed and a whole new area filled with giant ♥♥♥♥ing spiders.
Completionists won't like it - or the fact that there's a bunch of choices with very definite consequences that can lock you out of rewards - but it encourages thorough approach and constantly being on lookout for secrets, and the game is chock-full of those.

Okay, the elephant in the room and what most people hate: combat. It's slow. In addition to good old souls' stamina, attacks just come out slowly even with fast weapons. It's not very stylish or action-packed and emphasises strategy over reflexes. I can't really speak for the people who hated it but here's a tip: try out the biggest ♥♥♥♥ing stick you have in your inventory. Wielding slow and powerful weapons has rarely been so satisfying and I maintain this game has the best-feeling warhammers I ever cracked goblin skulls with.

What else is there? The setting is obviously nowhere near Souls stuff and you will get tired of the endless snow, the story is really predictable (although the novelty of medieval audiologs helps with that a fair bit) and most of the bosses are variations on Big Guy In Armor. Mechanically they are mostly handed well (two exceptions aside) but could use a bit more creativity in visual department.

What it really comes down to is this: it tries to be Souls. It's not. But it's a solid tribute and definitely a good game for at least the one playthrough when you get all the magic of exploring harsh, unforgiving and content-packed environments. The real failure" of Lords of the Fallen is that it doesn't live up to the source material - but when the source material is brilliant
date: being just good is nothing to be ashamed of. I wouldn't by it at full price but this game is a very solid sale pick.\n\nOh
recommended: and don't buy the DLC. It blows - about an hour long and ending with a boss that's just piling one idiotic design decision over another.\n"

reviewText:
So, despite the rumors and vids that i heard and saw, i still bought that game. I have to say that i don't regret it. Yes, the game has its flaws, but which game hasn't?
The bugs and the major performance issues didn't show up in my playthrough. (could be because of all the patches the developers released). In fact, i never had any FPS drop down below 55 on ultra settings and didn't had any gamebreaking bug or CTD.

There are only some problems i have with the game.
First, the overall length of the story. It is waaay too short for that kind of game. I didin't rush through the campaign nor did i miss any side quest. I did everything i could and explored every dungeon. For that 16 hrs are too few.
The second problem is the Lore. Yes you can read a bit about the Lore in the codex and you find audio notes here and there, but the explanation is way too vague and you are just thrown into a world you have no idea of. You get way too few infos about any character not even your own. A shame actually, because the world seems pretty interesting.
Thrid and final problem i had is the lack of quest informations and the vague explanations of quest locations. I guess it is a bit like Dark Souls in that regard, but it wouldn't have hurt to actually have a list of all open quests. I can live with the lack of map or questmarkers, but a chance to reread what the open quests are about would be helpful.

As you can see i recommend the game so there has to be something positiv about it right? :) There is. The fact that they shamelessly copied from Dark Souls pays off. The combat is breathtaking and you really have to be strategic to defeat the various types of enemies and bosses. The boss battles are hard, but still fair. The different weapon types all feel completely different. Every weapon has its own story and unique look. Armor as well. The weight and energy system is as good as in Dark Souls. Do you want to be the fast dodging skilled fighter with two blades or more the heavy armored Tank who wields a huge axe and tower shield? It's up to you. You can even be both or a mix in between ;)
Oh well and the graphics look badass.

So overall, I can say that i quite enjoyed the game and might start a NG+ sooner or later. If you didn't buy the game till yet and you really want a game that is a little easier than Dark Souls then buy it :)

reviewText:
I have been playing this game nonstop. At first it was hard to accept and get into. However once you start getting through the first few bosses in the game and explore the magic mechanics in this game. It gets really interesting. I recommend this for those who want a challenge but at the same time do not want to be punished harshly like darksouls. If you always wanted to play darksouls but cannot handle the level of difficulty this game is for you. It is pretty much the same mechanics but it is way easier the more you play.

Also for those who say this game was broken, I admit I was one of them who got this game when it first released. I can confirm to you now that I have been playing this game nonstop for the past few days and I have not had a single crash or any framerate drops. It works fine now so you don't have to worry about it crashing or being unplayable.

Recommended.

- Those who are wondering why I do not write a full detailed review with ratings, the reason is because reviews are just opinions. I do not want what I say to affect someone's decision of buying the game or not. Do not let someone's negative or postive review affect your choice of buying a game. Make your own decision.

reviewText:
I've only just started this, so this review will probably change, and I could be wrong about points that I make, so I'm going to apologize in advance, sorry. Also, I might spoil some enemy types that aren't integral to the story, but if you would rather figure out your own strategy against them, don't read the last few lines

Anyways, so far this game is satisfying, it's truly a souls clone in combat controls and exploration design but the game does not share similar character movement, progression, speed, or difficulty. Let me explain: I feel that the game's designers decided at a very early stage in development that the souls style of studying enemy attack patterns and figuring out where to go through trial and error was what Lords Of The Fallen was going to use. But instead of completely copying the formula, as there was a good chance that it would bring more criticism than it would praise, the game's difficulty is only in learning the enemies patterns. Most enemies do not instantly kill you, and very many don't actually hit you for a third or half of your health bar. Instead they usually deal a lot less damage. Also, the game gives you the freedom of using magic in any character class a lot quicker than the souls games.

The tough part, the portion of the game that I feel people will either love or hate, is that the game feels considerably slower than the souls games. Your character doesn't quite roll as fast backwards or forwards and the enemies really need to telegraph their heavy attack for you to be hinted at a safe side roll. Still, I was able to use it effectively on multiple enemies and it felt good to get my character to a green weight and feel how much quicker he was after getting used to the heft of dodging. As far as dual wielding and the long range guantlet, they are severely limited in my opinion. They have such a high risk of not stunning the enemy or taking such a long time to complete the animation that I feel that the easiest course of action is still sword and shield. I was surprised that the shotgun style blast spell of the guantlet took so long to shoot and since it recommends close range to be effective, in it's current state I have never sucessfully used it.

I have unlocked 4 spells for the warrior class and while I have benefited from using them in certain situations, since they share from the same mana pool as the guantlet, take a while to cast, and have a considerably longer cooldown, I rarely use them outside 1v1 encounters with tougher enemies. They really haven't helped me with crowd control. I can say that the guantlet's piercing spell has saved me a couple of times, though. As for the crowd control, areas stay clear of enemies that you have killed until either you are away from them a significant amount of time (could possibly also be distance from the area), or when you die. Enemies will then respawn and you can kill them all over again.

The trade off with healing and hoarding XP is explained pretty early on. You can heal and refill potions at red rocks scattered through the map. They have floating stones around them that represent the amount of potions they can fill and those have a cooldown, so the game promotes your progression forward and finding the next checkpoint rock. Also, you can choose to fill xp into either spell or ability points, with the trade off being the more xp you carry, the more rare the loot drops are. There is also a smith that will let you enchant items with gems if they have sockets. It will also let you bet xp into the smithing process to coax out more valuable gems.

The story itself did sort of a poor job explaining why you are doing what you're doing at the start. It really just throws you into fighting tutorials as Harkyn, and doesn't explain for a few hours why you're just killing a bunch of monsters. When it is explained by Kaslo, a monk you're following, it really is as simple as kill the monsters or we die. There is a lore tab in the menus that explains more in detail what you are doing, and pieces of that lore are picked up as scrolls during the game. I can't say much of the story right now outside of the obvious, you fight lords, you die, they die, it's fun.

That's all I can really type for where I'm at in the game but here's a tip for minimizing damage with most of the dudes with shields, the doggies, fatty sniper, and the circle-strafing rogue: The sprinting shield bash has stunned 99% of the humanoid enemies, and it almost always leaves room for a follow up attack. Use it on the dog like creatures, it knocks them like 10ft from where it connects. The fat sniper recovers pretty quick so after the follow up I make some space with the backwards roll and shoot him with the piercing guantlet, with the right timing, that's like a third of his health.

reviewText:
Fantastic game. It's dark, visceral, and difficult. Yet, unlike the series of games that it usually gets compared to, you actual learn to fight and beat the bosses. Not just stand back and cheap them with projectile magic.

It's georgous. You'll need a high end PC to run it but it's worth it. You pick a class, which only really effects the available magic spells and maybe initial stats. But after that, you pick and choose both your stats and play style, which is mostly generated by your weapon and armor choices.

Definitely a unique experience.

reviewText:
I really wish I could recommend Lords of the Fallen, the game carries a great deal of potential and by somewhat replicating the souls series combat mechanics they have assured that at least some of the combat is satisfying and enjoyable but the truth is that for all my hopes that souls style gameplay can become a genre in and of itself Lords of the fallen is sadly not the game to do it.

The most glaring issue for this game is it's shoddy release state. For a start the game is very poorly optimised, on release PhysX and Vsync options did not even appear on the settings menu and even now that these have been patched in the game still performs very poorly with either turned on and worse will run your GPU and CPU dangerously hot, Over-clockers beware this game can cause damage to your components, though its more likely your GPU will fail and crash the game before serious issues occur. Even if one simply turns off vsync and PhysX the game has a plethora of bugs including but no limited to:
Weapon special attacks that crash the game
Exploding enemies that crash the game
Inconsistent auto-saving that can cause loss of progress or leaving the player in a position from which they cannot progress.
All of these bugs will hopefully be fixed in subsequent patches but in its initial state the game verges on unplayable for a significant number of players.

Unfortunately the bugs are not the game's only issue. The game's main problem stems from the developer's misconception about challenge, namely, that prolonging a fight makes that fight more challenging. Of the various enemies in the game around 50% have health regenerating abilities of one kind or another, these enemies are supposed to be challenging when they regenerate from nothing to near full health but all this really does is force the player to fight the same fight they already won over again, this saps the satisfaction from combat leaving it boring instead of challenging. This problem is exacerbated during boss battles and while I have only encountered one boss with health regen abilities many of the bosses I have faced have had some mechanic which prolongs the fight unnecessarily usually forcing the player to stop attacking the boss to dealing with smaller, low level enemies. Rather than feeling satisfaction at your mastery after defeating a boss you will instead just be glad you don't have to go through the tiresome mechanics another time.

However eventually the game does become a bit more fun. Somewhere around the mid-point you will begin to find weapons that can take off a decent chunk of the more tiresome opponents health. You will be thrilled when you kill an enemy before it can heal. You will begin to realise that Lords of the Fallen is more about gear than skill and the most fun is to be had once you've gathered a decent set of tools to work with. There is certainly a satisfaction to be had as you dominate an enemy that previously caused numerous deaths but at the same time much of the sense of challenge has evaporated. Unfortunately many of the game's bugs begin to rear their heads not long after this point and your gameplay becomes a frustrating battle with CTD's.

The game's art style is very much going to depend on personal preference but whether you like it or not it doesn't feel like it has much individuality. Armour, weapons, enemies and scenery could all have been plucked from Diablo 3 though with considerable improved graphical fidelity.

Similarly the story will make you long for the quiet cryptic narrative of a Souls game as generic fantasy is drawled with all the emotion of a wooden plank. The character's never give you a reason to feel any kind of connection to them and you carry out the tasks demanded of you simply to progress with no care as to their fates. The game's decision to use a lead character rather than allow the player to create their own seems pointless as the character is never developed. He is generic, gruff, male anti-hero number 5677 lacking even an endearing one-liner that would promote him to generic bad ♥♥♥ status.

All in all the game feels like squandered potential. There is a good combat system here including a few refinements to the souls formula such as the perfect hit system that From Software should take a look at. But that system is dragged down by bugs, crashes and badly designed enemies. The good news is that these can be fixed. Bug fixing and optimization and rebalancing enemies and bosses could make this game an enjoyable experience. But until then this game is impossible for me to recommend.

reviewText:
Now, let me start off with the good. This game is fairly fun to play (which is a HUGE plus and the only thing that kept this game worthwhile to me)  and has solid combat (albeit some weird hitboxed in some places). The levels are rather well designed, with everything being interconntected by cool shortcuts.

Now onto the bad, which there is a LOT of.
FIrst of all, this game runs like absolute crap. On NVIDIA GTX 760, I was barely about to keep it at 40ish fps on all lowest settings. Second, this game crashes. A LOT. And this is especially frustrating because unlike the Souls games, this game only saves at checkpoints (bonfires). So, it is quite easily possible to lose 20+ minutes of gameplay after a crash. Some enemies (I am looking at you, exploding fire beasts) seem to almost always crash the game without question if you get hit by the explosion.

Besides running badly, this game has some poor design decisions. Certain attacks feel faaar too fast and unpredictable to dodge with any sort of human reflexes, so you are basically forced to eat them on the chin.

The difficulty feels really inconsistent. Unlike the Souls series, it really suffers from overleveling if you explore everything similar to many other RPGs. So, while the game starts off fun and challenging, if you are like me and explore everything, starting about half way through the game you will get so tanky you can just wear heavy armor and take almost everything on the chin without dodging or blocking.

Addidionally, the inventory system is HORRENDOUS in this game. It uses the same inventory as dark souls, where all items are put into one huge list based on the slot they go in. And while this wasn't horrible for dark souls, it is really bad for this game as it is based on the Western style of RPGs where you are constantly getting new armor/weapons which are straight up better than the ones you had before. As far as I could find, there is absolutely no way to trash, sell, or drop old items. And while you can favorite ones you want to use, you cannot automatically favorite new ones. So whenever you get a new weapon, you have to often scroll through 30+ other ones before you can find it.

The last downside of this game, is how insanely short it is. While my skill from a LOT of experience with the souls series probably made me beat this game a lot faster than the average person, the shortness still cannot be overlooked. Trying to explore and find EVERYTHING, this game took me 17 hours to beat. If I was just doing the main story, I probably would have done it in 10 or less. And with this game being relatively linear and lack of multiplayer, the replay value certainly feels lacking.

CONCLUSION/ TD:DR
Despite these huge issues, I have to say that I still enjoyed this. But the only reason for it is my absolutely ADORATION of the Souls style of combat (Dark Souls 1 is easily my favorite game ever made, with me putting 500+ hours into it). So if you are like me and absolutely adore this style of combat, you might find this a fun distraction despite the plethora of issues. For most people though, this game is not worth the $50, at least not until the bugs/crashes get fixed.

reviewText:
Potentially purchasing a broken game.
I want to say it's good, but it really isn't. A poor effort for a full release. Lots of very disappointing, annoying glitches and faults that render the game unenjoyable and potentially unplayable in some cases.
Weapons disappear for no reason, the game crashes and freezes on top of very demanding specifications and disk space (powerful PC's  in order to run the game),
No navigational indication other than memory and the will to explore; not even labels for the areas you are in or are about to enter (noting a majority of the quests make you travel to areas you are expected to know the location of, which is on the downright silly list).
I can go on. I am very disappointed and don't recommend this game unless it is fixed and people start getting what they paid for.

reviewText:
I would've like to recommend this game. But as a game developer I value gameplay and especialy experience over graphics, this sadly wasn't up for it.

A few plus points about the game: graphics, animations, music, sound effects, awesome looking armor (eye-candy) and I liked the storyline although It lacked a bit depth (not getting dragged into it enough).

The bad part: the combat was bad. Enemies do not follow the same rules as the player, making everything tacticly impossible, resulting in ditching tactis and starting to run and button bash until the other was dead. Even physics rules don't always apply to enemies; a full charging shielded guy can rotate 180 degrees instantly and knock me back, fire arrows hitting my tower shield sets me on fire, enemies thrusting their polearm into my shield gives me damage (100% physical damage reduction and still got enough stamina), I could go on with these flaws but I won't; simply honor rules of physics or how we look at magic.

If you played the Dark Souls series and loved their combat, don't think this will be like it. Well you can just ditch all your knowledge and the observating mindset. The thing I missed most was the feeling that I (myself) did it wrong when I died, falling into pits because of auto-targeting (not the lock-target) and dying because of physics flaws and animation/attack timing issues (for good and for bad) didn't really motivated me to hone my skills further (player leveling).

Hopefuly the developers will keep this stuff in mind for their next game and if they do I would love to buy it.

reviewText:
Just wanted to give a review on this to help people who are unsure about it. Overall the game is very good. The presentation and gameplay are top notch. It all feels hand crafted and it looks as though a lot of love has gone into it all. The difficulty curve is very good. If you're struggling with a particular enemy type early on then change your tactics. This is all you realise as you play through. Some guys have huge shields so using your sword might not be the best approach. Try some long spear pikey thing to piece the shield and all of a sudden your doing damage again. Same with armour. You can totally change the way you fight from moment to moment.

So...Dark Souls. Yes it's similar but so are most video games in general. compare Battlefield and COD...compare Silent Hill with Resident Evil....compare Ridge Racer to Mario Kart (maybe not that one... :))

All i can say is that LOTF is it's own game despite the similarities. After an hour or two it's clear this is no copycat. they have taken some of the greatest bits of Dark Souls and used them to craft their own world. You can feel the strong influences from the guy who worked on The Witcher. The enemies, armour/weapons, environment do really have a great look to them.

And then there's the lighting...WOW!!

Only complaint so far: Random crashes happen every hour or so. Also...could do with a torch in places...

If you love Dark Souls that much then stick to that. This isn't Dark Souls, nor does it try to copy it. This is a game for gamers who can appreciatte good games...simple. :)

reviewText:
It's basically Dark Souls with much better graphics and toned-down difficulty. Still, Lords Of The Fallen is a great game.
It took me about 17h to complete and the game crashed only once, so I guess I was lucky :)

+ Stunning graphics.
+ Runs smoothly, 60fps@1080p all the time, all maxed.
+ The combat is simple, yet stellar, with a feeling of weight.
+ Decent length.
+ Armor design is superb, they look seriously badass!

- Too easy. The bosses in particular.
- The boss design is boring, practically every boss is a dude with a sword etc...
- Clunky animations, especially the characters.
- Not much to explore, the game is much more linear than f.ex. Dark Souls.

All and all, Lords of the Fallen was a good game and I can recommend it to anyone who likes the whole Dark Souls - style of gameplay and genre.

8/10

reviewText: Great game in it's own right. Combat is very well done. Each weapon has weight and works out exactly like you would expect it to. Graphics are really nice but needs a patch to fix the memory leak. Story is decent, voices are well acted. The best is the combat by far though. It really has the OOMPH" that the Dark Souls game severly lacked.\n\nI want to add a few things. There are quite a few bugs in this game that are downright game killing. A couple of the weapons have added procs that when they go off will crash the game about 80% of the time. The small "dogs" that are on fire and roll towards you will cause the game to crash at times. Enemies can and will disappear through walls
date: there's no hit detection on anything except enemies. The game is NOT optimized well to run on PC. While running the game with 4gb of Vram my memory will shoot up upwards of about 80-85%. My cpu will skyrocket as well. Anywhere from 20% all the way to about 70% depending on the area. While this game was supposedly made separately from consoles it's hard to tell as you get hints telling you to use triggers or bumper buttons.\n\nWhile I enjoy the game a lot
recommended: there's quite a bit going on in the background that is killing this game outright. At times when fighting enemies you'll even hear an "error" sound but nothing happens. Almost like there's a window behind the game alerting to something going wrong.\n\nAll in all
hoursPlayed: a good game that needs a couple of patches to iron out the wrinkles. If you're on the fence about this one I'd give it til at least the Steam Winter Sale to see if it drops in price and has been fixed appropriately."

reviewText: What a shame.. I for one really do think the game is lovely, but in its current state I can't recommend it. I wouldn't say its unplayable, but it does have some very annoying bugs (very odd fps drops, which seem completely unrelated to what goes on screen, wrong enemy hitboxes, wierd AI glitches, and so on). As I said this truly is a pity as the game is actually quite good in itself. The combat is addictive and it does have a nice, dark tone to it although the voice acting and lip-sync leaves a lot to be desired. So yeah, If it wasn't for so many technical issues I would definitely recommend it, though in its current state there is simply too much microstuttering and various stability issues going on for a game a la dark souls, where stability should be kind of a priority. FYI I didn't see many CTDs (just one in 6 hours), its just the other problems that are very annoying. Ethically I can't recommend a buggy game.. But if they fix it, this could become a hidden gem!

reviewText:
I greatly enjoyed this game - but I struggled with it in the beginning due to comparing it too much to Dark Souls.

For example - there are enemies that have their shield up nearly constantly. In Dark Souls you would kick, here the kick was nearly useless. However in Lords of the Fallen you shield rush your way through which is actually more awesome than the Dark Souls kick.


The game has many similarities that's true - but did introduce new ideas and concepts, however it seems that the gaming community might have expected more Dark Souls (an excellent game) but got Lords of the Fallen (a great game) and thus saw Lords in a negative light.


Things I loved:

Running through enemies with your shield up.
Jumping attacks - all the time.
Using giant weapons nearly constantly (something I didn't tend to do in Dark Souls)
The art style.
Some of the more unique looking enemies.
Most of the boss fights.
Being balanced for a single player game - thus allowing you to feel very powerful.

I haven't tried to play as a rogue or cleric - I might try these for the next play throughts - but I feel that I got a great deal with the warrior play through.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RUr927fKpCE

In the past year I’ve become a big fan of the Dark Souls series. After several unsuccessful attempts starting the first Dark Souls, both on Xbox 360 and PC, I finally dug my heels in and found an entry point into the infamously difficult action RPG. I moved on to Dark Souls 2 after finishing the original and spent many hours exploring the world and leveling my characters. Eventually my interest waned and I moved on to other games. Even though there was new Dark Souls 2 DLC, I’d become burned out and needed a break.

Cut to a few months later and I started to see footage of a new Souls-like game called Lords of the Fallen. The game looked beautiful and was an unapologetic Dark Souls clone, an action RPG with tight combat mechanics, high difficulty, and punishing bosses. Lords was positioned as a western version of the Japanese Souls series and looked to move into the specific niche carved out by Demon’s Souls, Dark Souls, and Dark Souls 2. As a fan of these games I was immediately intrigued. How does Lords of the Fallen compare? Is it a true successor to Souls series or is it just a pale pretender?

Developers Deck13 Interactive and CI Games have delivered a game built from the ground up to appeal to fans of Dark Souls. If you’ve played any of the Souls games you’ll be able to pick up and play immediately; there’s even a control scheme that matches that found in Dark Souls, save for a few minor differences. Rather than going through all the ways Lords of the Fallen is similar to Dark Souls, I’ll highlight some of the most interesting ways they differ.

The first major difference you’ll notice relates to the character you play. In the Souls series, there are no set characters. You’re responsible for choosing the way your character looks and there are no clear backstories. In fact, the story in the Souls series is largely opaque, with a few hints here and there. In Lords of the Fallen you play as Harkyn, a former prisoner with a troubled past. Although you can still customise your playstyle with creation choices, everyone experiences Harkyn’s story. This streamlines the story but also serves to limit your role-playing possibilities.

When starting a new game you choose class and magic type. Class determines starting skills, armour, and weapons. Magic type is a little misleading, as your magical powers are closer to special combat abilities rather than specific types of spells. Every magic type enhances combat, whether by weakening your enemies or strengthening your attacks. There’s no option for a pure magic user, for instance, as the game is specifically tuned for melee combat. What magic there is supplements hand to hand combat rather than replacing it.

This focus on hand to hand combat means that fights are slower and more deliberate. Even fights with low level enemies can take a minute or two to win. Shield-bearing enemies are everywhere in the world and they take up the most time; unlike Dark Souls, where you’re able to break their guard and attack during the opening, the shielded enemies in Lords of the Fallen recover quickly and don’t offer many attack opportunities. Thankfully you’re given a gauntlet that can fire magic projectiles and this soon became my go-to method for dealing with frustrating shields.

Lords of the Fallen streamlines the gameplay formula set in Dark Souls. This makes for a generally easier, friendlier experience. One of the most tedious aspects of Dark Souls relates to running back after dying during a boss fight. Bonfires are normally not right next to the boss. This means you have to struggle your way through groups of enemies in order to have another go. Lords does away with this frustration and typically places checkpoints right next to boss areas. You can also bank experience at checkpoints and then spend it later.

In general, Lords of the Fallen is a much more linear game, and that’s both a strength and a weakness. I prefer the open world of Dark Souls and the nebulous character motivations. I like having the option to try a different route or move to a whole new area if I’m stuck. The bosses in Lords of the Fallen, the titular Lords, are also pretty unoriginal. Mostly heavily armoured knights with shields, there are no bosses on the massive scale seen in the first Dark Souls. While there are different patterns and stages to their attacks, most boss fights are grindy and tedious.

Some of the game’s mechanics are poorly communicated. I was halfway through the game when I realised some walls could be broken by dashing into them while holding up your shield. The health potion replenishment system could be clearer as well; sometimes I’d have them all refilled when saving at a checkpoint and sometimes not. I later discovered this was regulated by how many enemies you killed between checkpoints; there might’ve been a tip explaining this, but if there was I missed it.

The story in Lords of the Fallen is much more transparent than those in the Souls series. There are dialogue trees and clear quest objectives. I had a much better idea of what my character was doing and where the story was going. That said, I didn’t necessarily know where I needed to go. I lost track of how many hours I spent backtracking, looking for that one door I hadn’t opened yet or struggling to find an obscure corridor. There aren’t that many different areas and some of them are ridiculous mazes with similar paths that blur together.

On a more positive note, Lords of the Fallen looks beautiful, with great lighting and animations; it’s definitely got Dark Souls 2 beat. However, my biggest gripe with the visuals is the inconsistent camera. Several times I found myself losing my character into first person mode by getting too close to a wall in combat.

Ultimately I enjoyed Lords of the Fallen; however, there isn’t as much replayability for me when compared to Dark Souls. You’re limited in character creation choices and there’s not that much difference between a cleric, a warrior, and a rogue. There are extra boss challenges that’ll reward you with a special weapon if you complete them but some of these are exceptionally difficult and don’t interest me that much.

I beat the game once in about 20 hours and then again in New Game+ in another 10 hours or so; I had a lot of fun playing through the first time but NG+ wasn’t that different. The combat kept me coming back but at a certain point the enemy scaling outpaced my own and I stopped having as much fun. The interminable backtracking also wore me down; there’s only so much time I want to spend running around a circular room.

Playing Lords of Fallen made me appreciate the Souls series even more; it’s been enough to whet my appetite for another Dark Souls 2 playthrough, and an attempt at the new DLC. I’m looking forward to Lords of the Fallen 2; hopefully Deck13 Interactive and CI Games will deliver a game with wider scope and more interesting bosses. Until then, there’s always the endless appeal of Dark Souls.

reviewText: 7.5/10  It is definitely a Dark Souls Clone. I hope people keep copying Dark Souls. It's  bit glitchy at times. The Shield seems completely useless, because the enemies don't do enough damage, and every time I block, it just breaks my guard. It's a pretty short campaign. At the beginning your first mission is to find some guy named Kelso. It has good replay value. After playing it twice, I still don't know much of the Lore. Some areas can be really confusing. I spent hours wandering around. The areas loop back and short cuts can be opened. Almost every enemy's attack is easily dodgable. Some of the enemies will do a series of weak attacks, and then randomly do an attack that does enough damage to kill you in one hit. It seems unfair. Overall it's a good game and it's worth playing. I got it on sale for $10

reviewText:
Lords is a great looking game and combat plays out with weight and timing that feels really good, that metal on metal crashing never gets old. A lot of work has gone into armor and weapons, you would be hard pressed to find a single item you didn't want to wear or use.

Unfortunately it's not a very long or hard game. Milage may vary but if your compenent with Souls games it's not going to take you long. There are only about 10 bosses and only 2-3 that required more than one attempt. Level design can be a little messy, on one side it's enjoyably intricate and the other an overly complicated, messy maze. Some zones just have way too many shortcuts and alternative routes that make things very confusing.

...and then there was the crashes, mid boss fight frustrations a plenty. Hopefully when I get around to a NG+ run that will be fixed.

Having said that, I loved and highly recommened it, just wish there was more.

reviewText:
Lords of the Fallen

First off i wanna say that i went into this without any real expectations. The game was gifted too me by my brother who is a huge dark souls fan. After spending a dozen hours with the game i have too say I am quite impressed. I am basing this review on my own experiences and not those of other people. I can recommend this game due too the fact i have had none of the crashes and hardships that everyone else has been having. I will list some pros and cons for the game and then a final verdict.

Pros:
-Gorgeous graphics, some of the best ive ever seen in an adventure game.
-Combat is fluid and takes timing, gives you a sense of accomplishment
-Loot and more loot
-Replay value, if you love collecting everything and wanna get 100% complete there is lots too do here
-Soundtrack is spot on

Cons
-Enemy types become repetitive
-Some framerate issues
-Camera can get a little in the way sometimes due too linear corridors
-Voice acting is mediocre at best and lip synching is terrible

So overall I found the game too be engaging and fun. Not the best action rpg i have ever played but surely not the worst. A great battle system and sense of urgency keeps you on your toes as you traverse this world in search of a new peice of gear and formiddable foes.

7/10
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I can only reccomend this game!
Sure, it is no Dark Souls 1 in terms of the world, the difficulty, the atmosphere and the sheer amount of complexity and content. BUT, when you look at this game by itself, its very good. Some points that are worth mentioning:

- The combat is amazing. All weapon types handle very differently and you have a lot of choices on how to engage and deal with enemies trough combos, leap attacks, rollattacks, parries, counters etc.
- The itemsystem and rpg element of the game is very solid. The different types of armor and shields offer a nice variety and whilst the character leveling is rather straight forward, you can still develop a unique playstyle.
- The leveldesign is top notch, the world feels like a maze where you always find new paths, secrets and shortcuts.
- Although the artstyle feels somewhat generic, I really enjoyed the atmosphere of a rough nordic world mixed a world, that reminds you of diablo1.
- The story was decent. The dialouges sometimes felt a bit cheesy, but I liked the plot and the audio logs.

In the end I would say the overall quality of this game is a bit worse than dks1, but better than dks2! Regarding technical issues: I had several problems with crashes and freezes that were really annoying, but the game is completely stable with patch 1.2 for me now.

reviewText: It was a really fun game and was my first experience at challenging ARPGs. I must say though for a $60 title it was very short in terms of content. I got 13 hours out of a single playthrough and was left wanting more. One thing I also disliked was the fact that you could tell the game was progressing very quickly because it seemed that in no time at all you were onto the next boss fight with no kind of down time or build up between them. I know what I said is very negative so far but wait. The combat which has to be the highlight of this game is EXTREMELY satisfying. That fact that I started out a pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥ player and slowly progressed and got better and better really made me feel good and helped me feel like my character was actually getting stronger. The story in this game wasn't too bad but wasn't really fully explained in my opinion. It felt very open ended when I finished the game but the audio logs that are left around the world that help you discover the story are a very nice touch. I absoloutley love the art style in this game but maybe a few less spikes on all the armour would be nice. :p Overall though I'd give this game a 7.5/10 and anyone who is looking for a game similar to dark souls but a bit easier and more of an entry into tough ARPGs, this is the game for you.

reviewText:
A few technical problems with this one. If you are using an AMD graphics card, this game will likely slow down or run at sub optimum. The specs required are higher than suggested. It isn't super stable.

That said, this game is a solid experience. Like many people, I will compare it to Dark Souls since they fit in the same niche. This game is an odd blend of Diablo style leveling & loot collection (everything is randomized), and Dark Souls combat.

You can technically pick a class, but very quickly these have little to no difference, beyond the cleric having a heal. Weapon stats, damage, and speed are all random so a pair of shortswords can do more damage than a two hander, and be slower. You have a stamina bar, health, a limited number of health potions that refill at rest points, a block, parry, heavy attack, light attack, and roll.

The art personally reminds me of the chunky comic book style from Darksiders, so a big plus. It does repeat the Dark Souls 2 problem of most enemies being some variation of guy in armor"
recommended: and the rarer non-human enemies are quite cool. The story is pretty standard fantasy fluff
hoursPlayed: and isn't going to under or overwhelm anyone. For 20$ or less
voteText: you are getting 10+ hours of solid game to slake that thirst that -for me- only the Souls series really fills."

reviewText: Lords Of The Fallen is obviously inspired by the souls series. Really obviou,but the fact is that it does a very good job in creating a world and using the souls gameplay in a very good way. It is to be expected then, that you will be drawing parallels between the two. First of all is it worth the money? I would say even though there is no pvp as far as my knowledge goes (it might change latter) that it is worth the money and time to play this game. It really has been a long time since I spend 30 hours in a few days not even a week in a game such as this, the combat system is fun and challenging (not as much as the souls series) and there are enemies that will require you to really figth hard to beat them (or use magic but we'll get to that) the leveling system is also nice, one small critisism I have is that faith weapons become really weak later on, but over all it's a really well made game polished with fun staged and bosses. At this point I have to say that it is rather easier that what dark souls, demos souls or bloodborne are to the point that an experienced souls player can beat bosses on a first run without a guide (which is wild fantasy in a souls game) and thats because of what I refered to previously as magic".\n\nMagic in this game or spells are really overpowered

reviewText: So it took me about 22 hours to finish the game on my first playthrough where developers were saying approximately 30 hours, which to me is fair but I am very familiar with this style of game and BECAUSE of my souls experience this game posed very little challenge. Once I was in a comfortable set of armor and found a weapon I liked, the game was a breeze and again little to nothing posed any real threat, I mean I one shot every boss in the game as I went through and the bosses were easily harder than any of the trash that was encountered. Now, I will mention this, this game is HEAVILY inspired by the Souls series, and rightfully so, the Souls game were so unique and so unforgiving that when I had finished them both with about 200 hours invested into each I was craving more of that Souls style combat and I found it here in spades, just not really as punishing as souls.\nAll the people who said that this game was bad because combat was slow a clunky and the developers tried to make it hard by making enemies dodge hit and block faster than you clearly has no patience at all, they were obviously spoiled by games like Darksiders where you can litterally button mash your way to victory. Combat in Lotf is precise and deiliberate. Swinging a heavy weapon means looking for that window, taking advantage of it, and reducing yourself to the fact that you may only get the one swing in unless you use a weapon which a much faster attack speed, it's all up to the player. What I did like was that they allowed magic to be a viable option even when building a melee character without being punished for it. This is a solid game and if you are the type that enjoys weighty realistic combat, visceral environments kick a$$ looking bosses, this game will not let you down. 8/10 for me.

reviewText:
Gametime: 15 hours
Number of playthroughs: 1

The Good:
- Beautiful, grim, dark art. Gothic in a sense with other inspirations for the more fantasy stuff.
- Decent keyboard controls, only remapped 2 keys
- Combat is good; forgiving for new players and hard to master for hardcore players. Parrying is difficult and optimizing stats is rewarding (but not really difficult in any way).
- Sound design is nice but not awesome
- Lots of items to customize with progression and unique art.
- UI and interface is decent
- FIghting enemies is fun but takes patience

The Bad:
- Crashes, most of which have been fixed for me with patches but some random ones here and there still exist.
- World feels small and cramped most of the time. Needs more areas and side quests.
- Side quests are hard to track and remember
- A lot of items in the game have cryptic effects that you won't know until you read about them or really experiment and pay attention
- Last boss fight was lame
- New Game+ doesn't have much to offer

The Ugly:
- Not much really, this game is a stone's throw away from being amazing.

reviewText:
Edit 1/9/16:  Gave this game another shot after a bunch of patches and an entirely new PC with completely different hardware and OS.  Game still crashed after about 15 minutes.  I wouldn't bother with this, or at least try to get it on sale on a console where it's hopefully more stable.

I would like to be able to give this game a proper review, but it is bugged and crashes every 20-30 minutes.  Looking around, this seems to be fairly common, with some people not even able to get into the game due to another bug that blocks them at startup, even after the patch.

On the second boss, he is bugged for me so that occasionally he stands in place, but still continues his actual attacks, so while he stands there like a statue, I take random ghost damage from an invisible source.  The game crashed for me once immediately after defeating him (no credit for the victory), and once when there was one swing left.

So far I've only been able to wade through the crashing to get to two bosses, both of which just have huge tower shields, and it's nothing but circle strafe and poke until you win.

I will assume for the sake of the game that is has some variety in its further levels, but I won't be able to see those until the game gets into working order on PC.  This is one of those rare times I wished I had purchased on console rather than steam.

reviewText:
This game is fun for every hours you spend on it. almost every boss fight is different. For new players i suggest warrior, because warriors tend to have massive dmg reduction early game, and you wont get 1-hit kill by the shield mob. However this game do have several bugs, the most annoying one is the combo death in one of those portals. If you die there, you will die again when you respawn, which makes you lost all the XP. But after 2nd death everything is normal again so no worry for unlimit death.


The total gameplay time is about 20 hours. 12 hours if you are a hard core player.And 2 hours if you are a hacker. Ps.Do not be a hacker in games, you will lose all the fun, all of it.

reviewText:
Short, and not so sweet:

This product is still in alpha phase in my opinion. Here's why:

1. Game crashes anywhere from 5-20 minutes. This is a critical and inexcusable issue, and a product of this cost should not be crashing on most players' PCs. This is something would find in Alpha phase with even a halfway compentent QA or development staff.

2. Product feels half finished. For what contect there is, it feels like half a game. The story is vague and generic. The characters are not even close to flushed out. The world is particularly small. What the player can do is limited. The camera angle and use in third person (the only viewpoint) is terrible at times. Your character's purpose in the world is a little too simple.

I don't like to be completely negative, and there are some good aspects of the game:

1. Even though the game can be difficult, it can be fun at times. The combat, although clumsy, is more or less solid and satisfying. Additionally, although simplistic, character development enhances the RPG" aspect of the game
date:
but it seems to cater to the warrior class and playstyle and punishes any other choice.

2. Graphics are up to par for current gen - the gritty art style compliments the use of the various graphic effects employed. Sound effects are well done.

Overall
recommended: I would only recommend the game if the developers patch the game properly and sell it for about half the price. It's not a half bad game
hoursPlayed: but not worth the current cost."

reviewText:
Liked:
- some new combat mechanics (in regard to Dark Souls) such as shield sprint bash and blocking with shield on back
- level design (highly interconnected, well detailed), especially at the begining (Keystone)
- weapon design (in terms of graphics)
- Worshipper - best designed boss in the game, capable of punishing constant distance playstyle, could inspire DS developers how to make bosses not so easily exploitable through ranged attacks
- lore presentation (audio logs scattered through the world)

Disliked:
- bugs - tons of them, repeatable, often save-breaking
- performance - requirements don't match visuals or game mechanics, I can't find any reason for this game to require so much horsepower other that lack of developers' talent or nvidia influence to push for physx and their crap
- save system - especially painful with crap code quality in mind, continuous auto save system from DS would help here greatly
- unskippable cutscenes / dialogs
- combat - frustrating with heavy weapons, long windup and even slower weapon movement (who would swing so slowly with heavy weapon IRL?) makes for great imbalance vs most of enemies who can attack without almost any notice
- crafting - there is no crafting system, there is socketing system with about 4 types of runes (fire/magic/poison/scaling),
some weapons don't have any socket, don't have a clue why
- progression system - especially regarding weapons, this is not DS, where virtually any weapon can bring you through whole game, here you have to put points in stat of your choice (str/fth/agi), preferably only one per playthrough, to pass stat requirement for better weapons
- enemies - some bosses lack cooldown windows and require (to my knowledge, didn't use any help) cheap tactis such as ranged attacks and poison
- 1st playthrough length - about 17 hours, too little for me considering some farming was done and backtracking (no travel system)
- replayability - low, I could not force myself to play it again with this amount of bugs,

I could recommend it only if it was patched and for a tenner or so.

reviewText:
Warning: If you do not enjoy games like the Souls series, do not buy this game.

Lords Of The Fallen has been compared to the Souls series, containing a slow tactical approach to close-quarters combat gameplay, with difficult enemies and locations to overcome.

In this game, you will control a hero called Harkyn. He is a warrior with a mysterious past ready to confront an army of demons. He was release from jail by a mysterious man called Kaslo. Kaslo gives Harkyn an opportunity for him to redeem for his crimes in a mission to save the realm dominated by demons.

The gameplay is really good and easy to learn. I strongly recommend to play it with a controller, otherwise, the game can be harder to play. The game uses a risk and reward" system. The amount of experience the player can gain for use can be increased through a multiplier that builds up the longer the player mixes up combo attacks or avoids using checkpoints and spending their experiences.

The cons that I have about this game are about the cutscenes and the camera. They could have putted more effort in the cutscenes to be more natural. Sometimes the dialog and the movements of the characters do not match

reviewText:
Lords of the Fallen, oh how I really wanted to like you. A new 'Souls-esque' game to enter the struggle. I had an open mind, wasn't one of these naysayers that were judging the gameplay prior to launch. A fresh take on the souls series was a welcome thing in my eyes. The competition and innovation in gameplay and structure could help shape future souls games.

I love the enemies and the bosses I encountered.
The 'soul patch' system was fresh and unique.
The weapons and armor all had real weight to them. Batting an enemy, or being batted by one across the map was awesome.
Lighting and particle effects were cool.
Oh and almost forgot, the environments are truly great.


I truly was excited to play this game. And after 7hrs put into this, and only reaching the 4th boss due to crashing to desktop, wall bugs, glitches, terrain bugs, sound bugging out and hitbox issues....I'm going to have to put this game down until the devs can fix this technical disaster.

1 week after launch and I'm thumbing this game down. I'm hoping it'll work as intended in the future so I can revisit it.


edit:
1 day after I write this review, the game got patched. Fingers crossed it fixes my issues.

reviewText:
Dark Souls Lite: Prepare to Crash Edition

Pros:
-Looks pretty
-A slightly more forgiving soulslike, generally (see cheesy enemy types below)
-Interesting leveling/loot system in theory
-Combat feels weighty, if a bit slow

Cons:
-Crashes frequently
-Some enemy types are walking blocks of cheese, and the best way to deal with them is with even more cheese (hurr durr shield charge)
-Game heavily leans toward a str/heavy/turtle playstyle (hurr durr shield charge)
-Said shield charge is wonky as hell, leaving you standing there next to an enemy with your ♥♥♥♥ in your hand half the time
-Crashes frequently
-Combat and movement feels a bit slow/sluggish for a soulslike
-Annoying leveling/loot system in practice
-Save system was recently nerfed, compounding the annoyance of the leveling/loot system
-Terrible voice acting and writing (though kind of expected tbh)
-Did I mention this game crashes frequently?

I really wanted to like this game, but it was quite disappointing.  If you can find it in the $10-15 range, I'd say it's worth giving it a shot if you're into the Souls games, otherwise you might want to just pass.  It's hard to justify spending more than that with the frequent crashes, lack of MP, and relatively short playtime (10-20 hours), though there is ng+ if you're a glutton for punishment.  I will give this game another shot down the road probably, and hopefully most of the issues and kinks will have been worked out by then.

reviewText:
Played between 3 and 4 hours as of writing, spent about an hour in the rhogar realm.

Seems to me to be a relatively poor b-movie equivalent of dark souls. If I'm not fighting hordes of enemies that never lower their shields, I'm fighting the poor, corridor-based level design, the abysmal inventory system, the confusing item switching system, the laughable dialogue or the non-existant story.

It's quite a clunky game. Often you'll fight enemies with shields. Shield bash them, or kick their shield, and they'll lower their shield. For about a second. There is no time, even with some of the faster weapons, to follow up with an attack. It's as if Lords took the Dark Souls combat system but forgot to tune it based on their enemies.

As for story, there are quite a few side characters about, that all seem to care greatly what's going on. Even the playable character, Harkyn, seems to care what is going on. But I can't for the life of me give a single solitary damn, becuase I have no idea where, who, what I am, why I'm doing it, who I'm doing it with... You're just not given any of that information, so it's rather hard to empathise with any of the 2-dimensional characters.

The animations are stiff, in dialogue especially. Dialogue sounds like it was recorded somewhere that wasn't a recording studio, and that the VAs weren't really fully immersed.

And after my good 3-4 hour excursion, I've met cumutavely a total of between 5 and 7 different enemy types. There's undead hollow thing, smaller undead thing with sword and shield, bigger undead thing with sword and shield, bigger undead thing 2handing, fat undead thing with a crossbow... It's not the most creative game. Sure, the skyboxes can be pretty if you can make it out behind all that lens flare, but I'm a bit tired of snowy castles and towers.

It can be quite entertaining. quite. I've found myself thinking it's like dark souls but with the darksiders aesthetic and lack of fun.

In no way could I recommend this for it's RRP. I grabbed this on sale for roughly £12, and to be perfectly honest, at the moment that's about the maximum I'd tell someone to buy it for.

reviewText:
For a game that certainly tries to be Dark Souls, Lords of the Fallen is a good example of why a game like Dark Souls is to hard to pull off. There are so many small things that this game does worse than the former, and it makes the entire thing feel much worse for it.

First, the camera is like being followed by a helicopter with Parkinson's disease. It goes from uncomfortably shaky in large, open areas, to almost laughably ridiculous in smaller, tighter spaces.

Second, the combat. While a game like Dark Souls is more punishing than trying to fist a bear, it was always...ALWAYS fair. I can count on one hand the amount of times I died in Dark Souls and felt it wasn't completely my fault. In Lords of the Fallen, however, I died a dozen times in just the first area, and while I initially chalked it up to my learning the mechanics of the game, it soon became clear that this game is much, much harsher and even less fair when it comes to combat.

While the idea of a bulkier, heavier Dark Souls sounds like an awesome game, this is not that game. It all looks very pretty, but it fails to live up to the standards of the game it so obviously is trying to be. This game is trying to stand on the shoulders of a giant like the Souls series, only to realize that it has no legs.

This can all be summed up in an experience I had while trying to fight the second boss of the game. After dying maybe ten, fifteen times to the thing, I finally endured the nearly half-hour boss fight, had finally withered it down to the last fractions of it's health...and the game crashed on me.

2/10

Would not buy again

(also, it bears mentioning that game difficulty itself is not an issue for me [please refer to the 200 hours I've spent on Dark Souls], it is when a game is difficult without also being fair that I take issue)
voteText: 19 of 36 people (53%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Well, it didn't crash, as others have had issues with. My issues reside in the general feel of the game.

It's a pretty short game, offering much less of a challenge than your typical Souls game. Very few bosses, very few varying enemy types, and a hell of a lot of snow.

Music is ok, not bad at all really, but I suffered from a bug in which dying on a boss stopped its music from playing for its first phase, making it more frustrating than enjoyable to re-fight.

Combat, I personally went a strengh build, but any weapon that wasn't a one handed axe or sword attacked FAR too slow to be useful. Even stacking tonnes of poise and the heaviest armour, if you get hit out of a wind-up for your attack (as with large enemies and bosses) your attack is worthless and wasted stamina, resulting in rather crappy fights even with your standard enemy. Enemies also have a habit of, upon being blocked by a shield, reset to standing and ready to attack animation, meaning right after attacking, they recoil, jold back into idle, then attack again, all relatively quickly. Same happens if you shield bash a few enemies and hit them while they're recoiling, upon landing your strike they jolt back up to idle (even if they were on the damn floor ragdoll-ing) and are immediately ready to attack you, which the AI will. It's buggy, and while I see the appeal of a clunky, heavy sort of combat system, the game needs A LOT of polishing to make it better (and that's ignoring all the bugs).

The checkpoint and experience system is interesting, and actually the best feature of this game IMO. If you don't rest at a checkpoint (restoring up to 3 potions and all your hp, while saving progress) then you keep an experience multiplier you gain per enemy kill, offering eventually up to a total of 2x the experience for killing an enemy. It is a fair system, and I can't see it hindering any Souls-type game.

The look of the game isn't bad. Armour is nicely designed, but that's about the best looking thing you'll get. Bosses are ok. Areas are pretty lacking in diversity, and all look relatively boring. There is TOO MUCH snow, which'd have been fixed by probably having the game take longer than 10 hours to complete, with a total of 5 different areas to go and crap plot that says go back here because I said so"

The challenge rooms and bonus portals aren't challenging at all

reviewText:
Lords of the Pauldron.

In all seriousness, it's alright I guess.

Absolutely terrible worldbuilding/story/characters. Combat mechanics are promising but have flaws with a lot of cheap and unpredictable enemy AI that prevent total enjoyment.

Commendable attempt at non-linear level design, which is unfortunately derailed by environments that look too similar to one another and preventing players from learning a level's layout.

The overall pacing of the game is absolute dogshit, and easily it's worst flaw. This gets more evident later on in the game.

One example - a hard boss fight is placed immediately after another hard boss fight. You are physically locked away from the rest of the world and the player has no chance to mentally rest and recuperate by down-tempo exploration gameplay before being flung against another wall.

I would be lying if I said I didn't enjoy my time with the game, but the flaws eventually added up and left me with a very sour taste in my mouth.

It might be worth looking at, but not at full price.

reviewText:
In Short:
Game is fun for the most part. The combat takes some getting used to because it is far more sluggish/slow than those who are used to the souls series. It's a pretty neat looking ascetic overall in my opinion, but the high fantasy style that seems similar to World of Warcraft, Diablo 3, or Darksiders series is getting a bit over used. The story is nothing special, but not bad either. There's a lot of lore to find, but it's told to you in scrolls and cutscenes and such, not like the Souls series where you find items and piece the lore together yourself.

There are some nit picking problems like I don't find the jump mechanic and various areas to get some loot and require a jump any fun, just frustrating, but those small issues don't detract enough from the game's over all joy. The only big problem are the crashes. As of October 30th, the game crashes way too easily and often. For those who don't have an Nvidia to do that fix" (which doesn't work for everyone) you're pretty much screwed until they patch it. The other issue is the frame drops which are fairly frequent (doesn't seem optimized). I'd wholly recommend it immediately if not for the crashes and frame drops. For now

reviewText: Fun, challenging, and top notch visuals. My GTX 760 could not hold the frame rates and I had to compromise on the graphic settings. Replay value is short, there are speed runs of this game that are under 2 hours. I got this game on sale and it was worth it.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Things I liked:
- great visuals
- great sound
- awesome gameplay (supports different play styles)
- can be challenging at times
- promotes aggressive style of play
- encourages storytelling

Things I didn't like:
- bad storytelling (no hints on why is something happening). Actually NG+ allows a better understanding of the story
- sometimes bad voice acting
- cutscenes are overshadowed by the gameplay itself

If you like action RPGs, and you like Dark Souls, you are up for a treat.

P.S. I didn't suffer from framerate drops or crashes. I played the game on two computers: laptop with i7 and GeForce 880M, and on desktop with i5 and R9 270X. The game played perfectly on both machines.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is a very fun (and pretty looking) action/rpg similar to Dark Souls (as you may be able to tell from the screenshots).
While some have found this to be a buggy game, I played it with few bugs encountered (and those that I did find were not game-breaking). I feel strongly that this game is much better on PC than Dark Souls is, I was able to complete it with keyboard and mouse (not possible with Dark Souls).

Although the game is said to be 18 hours long, it took me over 28 to complete. Maybe I'm slower than others (or worse).

Still, in the end, this is a really good game. I enjoyed it a lot and would recommend it to any PC gamer looking for a high fedelity Dark Souls experience.

A+
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Let me start off by saying that Lords of the Fallen is a great game.

The graphics are amazing and the experience is even further enhanced by impressively gritty sound effects. The combat is weighty and more complex than you may think based on whatever youtube videos or live streams you have seen. There are numerous ways to cut up your enemies, be it with an axe, sword, mace or even a bloody polesword. Combining light and heavy attacks has varying results, which is complimented by dodging and sprinting attacks.

Now, there are a couple important points I'd like to make, first regarding the claims of extreme game-breaking bugs and the second to its comparison to the Dark Souls franchise.

The bugs: After its release I am sure this game had numerous game breaking bugs; however I purchased the game recently and have only experienced a couple minor bugs that were fixed in a minute. I've had only had to restart the game once to fix a bug and that was because I was assumed a setting change that I had done would only work when restarting the game and it did. I am now about 10 hours into the game, 5 bosses down and have not have ONE crash. NOT ONE. So people, please start buying this game and get stuck in !

Even better is its pause mechanic, which comes into play when minimizing. I have a fairly powerful gaming laptop (Lenovo Y510p), but some games do overheat such as this. When it gets hot, however, the game simply minimizes instead of crashes and when it does it PAUSES. So i have never died from an unwanted minimize.

NOW - DARK SOULS...................... I can't believe the publics reaction to it being like dark souls. As someone who has beated Dark Souls and Dark Souls 2 I can easily say that this game is a treat. Yes they are similar, but that's a good thing. Lords is merely inspired by the game and it really does differ greatly. Yes it has that timing-orientated combat, the powerful monster enemies and the bosses that can crush you. But it is not Dark Souls and varies greatly. It does include some aspects of Darksiders (although I never thought I'd admit this) in terms of graphics and the fact that in Dark Souls your aim is to not get hit and its pretty easy, but in Lords of the Fallen sometimes the best strategy is to take a few hits while jumping axe swinging into the enemey because you know thats his biggest opening (the tower shield guys)

First, the good:

The ability to pause in game to either the home screen or your inventory. At first I thought this was a bit too much as it was something I had come to appreciate when playing Dark Souls, but then I realized how insanely irritating it was to not be able to pause in Dark Souls.

Combat is powerful, complex, weighty and rewarding.

Amazing current-gen graphics

Great music and sound effects

Intricately designed areas and world

Bosses that are definitely fun and well thought out

Labyrinthian Diablo like dungeons

Cut scenese with customizable dialouge and last hit kill" cutscenes
date:
which I felt were a niceish touch

Each weapon has a unique and sick backstab action

The bad:

The bosses are sometimes too easy (e.g worshipper was great. Infiltrator was boring)

Some bugs

Maybe not enough 'outside' play
recommended:
but there is some and its awesome.

I have to go now though so i rushed this but ya BUY THIS GAME! :)

Where Dark Souls says "prepare to die" Lords of the Fallen says "prepare to get a lost and go crazy in a labyrinth" which to me is great because Souls 2 didnt have nearly enough castle gameplay and in Lords you get fully submerged in the depths and dungeons of medievil Cidatels



"
