reviewText:
(Note about me: I have played through Dark Souls 1 (162 hours played so far) and played a bit of Dark Souls 2 (43 hours played so far) as well.)

I was really looking forward to this game, because I really like the Dark Souls style of games and combat, but rarely you see combat that's like that. So most likely I am biased towards a game like this.

Gameplay
Combat

The combat is rather similar to Dark Souls, especially when it comes to melee weapons, but there are still differences. The melee combat felt as satisfying to me as in Dark Souls, so I would say it was pretty good.

A big difference would be that there are no changeable ranged weapons. You only get your gauntlet near the start of the game and that's it. The gauntlet functions as a mix of a ranged weapon and also spell weapon as it drains your mana and isn't just simple projectile shooter weapon like a bow would be. It has 3 different modes, that are quite different from each other, and later on in the game you'll get the ability to further customize and change how the gauntlet works in each of the modes. Meaning that you aren't just changing the stats of the weapon, but rather you are changing what the projectiles do. (e.g. making a projectile attrack enemy attention, drain life, knockback enemies, etc.)

On the other hand there is a lot of melee weapons, but as you soon find out (especially after you get to socket runes into them), many of them are obsolete compared to other weapons. The only redeeming factor for the weapons might be their moveset, which can matter a lot to some people, but to me it wasn't enough of a tradeoff when I could be doing significantly more damage with the other weapon. So in the end I was finding that I had at max 4 viable weapons for myself when I played with a really heavily str focused build.

Another significant difference is that there is no way to be a mage like you could be in other games. There are no spells that do damage on their own, rather they usually support your combat skills or weaken the enemy, etc. The gauntlet might be able to compensate for that, but I'm not sure it would be enough. Especially because when the few times I tried how viable it would be to use it on its own, I found out that the shots consume too much mana and don't deal enough damage. This however might not be such a bad thing, because at least from my experience fighting ranged or with spells in a souls game (in pve at least) makes the game much more easier and less fun because you no longer have to get up close and have to be so careful when you attack near them because they could countera-attack you.

One thing I really missed though is the lack of PvP. Fighting others can be pretty fun in a game like this and it can create a lot of tension if you have a lot of souls on you at the time, but nothing like that can be found in this game. It was probably a conscious choice on the dev's part, but I think it could be more fun with it.

I noticed a really big problem with the armors in this game. Later in the game when I had a decent amount of strength, I could equip the best and heaviest armor without any penalty and it made the game far too easy in my experience. Bosses were still difficult, but normal enemies did between 1/5th and 1/10th of what they did to me before, which was such a big decreese in damage that I stopped caring about getting damaged, because I could do that without being punished (even if I got hit). Not sure if this is a problem with how much points I put into strength or what, but it made the game less enjoyable and too easy in my experience.

Enemies

The enemies looked interesting at first, but after a while I got bored of the Rhogar all looking the same and being pretty much the only enemies with few exceptions. The enemy variety got better near the end of the game with new enemies being introduced, so I wouldn't say it was that bad overall.

The cast of enemies certainly had some interesting enemies, for example the most fragile enemy can't see, so you can easily avoid them if you want to or ambush them.

I think the bosses were great, much better than in pretty much any game including Dark Souls. Many of them had interesting mechanics tied to them or were somewhat different depending on how much health they had and apart from 1 bossfight you never had to fight multi-boss bossfight. And even that bossfight wasn't that bad because every once in a while one of them removed themselves from the fight, so you had to deal with only one of them at a time most of the time.

Overall most melee enemies had big sweeping attacks that can also easily turn around or hit you when you are behind enemies, so you had to either roll to dodge or block, which I found a bit dissapointing, because I like being able to dodge enemies just with the right positioning and movement, but that wasn't possible.

Story
The story seemed interesting, but I didn't pay that much mind to it and I think I missed important parts of it, so can't give a good opinion on it.

One thing I really didn't like on the story though is how one big important choice was presented in the game. It was rather contrived and felt forced, because how the choice was made, made it look like it's just a choice for how to use something given to you, that doesn't even affect how you will be able to use it after you select one of the choices, and yet it seems that choice chooses which one of the 3 endings you'll get.

The way it was given to you was more direct way than in Dark Souls. There are many cutscenes and conversations with characters, but also part of the story is conveyed through the environment and through scrolls that you pick up.

Setting

I found the setting interesting and I wouldn't mind exploring it more. Unfortunately, the game forced you to revisit old areas with new enemies, especially at the end of the game, instead of new areas, which was kinda dissapointing, because I wouldn't mind exploring more areas.

None of the areas came out as cohersive wholes and even though some of them looked rather nice, it often felt like they made a nice area and then randomly placed random minions there. Dark Souls in comparison has areas that have enemies in them that make sense for the areas, for example a lower area of one of the earlier areas you find yourself in is full of old houses that seem abandoned and damaged and the enemies in the area are lightly armored enemies with daggers that try to ambush you and work in groups.

Conclusion
I think the game is really good, especially if you like the way Dark Souls combat works, but note that the game is much shorter than Dark Souls and besides the combat it's not like Dark Souls and if you don't mind that then I would recommend it.

reviewText: At first I was very dissapointed with this game(becouse of lags and crashes, and boring start of game), but after patches, I've managed to overcome first 1-2 hours of game and I've noticed that I really WANT to play this game(feeling that I have not experienced for long time). The graphics are very good, design of armors and weapons is awesome, much better than in any fantasy RPG I ever saw. Gameplay and controls are similar to Dark Souls, but for me it was much easier to play this game (don't know why). Also unlike DS this game has story which is big advantage for me. The game is interesting to play and explore. The disadvantages are: still quite poor optimization (few times I experienced lags and there still were 2 crashes for a single walkthrough) and shortness (the game is very short - about 6-8 hours for me).

reviewText: I waited for this game ever since it was first announced. It looked great! Stunning visuals and it came at a time when I had just finished Dark Souls 2 and its dlc's so it was a great transition.\n\nI waited a couple of days after release before I got the game as I wanted to gauge the general feeling. I noticed that a lot of people were slagging the game off because it was trying" to be dark souls. Being a genre defining game its understandable that any subsequent games in that genre will be compared but that doesnt give people right to slag it off just because it's not a good. Anyway
date: mini rant over.\n\nThis game is very good. The graphics are stunning. At first I thought they were a littke blurry but I realised that it was just part of the art style. The combat is great. More aggressive than dark souls. Some of the regular enemies can be as difficult to get past as some bosses. In general
recommended:
the game is relatively easy. There are a few hard spots that took a while to get that rhythm.  Nearly all the boss fights I finished on the first try with only 4 fights taking a couple more.

The story was largely a mystery until halfway through and some if the characters seemed randomly placed. Quests were unmarked and there was even a point where I had managed to face the 5th boss before I had found the 4th.

The magic was largely redundant. I only ever used one spell. Granted
hoursPlayed: I've only used the warrior spell tree so there could be others that would be useful. The magic gauntlet that is in the game seems just like an excuse to have something like a gun. Again

column17:
I would give the game a solid 7/10.
Pros;
- Gorgeous graphics with a awesome setting
- Well done combat with good balancing
- The armour sets are badass
- Bosses are inventive
- Plenty of back story in the form of well done audio logs

Cons;
- The story was good but the delivery could have been better. Often spent time wondering what was going on purely because of poor scripting.
- Gaps in said story
- Some boss battles too easy"

reviewText:
Should you try this game? Yes. Is it like Dark Souls? Sort of. (TL;DR at the end)
Before I start:Many people had problems with the performance, I started to play after patch 1.4 and everything was fine, no crashes, stable framerate.
First of all the grapchics are great and the combat is pretty solid, animations look realistic but sometimes you can just stick close to an enemy and avoid getting hit. Regular enemies can get hard to kill because the window between their lowered guard is little, so if you have a greatsword you may have a hard time dealing with them.
Game is also more forgiving in my opinion, if you are afraid of rolling you can go with a heavy armor that can absorb a lot of damage. The third boss got me becaus I was using Dark Souls techniques and tried rolling away but still getting hit, so I equiped the heaviest gear and tanked the boss and it actually worked.
There are 10 bosses, some are hard some are easy especially if you figure out their attack pattern. But the world has a lot of hidden treasures that you can try and find.
If you manage to beat all the bosses in the first attempt and not get stuck and lost for a long time you can complete the game in 10-12 hours.

IN CONCLUSION
If there is a sale on this game and you like Dark Souls type games, give it a go, I don't think you will regret it.

I noticed a really big problem with the armors in this game. Later in the game when I had a decent amount of strength, I could equip the best and heaviest armor without any penalty and it made the game far too easy in my experience. Bosses were still difficult, but normal enemies did between 1/5th and 1/10th of what they did to me before, which was such a big decreese in damage that I stopped caring about getting damaged, because I could do that without being punished (even if I got hit). Not sure if this is a problem with how much points I put into strength or what, but it made the game less enjoyable and too easy in my experience.

Enemies

The enemies looked interesting at first, but after a while I got bored of the Rhogar all looking the same and being pretty much the only enemies with few exceptions. The enemy variety got better near the end of the game with new enemies being introduced, so I wouldn't say it was that bad overall.

The cast of enemies certainly had some interesting enemies, for example the most fragile enemy can't see, so you can easily avoid them if you want to or ambush them.

I think the bosses were great, much better than in pretty much any game including Dark Souls. Many of them had interesting mechanics tied to them or were somewhat different depending on how much health they had and apart from 1 bossfight you never had to fight multi-boss bossfight. And even that bossfight wasn't that bad because every once in a while one of them removed themselves from the fight, so you had to deal with only one of them at a time most of the time.

Overall most melee enemies had big sweeping attacks that can also easily turn around or hit you when you are behind enemies, so you had to either roll to dodge or block, which I found a bit dissapointing, because I like being able to dodge enemies just with the right positioning and movement, but that wasn't possible.

Story
The story seemed interesting, but I didn't pay that much mind to it and I think I missed important parts of it, so can't give a good opinion on it.

One thing I really didn't like on the story though is how one big important choice was presented in the game. It was rather contrived and felt forced, because how the choice was made, made it look like it's just a choice for how to use something given to you, that doesn't even affect how you will be able to use it after you select one of the choices, and yet it seems that choice chooses which one of the 3 endings you'll get.

The way it was given to you was more direct way than in Dark Souls. There are many cutscenes and conversations with characters, but also part of the story is conveyed through the environment and through scrolls that you pick up.

Setting

I found the setting interesting and I wouldn't mind exploring it more. Unfortunately, the game forced you to revisit old areas with new enemies, especially at the end of the game, instead of new areas, which was kinda dissapointing, because I wouldn't mind exploring more areas.

None of the areas came out as cohersive wholes and even though some of them looked rather nice, it often felt like they made a nice area and then randomly placed random minions there. Dark Souls in comparison has areas that have enemies in them that make sense for the areas, for example a lower area of one of the earlier areas you find yourself in is full of old houses that seem abandoned and damaged and the enemies in the area are lightly armored enemies with daggers that try to ambush you and work in groups.

Conclusion
I think the game is really good, especially if you like the way Dark Souls combat works, but note that the game is much shorter than Dark Souls and besides the combat it's not like Dark Souls and if you don't mind that then I would recommend it.

reviewText:
In short:
It's not worth the £30 I paid for it, bear in mind though, that's not to say it's a bad game, because it ain't.

Graphics:
Beautiful environments (most of the time you get to see dungeons), weather effects (not that many of them, but still a joy to look at them). Absolutely great design of a dark world at the edge of destruction, same goes for the enemies.

Story:
From what I've noticed there's quite a lot of people complaining that it was dull and uninteresting which I'd like to disagree with. It's not among the best ones though, so don't get your hopes too high either.

Gameplay & Difficulty
While I did not continue playing after finishing the game once, I'm pretty sure I have the right to say that this game is nowhere close to being as hard and unforgiving as Dark Souls. Boss battles... some bosses I actually didn't have to dodge or block at all, I entered enraged mode (Warrior Ability - *Rage*) and bashed the b**** to death.
The game got (for me, obviously...) a bit too easy after a few hours of playing, jumping onto my enemies, killing them with one blow.
It took me about (don't look at hours on record, I'm always pausing for long periods of time) 10 to 12 hours to finish the game.
There's quite a lot of equipment which kind of ruins the nice feeling of finding something real powerful. First you find a set of armor, newer, better, so you put runes into it and then boom... you find something better after (not exaggerating) 10 minutes and you redo the whole armor-runing process.

reviewText:
Before I get into the good, I will shortly list the bad points, as there hasn't been too many. Firstly, the game lags unexpectedly in some places and has crashed a couple of times (One resulting in a pc restart, which I thought was odd), and secondly, when replaying the game, the fact that loot isn't randomized can get a little bit boring as you begin to know what is where. However, now that I have that out of the way, I can get onto the good points.

This game is a great alternative if you want a game that plays like Dark Souls, but is a more western style Action-RPG. I love the armour and how bulky everything is, it reminded me, in a way, of the first fable games, with the ridiculously large hammers that you could wield! The classes are nicely varied, and the xp system (getting xp to a checkpoint and getting larger xp modifiers for surviving while holding a large amount of xp) was very satisfying, and felt rewarding when you go on a big monster massacre and actually come out of it alive.

The bosses are all very varied, and if you bother to pick up some of the extra lore, such as audio-thingies, they can be interesting to learn about too! They are all challenging in their own ways and require a certain amount of tactics to beat them. The story line itself is nice, the lip syncing and voice acting was average, but I liked the fact that you have choices in conversations, some of them actually affecting the outcome of certain situations.

Lords of the fallen - 9/10

TL;DR - The game has some performance issues at the moment, and I feel spoilt by randomized loot in other games when I play this, but the armour it gives you is very chunky and makes your character look like a boss. Speaking of bosses, they are varied and fun to beat, the story is also pretty good so far!

reviewText:
Lords of the Fallen is a beautiful game that feels like a mix between the gameplay of Dark Souls, the loot from Darksiders and the aestetics from a Blizzard game. The movement and the combat feels very responsive and the flow is very natural with each of your swings with your weapon. This game does a good job at showing off great animation, especially when you land your blows on the enemies and stagger them. The controls are easy to learn, though you can't re-bind your keys for either keyboard or controller. There are how ever, two control settings from which you can select; if the original controler scheme should not meet your standards. The game does a good job at delivering the story to you and it doesn't forcefully do so either. Every dialogue is skippable, should the story not meet your fancy. Unfortunately, the gameplay isn't very challenging and there are no settings to change the difficulity. The video options are also very lacking and should you not use an Nvidia Video Card (Graphic Card) you won't be very pleased that the game has a running PhysX that you can't toggle on and off; Making the game run awfully bad for those that do not have support for PhysX. The camera can be a bit off from time to time, but the game generally does a good job at making sure you know what's going on around you.

I would recommend this game to anyone that enjoys a third person fantasy-based RPG. If you're into Dark Souls, you might want to have a look at the game for a casual playthrough if anything.

As of the time I'm writing this review, I'm 6 hours into the game and have not yet died a single time.

reviewText:

If youre looking for a hack'n'slash this is probably not it. It requires some tactics but if you have played DS you will know what you are dealing with, although everyting in this games seems heavier".

All in all a great an gorgeous experience. 4.5/5"

reviewText:
Just finished my first playthrough. Here's a quick summary of what I think after those first 16.5 hours,

Pros
- Great boss battles, both fun and challenging, rarely feels unfair
- Gorgeous artwork, very consistent
- Solid combat mechanics (VERY similar to the Souls games) if you die it was probably your fault, if you're stuck try respec'ing

Cons
- The odd non-critical bug (eg. invisible collision in a doorway, bugged NPC audio, broken dialogue tree)
- Very low quality writing and voice performances; the game would have been much better if all friendly NPCs and audio logs had just been removed

reviewText:
A technically inferior, but shinier Dark Souls.

I'll put it simply, the game's fun, and it looks great, but there's a few things that irritate me and not in the way that Dark Souls irritates you because it's difficult.

This game is difficult because of the choices made in some game mechanics, as well as small bugs that turn into big problems.

One such bug is enemies turning around to instantly face you if you manage to flank them, completely negating the tactic in the first place. I'm talking about the no-animation, teleport-y kind of turning around, allowing them to immediately attack you again without giving you an opening to attack them without being hit yourself.

It's also too easy to get stunlocked to death by groups of enemies. Sure, it's more realistic" if one knock to the ground can immediately mean your death due to multiple enemies being able to still attack/hurt you when you're in a helpless position
date: but it's not at all fun
recommended: or indeed fair. If you die in Dark Souls
hoursPlayed: you know it's your fault
voteText: and you know what you can do to prevent it from happening next time. Further to the point

reviewText:
I had never heard of this game, just bought it on impulse because it looked so good.  Best buy I've done all year, so far I've had 40+ hours of pure RPG action madness fun.

The game has a very steep learning curve. and is damn hard in the start but once you master your character and understand the xp system & save system & weight system; it's fantastic.  Hope these guys make more.   I see some people complain about bugs, I haven't seen anything in 40+ hours playtime that I don't see in every other game out there.

Be prepared to die a lot the first 5-6 hours, be prepared to figure things out, nothing is explained properly and the manual is total crap so you need to try things or do research, it's just the way it is.  Take it as a challenge, don't whine about it.  Once you get proper control and figure out when to use what weapons, stances, etc you're gonna have a blast.

Graphics 12/10
Gameplay 9/10
Sound ??/10  (spotify, find some manowar)
Story -10.000.000/10 (but who gives a ♥♥♥♥, really)
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A technically inferior, but shinier Dark Souls.

I'll put it simply, the game's fun, and it looks great, but there's a few things that irritate me and not in the way that Dark Souls irritates you because it's difficult.

This game is difficult because of the choices made in some game mechanics, as well as small bugs that turn into big problems.

One such bug is enemies turning around to instantly face you if you manage to flank them, completely negating the tactic in the first place. I'm talking about the no-animation, teleport-y kind of turning around, allowing them to immediately attack you again without giving you an opening to attack them without being hit yourself.

It's also too easy to get stunlocked to death by groups of enemies. Sure, it's more realistic" if one knock to the ground can immediately mean your death due to multiple enemies being able to still attack/hurt you when you're in a helpless position
date: but it's not at all fun
recommended: or indeed fair. If you die in Dark Souls
hoursPlayed: you know it's your fault
voteText: and you know what you can do to prevent it from happening next time. Further to the point
helpfulPercent: if you get swarmed by a group
votesHelpful: your first instinct would be to retreat and take them on in a more tactical sense
votesTotal: right? In LotF it only takes a nudge for you to get stunlocked enough to suddenly get surrounded
votesFunny: and then you're done for
commentsCount: as there are no i-frames when rolling.\n\nIn LotF
column16: you're forced to play tanky and take hits
column17: as going the light route is simply a massive handicap
column18: due to dodging not being as refined as in Dark Souls. So a lot of the time it's luck as to whether you're going to win a fight or not
column19: or whether the enemy you're fighting is going to poise straight through your well-timed heavy and land you on your ♥♥♥ for a grizzly death. So a lot of the time you're relying on your health and defense in order to survive such things
column20: and hopefully dole out more damage to them than they can to you.\n\nDespite this
column21: I would recommend LotF
column22: just don't expect to be able to play like you can in Dark Souls
column23: and don't expect the kind of well-crafted mechanics or indeed interesting lore/characters that Dark Souls is known for. Play tanky
column24: get mad when faced with ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t
column25: have fun when not."

What I wold have liked to see in the game is a little more enemy variety in terms of tactics. Both for the regular baddies and for bosses as half way through the game I found myself just jump-bashing most enemies which got a little repetitive despite being quite fun.
The mages provided a little variety (especially spirits) causing me to actually swap weapons but that was basically it.

The bosses played out pretty much  similarly as well
helpfulPercent:
just wait for the boss to pull off an attack with the longest cool down and strike him a few times and then retreat (repeat until dead). So little adjustments there would come a long way.

The story as such is pretty straight forward with a few alternative endings. I did like the ending but would have liked to see some more meaningful choices in the game and reflections of those choices in the end. But for an action RPG this is fine.

In total

reviewText:
EPIC GAME!!!!
The combat system is amazing, every piece of gear looks awesome right from the start, the score has a very Diablo II sound to it, graphics are top notch and the boss fights are intense!

Since the graphics and effects are so stunning, I had hoped for some more interesting looking armour later on but I finished it without finding anything jaw-dropping. Playing it through a second time now, might loot something more interesting this time round, I hope!

I only have a few complaints:
Bad story telling. A lot of decissions in the game I wasn't aware I made because they weren't explained clearly and there were times I wasn't sure what was going on, for instance (warning, spoilers in this blocked out text): The opening scene which I still don't fully understand even after finishing the game. Is it meant to be a flash back? Whats up with the hammer? Is it Harkyn or someone else? The giant demon who I thought was a fallen lord that vanishes with Yetka, what was that all about!?? And after the talk with Adyr you return to the citadel only to be attacked by the human soldiers, calling you a traitor for no reason. This is later explained a bit by picking up a scroll, but only after hacking through a small army of good guys you don't want to kill. And the mountain in the opening and at the end, what is it supposed to be and why did it break/fall apart?

Extremely light crafting system. It would have been awesome if the crafting sytem let you craft gear instead of just unlocking runes and socketing gear, the smith looks more than capable. You can't combine lower quality runes to make better ones, but maybe this was intentional to keep the flawless runes a rare thing.

Luck stat/drop modifier doesn't seem to work. It just increases the frequency of rubbish dropping, doesn't increase the quality of drops.
Having said that though, I still highly recommend this game! :)
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game looked very promising but it lacked a better story progression and script.

On the Pro side:

Good graphics.
Interesting design of the characters and enemies, including boss battles.
More friendly to the gamer than Dark Souls.
An original fighting system.
An accomplished world layout.

On the Cons Side:

Poorly optimized.
Is boring some times.
The story lacks depth and more background development of the caracters.
Small world not able to explore it.
Voice acting is terrible.
Other characters are there just for nothing, they dont add anything to the story.

I have to say is a game that had a lot of potential but lacked the most important element: A good story and background development of the characters. Maybe for a sequel they will get this and other details more polished and achieve a great game, but for now is only this.

5/10 Mediocre game, get it on sale only if you like this tipe of game, like dark souls but with less content and difficulty.

reviewText:
It took a lot of work to make this game run, but at long last I have made the dam thing work.

I've played it for a fair few hours now and I honestly enjoy it. It has the aesthetics I believe look downright delicious. I still believe it was a bad workmanship that the game has had such a damming amount of issues on release, but at least it seems they are indeed working on these issues unlike so many other developers.

Though the story is, in my honest opinion, very poorly portrayed by a rather stale character of Harken (his emotional mindset seems to be stuck on 'meh'). The cutscenes could have been far better too, but none the less it is still entertaining to play.

The 3 character archetypes are nice (I have chosen warrior myself) and its superb you are not limited to using gear but will be penalised for not having the right build for it (endurence 12 for example) is fair in my opinion. Gear feels like it matters and I like that.


All in all I recommend if your interested, check out some gameplay videos before making a verdict but if you like it, then yea I'd say money well spent.

reviewText: Don't let your decision wether to buy this game be influenced by the Mixed" status of the user reviews. Most of the bad reviews are not actually about the game

I and many others can play this game without any problems. It's just that customers who are content with a product are much less likely to write a review about it than discontent ones. I just wanted to bring a little balance to that.\n\nThe game is often accused of being a Dark Souls ripoff. That's not entirely false
recommended: but it doesn't really cover what this game is. Lords of the Fallens approach to combat is basically copied from Dark Souls with a few subtle differences you will only notice after playing for a while ... and why not? Hardly any game did combat as good as Dark Souls did. And that's where the similarities end. The level design

reviewText:
Lords of the fallen is a great game if you like harder arpgs where your attacks are a commitment, and timing is important. Lords of the fallen is trying to make an entry into the same genre as Dark Souls, with a lot of similarities,
but also some cool differences.
I have more than 600 hours in Dark souls 1 and 2. Lords of the Fallen has fun bosses, weapons, armor, and the labyrinth DLC adds a fun puzzle. As a dark souls 1 and 2 onebro, I actually think doing a level 10 LOTF run would be harder, if you are worried it will be too easy of a game, Please support this game when it is on sale, and allow for the rest of the world to enter the HCARPG market without a unwarranted fear of failure. EDIT: I did a lvl 10 run, and it was challenging, but not as much as I thought, but still very fun.

Pros
+ Great graphics
+ Different builds play and feel different, add replayability
+ You feel like a badass, but a mortal badass
+ Combat is always fair, you should only die to an enemy once if you can learn.
+ Bosses have interesting mechanics (not all but most)

Cons
- lots of people complain of crashes (not me)
- World is large, and well made, but only consists of a few kinds of environments
- Some combat is forced in small corridors and the camera makes this hard to see what you are doing (only a couple spots)
- No multiplayer at all (Dark souls multiplayer is wierd, someone make a co-op game like this please)
- Story has a canned ending with a narrator telling very similar stories. (Still better than ME3 ending)
- Magic is basically a cannon with only a few good moves you can use to cheese the game

TLDR;  Dark Soulslike. Good game, but not for everyone.  Give it a chance if you like that kind of combat.

reviewText:
When you want to clone a successful game you have to follow 2 rules:

- Don't change the core formula that made that game successful in the first place.
- Add something that makes your clone unique without hurting the core formula.

Unfortunately the guys behind this game decided not to follow the first rule and the second rule is pretty uninspired. The main problem of this game is centered in the character gameplay, it's slow, it's clunky, the shake on the camara view is annoying and it's slow... yeah, I said slow twice because it is god damn slow.

Visually the game looks good and the theme is attractive but gameplay kills it for me. I could force myself to adapt to the gameplay and learn to enjoy it but that makes no sense having better games out there.

reviewText:
This game was clearly inspired by Dark Souls and Demon Souls, however it falls short on trying to replicate the gameplay in many ways. In many ways it takes on from Dark Souls 2 rather than Dark Souls 1, which in my opinion is a bad thing.

Pros -
* Great graphics.
* Game flows decently if kind of slowly.
* Voice acting is spot on.
* Weapons are pretty neat, if you can actually use them.

Cons -
* All weapons are slow. Save perhaps for daggers and smaller weapons, anything bigger than a stick takes a good second to swing regardless of whether it's a normal version or a great (large) version.
* It's rather unfair at times. Took me probably an hour just to beat the first boss because he simply turtled the entire time and I was stuck with a one-handed hammer that took a second to swing each time I tried to attack. Keep in mind I JUST STARTED.
* The game offers little to no information on anything without you having to dig through menues. I get that I should look at more information on weapons if I want to really minmax or something, but I was using a weapon I couldn't actually weild without even realizing I didn't have the stat requirement. It's extremely confusing and trying to look at things with more information is a pain in the ♥♥♥.

Overall the game seems like it had potential, but with the combination of it trying to be Dark/Demon souls with it's difficulty" it just doesn't work. If you like Dark Souls or are looking for a tough game to kick your ♥♥♥ for your mistakes
date: look elsewhere.\n\nEdit: This game can be summed up as Fan-Made-Dark/Demon-Souls. They wanted to make a game like it
recommended: but didn't know what made it so great or at least how to replicate it."

reviewText:
Adds some interesting things to the Souls type game. Combat is, well, plodding is the best term I can think of, especially early on. It doesn't have the mysterious feel of the world like you get in a Souls game. Lack of multiplayer seems like it will hurt replayability, though the light/medium/heavy combat styles with the three flavors of magic are different enough they may be worth trying out.

I do have an issue, as other's have mentioned, with the attack window. The larger enemies are too adept at bringing up their shield and spinning around, and so the opportunity to attack feels really small, and can get frustating at times.

A number of people have had crashing issue, but I have yet to see one. Runs fine on high with my R9 270X.

Overall, it's a worthy effort and there is fun to be had, but it may be one to wait for a sale.

reviewText: first and foremost if you want to play the genre but arnt ready for dark souls this is a good starting place. It has all the elements of the dark souls series except ranged weapons, which in my opinion was good as range often made dark souls much easier, so this is kind of forced melee learning if you arnt used to it. this game is as advertised, its an easier dark souls game. This game also simplifies a lot of the dark souls non-combat mechanics such as weapons and armors dont get upgrades, but instead they have runes that can be unsocketed and resocketed as many times as you want. experience is also simplified as  you can dump all your xp at save points so that you dont drop it on death. now for my negatives about it... the game itself crashed on me 5 times, causing me to redo things (such as bosses). almost all of the bosses had some gimmick that you needed to learn in order to beat them making bosses and the occasional ledge the only ways i died. after i finished the game i looked at how other people beat some of those bosses, and apparently i missed 75% of the health potions in the game(and i still beat the game without dying more than twice to the same boss). due to gimmicks there were a few bosses that didnt feel like bosses, but instead just enemies with extra health. this game is short, if i didnt have to redo parts due to crashes my playthrough would have been about 10 hours, however if you are new the the genre this could be much longer. i also have a few issues with the combat, mainly about shields. In the souls series you can attack immediately after a block, and enemies follow the same rules as the player. In this game however there is a lag between blocking and attacking, but the enemies dont follow this rule leading to shield enemies blocking your attacks then immediately attacking you back. In dark souls 2 they addressed this problem by replacing the kick with a shield break attack, however even though this game is mechanically similar to dark souls they didnt add it in. Due to all the sheild enemies and the sheild mechanics not working the same for the player i ended up just 2 handing  weapons with lots of poise. This poise allowed me to take a hit or two while i bashed on their shield a few times causing them to recoil which allowed me to actually hit them. I didnt do any backtracking or farming, nor did i look anything up, and i say this because early on i felt like my weapons were way too weak. finding a good weapon really made a huge difference. i complain about this because you are supposed to have a choice with weapons. In dark souls weapons are a preference based on your attributes, but two weapons of the same type will do similar damage, however in this game i got a sword off the first boss and compared to the sword i ended with it dealt five times less damage. the weapons dont appear to be balanced off stats, but rather where you are in the game which allows enemies to scale poorly. the enemies in one area might die in one hit, while the enemies in another area might die in ten hits. the armors in the game also scaled weirdly as large jumps in poise and armor wernt matched with large jumps in weight. there were some medium armors that after being socketed were just better than heavy armor found in the same area. the game give you a gauntet to cast ranged shots at the cost of mana, but i found that after i got a ranged class spell i pretty much stopped using it as the class spell was just hands down better. lastly there were times that enemies attacked or shot through walls leading to taking extra that i wasnt expecting. i might play through this game again, but im going to wait a while and see if they fix the crashing bugs and some of the attacking through walls bugs. so if you havent bought this game yet, but want to eventually, wait for it to go on sale at a later time, minimally after the crashing bugs have been fixed.

reviewText:
This game was clearly inspired by Dark Souls and Demon Souls, however it falls short on trying to replicate the gameplay in many ways. In many ways it takes on from Dark Souls 2 rather than Dark Souls 1, which in my opinion is a bad thing.

Pros -
* Great graphics.
* Game flows decently if kind of slowly.
* Voice acting is spot on.
* Weapons are pretty neat, if you can actually use them.

Cons -
* All weapons are slow. Save perhaps for daggers and smaller weapons, anything bigger than a stick takes a good second to swing regardless of whether it's a normal version or a great (large) version.
* It's rather unfair at times. Took me probably an hour just to beat the first boss because he simply turtled the entire time and I was stuck with a one-handed hammer that took a second to swing each time I tried to attack. Keep in mind I JUST STARTED.
* The game offers little to no information on anything without you having to dig through menues. I get that I should look at more information on weapons if I want to really minmax or something, but I was using a weapon I couldn't actually weild without even realizing I didn't have the stat requirement. It's extremely confusing and trying to look at things with more information is a pain in the ♥♥♥.

Overall the game seems like it had potential, but with the combination of it trying to be Dark/Demon souls with it's difficulty" it just doesn't work. If you like Dark Souls or are looking for a tough game to kick your ♥♥♥ for your mistakes
date: look elsewhere.\n\nEdit: This game can be summed up as Fan-Made-Dark/Demon-Souls. They wanted to make a game like it
recommended: but didn't know what made it so great or at least how to replicate it."

reviewText:
If this game goes on sale for 20-30$ i would say pick it up but as a full price package this game is frustrating (for the wrong reasons). Yes, it is pretty short but problem is the replay value really isn't worth while for couple extra items. I could go on and on but ill just make a quick pro/con list to speed it up.

I only ran as a Heavy armored/Sword and shield spec with cleric spells. I tried other styles and didnt care for em.
Pros-
Very pretty graphics through out.
Kinda a pro and con fact that a shield spec heavy armored run only seemed helpful for bosses which is nice but really crappy against some of the later enemies in the game forcing me to switch to a 2 hander for them which i didn't care for 2 handed weapons in game at all.

Cons-
Most of the shield enemies are very annoying due to fact its a good 70% shield enemies that like to turtle slows down the game alot.
Spells...... for love of god they take so long to cast it almost renders them useless when really really need them most.
The bosses are incredibly lame and simple even the last boss i killed on a 2nd attempt due to lame OP power he spams on you when sitting there thinking wtf is he doing.
Story is very standard. None of the extra characters are fleshed that you help and main character is pretty cookie cutter kick ♥♥♥ take names later affair.
More of a personal issue to me but Weapon variety seemed very low. Either greatsword this greataxe that couple swords and daggers with some hammers thrown in. Took while to find a 1 handed str sword which was the style i liked rather then slower heavy weapons.

Overall if they get a sequel i would like to see what they bring to it but wait for this to be on sale.

reviewText:
I'm torn between recommending this game, or not.
Pros:
- Incredibly gorgeous graphics.
-Optimized amazingly.  I don't have the BEST graphics card, but I had it maxed out and stayed at 60fps all the time.
-The armor and art style in this game are incredible.  Absolutely beautiful backdrops and awesome armor.
-Pretty solid gameplay, Definitely provides one hell of a challenge.

Cons:
-The combat is annoying ONLY because you get animation locked during attacks.  Literally everytime I died or got hit is because once you click attack it literally takes like 3 seconds to swing a big axe.  In that time as you're winding up (unable to cancel and dodge) you will get WRECKED by npcs.
- Difficulty.  Yes, this is a baby to Dark Souls and a lot of people REALLY enjoy the challenge, but dang... I got stuck on the fourth boss and just COULD NOT beat it because of the animation locks, inability to dodge etc and it just got to the point where it went from a great challenge, to screw it i don't care anymore.
-LAUGHABLE voice acting/mouth animations.  Holy cow.  So cliche and it's like the game was made for the korean language or something because the mouth movements don't really match what's being said.

In the end, if you want a really beautiful game and a dark souls type experience, this is a great game, but sometimes the animation locks alone made me rage quit.  Once you get to a certain level however, the game DOES get a bit easier, both due to better gear and finally learning attack patterns etc.  I definitely had fun even if the story and voice acting is a little funky.

Bit of advice:  Cast your prayer where they attack your double and just kill things from behind them if you're stuck!

reviewText:
No, it's not as good as dark souls... But the reason you are here is because you like Dark Souls combat and progression.
This implements something similar to Dark Souls 1's combat and progression system, but personally, I think they've actually done a better job with it.

Also, I think the bosses I've encountered so far have been brilliantly designed.  They don't look interesting at first glance, but actually fighting each one takes a completely unique stratagy that you have to figure out as you go, which is really quite satisfying.

So, if that is all you want, get it.

HOWEVER, if you want the rish story and varied vistas of darksouls... well you're not going to get it.

IMPORTANT NOTE: While you may be able to run this game at max settings using your current CPU and GPU, I'd take a look at your RAM.  This game eats up a lot of it.  I recommend 16GB for max settings and 8GB for min to avoid thrashing.  At 8GB on max graphics, it was clear my CPU and GPU were fine, but every now and then It would freeze for a bit.  which indicated that something was being transfered to/from the disk.  After checking the the tsk manager, I found that I was using nearly 7GB of the 8 on my computer.  Since then I have upgraded my RAM to 16GB, and it runs at a smooth 60fps now.

The level design is pretty good, and IMO is better than Dark Souls 2's level design. However, level design is not the same as the visual design.  Some people don't like the visual design since there isn't a ton of definition, but I think it's fine that way.  It just means you can't play with your eye's closed. Overall, that is pretty much the theme of the game.  Stay alert.

reviewText:
I've had people ask me for a review on this game, and so here you are. I currently have 40 hours on the game. The review will go in order as Gameplay, Features and Story, Environment & NPCs. Scroll down to the final paragraph if you want to skip the lengthy text.

GameplayNo character customization is available in LotF, instead you play as Harkyn, a sturdy man with facial hair and a bald head. You have a selection of 3 different magic classes and then 3 different builds, ultimately giving 9 choices if you look at it that way. Magic classes each have 3 unique abilities that you can unlock and use throughout the game, as well as a fourth ability that is the same for each class, called Prayer, which creates a statue that your enemies will attack. Your build choice simply affects what stats you start with and what weapon/armour you face the first boss with. The magic classes are as follows:

Solace, or better known as cleric, the slower and middle-grounded of the three.    Shelter gives you increased defense and slowly regenerates your health.
Daze slows and lowers the defence of enemies around you, a very useful ability against mobs that hide behind a shield.
Punishment returns enemy attacks by stunning and dealing damage back to them.Deception, or better known as rogue, is the stealthy single-target magic class. My personal favourite.    Mimic creates a phase of you that copies everything you do, making it that each attack hits twice for a certain amount of time.
Stab sends a phase sprinting towards your targetted enemy and deals damage to them, best used as a finisher imo.
Shift makes Harkyn become invisible and silent for a period of time, increasing your movement speed. His next attack, unless a backstab, will deal a large amount of damage and bring him out of stealth.Brawler magic class, or better known as warrior. The brute of the three.    Rage increases your attack power and damage as well as removing energy restrictions.
Ram sends a charging force through your enemy, staggering or knocking them down while dealing a small amount of damage.
Quake is a close ranged ability that creates a huge hammer to slam down in front of you, devestating any enemies near you.When you use an ability, it shares a cooldown with every other ability, meaning you cannot use two at once. You have to choose which ability is best to use at that moment, and then wait for your cooldown or mana to regenerate. Once you choose a class, you cannot change this throughout the game, but when you reach NG+ you are able to choose a second class to master the abilities of. I chose rogue, and then warrior on NG+, and of course cleric on NG++, ultimately getting every ability in the game.

The combat is clunkier" than Dark Souls combat
date: as you may of already heard. Rolling is a little slower but still fairly easy to learn. Blocking is an effective mechanic
recommended: too. There isn't much to fault it with it's just not quite as exhilarating as Dark Souls
hoursPlayed: doesn't have as steep of a learning curve and severe difficulty. I died on one or two bosses a few times
voteText: but overall didn't find the game too difficult.\n\nThere are different weapons such as staves

but nothing very memorable. NPCs are average at best.


TL;DRWell

You take the role of 3 classes, and then 3 subclasses fighting challenging enemies either up close, or from afar with various spells. This is mostly a melee game though with very limited ranged fighting abilities. The bosses are not much harder than the regular mobs, meaning the regular mobs are challenging in their own right.\n\nI recommend this game if you are a fan of challenging action rpgs. Its also a must-get if you're a Souls Fan.

reviewText:
Not worth the time. The game, 2 months after launch still crashes and has obnoxious camera angles and sway. The performance is still all over the place. The game additionally is flawed, since you can charge and charge ANY enemy over and over and never take hits while doing almost significant damage. Ever. (Shield)

*EVER*

This is a dumbed down, buggy unpolished sloppy attempt at recreating a souls esque game. It is not a challenge for a souls player (beat ALL bosses first try, if it didn't crash getting there, and like Souls 2 the bosses were pretty repetitive.) The crashing wouldn't be such an issue if it saved in near realtime like souls, but NO. It is checkpoint based. You killed all those enemies and your game crashes? Oh, well do it. Again. And again. And..

I had 1 crash per hour and PhysX was off. The performance, HOLY ♥♥♥ the performance. This game is running on 30-70fps ON A GTX 970 OCd at 1080p. Do you see a problem there? Top tier card, bottom tier performance. Hmmm. Combat is satisfying when the camera isn't jerking all around the place artificially. There is additionally a lot of routes you can take when deciding what weapons you will use.

If the issues were gone, I would say the game is enjoyable if you are looking for a short (10 hour short) RPG with very little mechanics and decisions (completely linear besides exploring) easier souls like game. MEH quality game, AAA hype.

reviewText:
Take Dark souls 1, slow it down at least 3x times, overdesign the ever living heck out of it, pretty it up and done you get lords of the fallen.

Performance personally for me has been fine, however it does suffer from ocesional stutter, no the denuvo drm does not damage your ssd.

Now for gameplay, its incredibly slow, heavy and impactful, enemies tend to get annoying as the combat is extreamly slow, this is especially true with bosses, they take ages to kill not because of their health or armor...but because how slow the game actually is, the dialog is flimsy and poorly written but who botheres with that in this type of games. the game lacks creativity as most enemies are just dudes in very detailed shiny armor swinging big sparky weapons, sure it might get old but i personally enjoyed it. however i must mention the game looks fantastic if you can handle it.

I wish there was something like neutral, but i am giving it thumbs up, personally i am enjoying it, i can recommend it on sale for people who ran out of dark souls to play and need something to get their void filled in.

reviewText:
Not a bad game, anyone who has played dark souls or demon souls will get a bit of fun from it, but may find it below what you would expect in terms of difficulty. For example I found myself killing a boss I was supposivbly meant to leave till later on.

The gameplay is solid, giving you an idea of some of the things dark souls could have done, the perfect timing system with swings to reward not button mashing, the magic isnt intrusive on combat and isnt a automatic win and enemies are both fun and can be unpredicatble.

The problems being no enemies are really memorable including bosses, a lot just involve either jus the dodge-hit strategy with little deviation from their 2-3 moves, or out cheaping them, for example on boss who will spam a fire attack you wont be able to dodge really all that well, so you have to spam fire resistance items to really win just in case you get hit once.

The Rune system is interesting, but could use more work, its really hardly worth your time exept for the gauntlet.

The characters are really needing work, I came out of dark souls and really felt terrible for some chars, even my enemies fates. In this I really couldnt care less about any of the supporting cast or the main character, there is really nothing worth noting about them, you have: obvious villain"

reviewText:
After having beat the game, I believe I can offer my two cents

Lords of the Fallen is a game similar to the Dark Souls franchise in mechanics, but lacking the charm of the Dark Souls

- I never got the feeling any of my choices had an impact
- None of the character's are all too memorable
- The story is very confusing
- The environments all get very boring, very quick
- There's no real exploration, you'll eventually reach your desination by killing enemies
- The enemies and bosses are all very generic (Fight humanoid enemy with a sword #5)

So, why do I still recommend this game? Because, there are little things here and there that make me love it.

+ The armor sets all look gorgeous
+ It's insanely fun to play as a tank and smash your enemies to pieces with a warhammer
+ There are little snippets of dialogue here and there that furthered my interest in the world
+ While I never fully understood why Harkyn was so important, I definitely liked him and wanted him to succeed.
+ I got ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off at certain characters and wanted to kick their ♥♥♥♥ in, something most games haven't acomplished.

All in all, I'd give Lords of the fallen a 7.5/10. It's worth picking up if you want something to play similar to Dark Souls, or just want a good RPG to play.

reviewText: As a huge fan of the Souls series, I was delighted when I heard of this game. It seemed very good to start with, but as I got deeper into the game a number of problems arose. The first was the numerous bugs, with random sounds playing for no reason, fps drops, and even the game crashing rarely, which forced me to do a whole lot of work due to save points instead of auto save every few seconds like other games. In addition to that, there are a slew of other things I take issue with, such as the outright bizzare enemy hitboxes, the ridiculous difficulty it takes to wield a heavy weapon effectively (especially against enemies with shields, they'll get their guard broken and then have it back up before you can actually get a swing in on them), and a number of times I was trapped in a corner by various bosses, causing me to lose the boss fight and start over.\n\nOverall, a very good idea, but I would not recommend this game due to it's poor execution and massive array of bugs. It feels like a very good Beta, but it's not a Beta, it's a full game.

reviewText:
I could say a lot about this game, but I'll try to keep it short. Souls fans will definitely enjoy this game. While borrowing a good deal from the success of Souls games, Lords of the Fallen has enough to define it as an entirely seperate game.

Combat feels heavier, and much more similar to Dark Souls than Dark Souls 2. What it does different from DaS combat is implement magic as a part of every build. The only character customization is essentially choosing a heavy armor tank build, a medium armor cleric build, and a light armor stealth build. The estus flask idea carries on with health potions, which replenish at checkpoints. Players can increase their potion count by finding empty bottles, hidden in hard to reach locations.

The graphics are beautiful, even better than Dark Souls 2. The lighting provides a dark and intense atmosphere without critically hindering visibility, though players will probably find it difficult to spot traps in the dark indoor chambers.

While I won't compare the story to those in the Souls games, the story in Lords of the Fallen is much more direct and is quite good so far. There's a whole tab for discovered lore, for fans who love to delve deeper into a world's history.

And finally, the death system has a few tweaks compared to those of the Souls games. Upon death all carried xp is dropped and players are sent back to the last activated checkpoint. Beyond that, no stats or equipment are affected, although players only have a few minutes to reach their death spot to reclaim their xp, and death before retrieval will result in the loss of any dropped points.

I suppose that wasn't really a short review, oops. All in all, while Lords of the Fallen originates and borrows strongly from the Souls franchise, the game successfully sets itsself apart as more than a clone. Though some elements of combat may be more forgiving, Lords of the Fallen is still every bit as challenging and demanding as any of the Souls games.

reviewText:
This game is fun to play.

However the crashes continue from day of release. There is nothing you can do to prevent them it seems.
Video crashes occur constantly. I have had some success in reducing the crashes by reinstalling video driver if crashes become constant (less than 5 min). I have found if you delete the config files from my documents and the steam folder for LOTF then let the game set the video, I have had the least crashing by leaving settings as is.

If you want evidence of what these crashes cost you I have 77hrs played on steam yet my only save has less than 67hrs. (screenshot is public).

My rig has SLi GTX 780's and no other game has these problems.

The only reason I can figure for leaving the game in this state is making you sit through the 3 advertisement splash screens (that play twice each) while you reload after the crashes.

reviewText:
I was waiting until I finish this game to make a review about it. I was hoping that if I finished the Story it would surprise me but I decided to make the review even before that.
And why? Because this game is not good. Period. I didn't play a lot of Dark Souls to compare it to, but I can recognize a broken game.
I had huge expectations about this game, but now I really regret that I pre-purchased it. It's not worth the price. And I'll probably won't purchase other CI titles.

Some reasons that I don't recommend this game (Warning: Spoiler Alert)

- I lost the count of how many time I was holding the defense button with the shield selected, facing my opponent and with full action bar and, even with all these things right, I ended up receiving damage from my enemies and dying.

- When you're using the gauntlet you can shoot at an enemy holding a huge shield that covers all his body and he'll take damage anyway.

- At the same time, you'll face some archers that will shoot fire arrows at you and, even holding a shield the whole time, you'll take fire damage.

- The enemies (archers specially) can see you from far away and they'll hit you for sure. No matter how far you are.

What else do I have noticed?

The game crashes sometimes.

* Do I have anything good about this game?

Only that the graphics are impressive. But, what good is having great graphics if the game does not work right?

If you have any interest in this game, wait for a huge promotion. That's my advice.

reviewText:
Disclaimer: In 30 hours of inflated gametime, I have experienced two crashes. My sympathy goes out to all who were not as lucky as I was. At the time of writing, I have completed the game as a cleric and I'm wrapping up my NG+1 mode as a Warrior. I had to cut a lot of content for this review because of the word limitation Steam puts on it's user reviews.

++Let's start with the good stuff first. While graphics aren't important anymore in this day and age, because every single game looks gorgeous these days, it must be noted that Lords looks absolutely stellar. Even though my system can barely run it, you can clearly see that there is a lot of hard work that went in almost every single area of the game. The game doesn't look as magnificent like in the screenshots though, but don't let that dissuade you: this game looks superb.

++I liked the compactness of the game world. While every single RPG of the last 8 years is trying to be the next World of WarCraft or Skyrim, Lords keeps it neat and tidy. Lords doesn't have many locations, and, logically, every location in the game looks gorgeous and lavish with detail. They all look like real, believable places. There is no silly padding, no unnecessary: Harkyn! Please kill ten demon hounds and then return here!" questing. There is one main quest
date: about ten side quests and a neatly compacted game world consisting of a handful of locations for you to do them in. If you're great at the game
recommended: you'll just blast past all the content in a matter of a dozen hours and have seen all the locations. But I really like this style of RPG and it's a system I definitely I want to see more of.\n\n++Honorable mentions: Awesome looking armor and weapons. They're a real treat to behold and there's a huge amount of armor and weapons lying around if you look hard enough. The XP system is also a real treat. It allows the unskilled player to grind himself XP
hoursPlayed: plainly making him more powerful versus other enemies

reviewText:
Now, Lord of the fallen is a game i was initially wary about. I'd heard from youtuber Totalbiscuit that this game was horrendously optimized for PC. As it turned out he was right, i vastly exceed the recommended specs for the game (nvidia geforce 770 and 16 gigs of ram to give you an idea) But the game still had horrendous framerate, to the point that it almost froze. I ran a test with fraps to see the numbers, and it was consistently at 30 or dropped below that.

Now, the game itself is very Dark Soul reminiscent, (Both of them being bad PC ports) And handles very much alike it. You control Harkyn, the main protagonist of the game) From a 3rd person perspective. You've got several different playstyles much alike that of the Soul games. But what i found in this game was that there was no way you were ever going to enjoy the game playing your own way.

I started out as a Rogue, because ive always enjoyed sneakily shanking enemies when their backs are turned, and quickly found my ♥♥♥♥ on a plate because there had been no proper explanation of a stealth system, or if one such system even existed.

And then, right after the tutorial fight with the first Rhogar, i had my first crash.

I was ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥♥. I looked at the forum to see if this was a common issue, and indeed this was something that has happened to a lot of people. I then also saw that the forums were infected with the very worst part of both the PC gaming community and the Dark Souls community. So entitled ♥♥♥♥♥♥s saying that anyone who does not own a pc powered by the souls of dead children should have no business playing PC games, and also ♥♥♥♥♥♥ who ramble about you being a noob if you can't find this one single item burried away in a cave somewhere near a cove behind two secret walls, a fire, and a monster the size of the moon.

So i returned, my problem unsolved, when as soon as the Nvidia logo had vanished the game crashed again.

So after i'd gotten myself something to drink, and beat my head against the wall for a few minutes, I booted up the game again and it actually launched. To then find that my save file was gone.


Grumbling and determined not to let this ♥♥♥♥ing game beat me, i started a new file and created myself a Cleric Brawler, cause i decided that if the game was gonna be a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ then so was i. And suddenly the game was an absolute ♥♥♥♥ing cakewalk, i died two times at the first boss and then he was trashed aswell, Despite this i did find myself cursing at ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t momentum cancelling attacks from enemies. This continued until i reached the third boss.

This was where i officially clicked quit game and deleted the damn thing from my PC. ♥♥♥♥ you Lords of the Fallen. Being hard is one thing, but be hard and fair at the same time. A boss that spawns minions that stun lock you and then proceeds to beat you senseless isnt fair, its trying to beat a wall down with your forehead.

So in short, can't recommend, maybe try Dark Souls 2 in stead.

reviewText: Dark Souls had a baby with a WRPG and it came out a little premature. I enjoy some of its design decisions but it's incredibly short (with DLC it took me under 9 hours), and I can only ascribe so much of that to my experience with similar titles. However, it has actual useful kb/m controls, and is a solidly programmed title on this platform, so that's a huge plus over the aforementioned's PC edition.\n\nI'm incredibly fond of its risk/reward mechanic: the longer you go without laying down a save/dying, the higher your XP multiplier becomes. XP functions as currency and level-fodder, but can be gained also via exploration, sidequests (yes! those exist in this!), and a checkpoint" system which lets you choose a new respawn point/effectively quicksave
date: without resetting the multiplier. The multiplier only applies to combat-given XP
hoursPlayed: and it's not like that doesn't make boss encounters more tense as you try to take them out in one so you can turn them from one level up into four.\n\nOther positives: bosses all have a specific kill condition to upgrade their drops (which is hinted at in some of the lore or notes) for further risk/reward and playstyle changes

I only recommend this game if you are willing to die. Possibly a lot. You have to be adaptable if you want to play a rogue. You have to use a shield sometimes whether you want to or not. reviewText:
Runs mostly ok, though does have issues.

Had two CTD's so far.
My magic meter won't fully recharge (I think it's a bug from the greed amulet that I once equipped).

It would seem that the game was designed for the cleric class.
Theif type characters suck because sneaking is broken (no sneak mode, AI has tunnel vision, no indicators if you're in the right position for a sneak attack).
Using a sheild is highly recommended as some enemies are terrible to fight without one, and secret walls need to be sheild bashed.

No map/GPS and quest log make navigation difficult, and sometimes there's no clear direction for what you are meant to be doing which results in hours of wandering.

HOWEVER:
The graphics are highly polished, the environments well designed.
The combat is fun and skill based, though sometimes the game finds it difficult deciding what attack to do when you press a button.
The RPG elements are good, though very basic. Needs proper spell tress and specs.

A sequel that fixes all of this and has about 3 to 4 times the content of this game in all areas would make be epic.

It's a shame that the game is still rough around the edges.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A surprising sleeper hit that punches way above its weight class, but holds its own impressively.

I was surprised by how much the game hooked me. At first I was put off by the Diablo/Warhammer-esque artstyle, but I totally came around on it. The beautiful look of the game is one of its biggest assets (especially after the graphical disappointment of another, similar game. Ahem.)

The gameplay is of course inspired by Dark Souls, but it actually introduces some fresh new ideas like timing-based combos, overcharging attacks and a fun upgrade mechanic where you bet experience to receive better runes.

It's a neat package. Every part and system of the game is a bit smaller than its inspiration, owed to a small development team and tighter budget. But it is a prime example of making the most of limited resources. This game was a really nice surprise.

reviewText: I have finished this game on a debatably medium PC. It has not crashed once on me. The 1.4 patch did wonders, I guess. Otherwise, I found the game to be quite entertaining. It has a small world, yes, but it's filled to the tip, and you'll be backtracking a lot, since some areas open only later in the game. The design is kind of power fantasy, you look like a spiky tank most of the time, and the enemies are grotesque. The combat is clunky, albeit realistic. It focuses on tactical blocking, evading and timing of your hits, and the heavy weapons WILL feel heavy (some of them need two hands to be used, regardless of your strength). It kinda forces you to use all the tools at your disposal, which is a good thing, since it varies the gameplay and forces you to think up strategies on the go. The main story is meh, but you are a criminal and you can totally mess up humanity if you chose one of the three possible endings, so in the end it's fine by my standards.

reviewText:
I was interested in this game since release and finally picked it up during christmas sale of 2014. Dark Souls is one of my all time favorites, so I was ready to ignore negative steam reviews and form my own opinion. The game is highly recommended to every Souls games fan. It is also a nice introduction to these types of games, so if you really wanted to try Souls but wasn't sure it's for you, I'd recommend this game. It's somewhat easier and more friendly, so beginners will have good time playing it.
First of all, it is a sure clon of Souls series games and I can't escape comparing it to them. Combat mechanics is absolutely the same, leveling up and saving is almost the same, the spirit of the Souls is here. But with a nice twists here and there. It is surely more a western game, then japanese for starters. The art and graphics are absolutely gorgeous, UI is fantastic and easy to use (which cannot be said about Souls), every mechanic is nicely explained and you don't need to read dozens of guides just to be able to do basic things. But it doesn't mean the game has no secrets, no. Like every Souls game you will miss a lot on your first playthrough, but that's okay.
The things I would've liked to be improved in Lords Of The Fallen:
- Content and length of the game. I finished it in 16 hours and that's counting some grinding. Locations lack variety, there are disappointing number of bosses and there's no wow" effect like it was in Dark Souls. I hope next installment brings more epic fights in a bizzare locations
- More class variety and leveling up options
- More interesting and engaging NPCs. There were some
date: but nothing to write home about. The only interesting one I think was some dude you had to bring human skulls to\n- No multiplayer options. May be it was too difficult to achieve
recommended: but it would've been nice to at least place some clues for other people.\n\nAnd that's basicly it. Technical side wise the game run nice for me. It crashed only one time and there were couple wierd sound glitches
hoursPlayed: but nothing too bad or gamebreaking. Developers did nice job patching and I didn't encounter too much problems. Of course they should've shiped more polished game
voteText: but they didn't abandoned it

so it's all good.
What I did like about Lords Of The Fallen:
- Magic is more of an addition to the main combat then focus of it. I liked how easy it was to use and how uncomplicated the system was. It's more of a support style magic and I thought it worked great with this type of game
- Design of the world

reviewText:
My personal rating 8/10. I hope you guys enjoy it as much as i did.

Lords of the fallen is a great game. Just like any other on release date it had some issues , few crashes and few frame drops there and there, but overall it is a very good game. I personaly expierenced only 3 crashes in over 19 hours of gameplay, posibly because i played it all maxed out @1920-1080 with a single gtx 970 not even overclocked. I had a stable 60 fps most of the time.

Pros:
Beautiful graphics. not to bash the Dark Souls 2 but man, this game just blows it out of the water, it's really something to look at.Very responsive controls, combat feels fluent. it's always a challange even if you facelower lvl monsters from earlier areas, so you gotta keep your guard up.

Cons:

Possible improvements? i would very much like to have a map in this game, for that matter in any rpg game. It's surprising how in 2014 we still get games which haven't got maps, in my opinion it's just absurd.

reviewText:
Third person action game with mechanics similar to Dark Souls 2.

Graphics:
High end graphics with a lot of indoor areas, however the cut scenes and NPCs are not that great. Also, if you get to close to a wall during a fight you will probably disappear from the screen and take damage from your enemy.
Grade: 8/10

Sound:
SImple ambient music and sounds. Lots of sound reuse and similar sounds that trick you. You think there are more enemies, yet you just killed the last one. You open a chest and the sound tricks you into thinking a enemy is behind you.
Grade: 6/10

Controls:
Copied directly from Dark Souls 2, which is not a bad thing. Right button to lock camera on enemy, L1 to defend, R1 to attack, B for magic, X for items...
Grade: 9/10

Game Story:
Simple story and very straightforward, get ready to do a lot of backtracking and get lost forever indoors at areas that look all alike. Did I mention that I hate games like these not providing us a map? I do hate it.
Grade: 7/10 (yes you lost points for not having a fu... map)

Difficulty:
There are enemies that are harder to beat than bosses, as some require you to find his heart before being able to kill it, others defend like hell and some explode after dying, killing you instantly if you do not retreat. The first boss fights are harder as you are a low level player. After you get to higher levels, the boss fights become a pacience game taking a longer time but easier in the end.
Grade: 8/10

General Grade: 7,5 - 8/10.

If you get this game, you won't regret.

reviewText:
This game... I really just... The game has potential. It does. When the game works well it's pretty fun, and there are some neat mechanics in the game. But it just isn't put together all that well. After one play through nothing really changes and I found myself speeding through content just because I didn't want to listen to it again.

Then there's the added problems of glitches, leveling, and really odd difficulty spikes.

The glitches are said to be improved from where they were originally. I played that game in patch 1.4 and it's still buggy as all get out. At one point the final boss walked through a wall, got stuck. I hit him a couple of times, he telleported, moonwalked for a little bit, and then insta-killed me with lord knows what. That's just one glitch there's plenty more to choose from.

The leveling system in this game is completely broken past the first play through. Once I got to about level 80 I stopped really being able to level through gathering experience. I had to go through all the secrets I already found to pick up attribute shards in order to level up because the experience needed was so high. By the end of my third play through to get one level I would have needed 1.5 million experience off of enemies that give about 2 throusand experience with a full multiplier. That's pretty crazy. I wouldn't mind if it weren't for the last problem.

Difficulty in this game makes no sense. It isn't a hard game, not even close. It's that some enemies are much much stronger than others and it doesn't always make sense. In NG+ and NG++ some of the most annoying enemies for my agility build were the zombies. The trash mobs that are everywhere. Nasty looking guy with a giant shield, no problem. Stupid puss zombie that can't even swing a sword well. Ya that thing will take three times as many hits to take down. Granted it has to do with my using the agility staff with three runes for most of the game and it being mostly poison damage, but even when I switched weapons those things were damage sponges. Then there's the bosses. In NG++ I was to the point where the second to last boss couldn't take off more than 5% of my health bar in an attack. I easily tanked through that fight and all the others. Then I got to the last boss and he damn near one shotted me. It didn't matter what armor I put on he still did it. And by then I couldn't do things like change my build to try different tactics. I was stuck trying to beat this guy when he would kill me that easily. It just felt unfair. Not even challenging, just unfair.

There are positives though. The game is pretty. Well not pretty so much as the graphics are nice on higher settings. And the combat, when it works correctly, is pretty fun. The positives just aren't that great though.

It's tempting to compare the game to Dark Souls, but it's really nothing like that game. This one is more like a game that started out that way and some one just get saying to extreme it up. There's armor in the game? Give him huge pointy shoulder pads with a fist on his chest! There's daggers in the game? Make some that have extra pointy bits and detailing all over the place. Put skulls on shields, put tatoos on the guy's face, put a giant hand in the background! EXTREME!

My first playthrough was fun, and if that's all you want go for it when it's on sale. If you're like me and you want to get all the stuff you might want to look else where. With the above mentioned stuff the experience is frustrating. Not difficult, not at all, just frustrating.
