reviewText:
First off, most of the reviews complaining about the optimization problems are no longer valid. That being said, there is no excuse for games these days especially non-indie titles, to be released as beta feeling as this game was. Unforunately that seems to be just par for the course these days in the industry and I won't let my personal feelings on that matter apply here.

This game is a third person action rpg that uses a similar control set-up to the dark souls games and leveling system, but that is where the similarities really end. You do gain and lose your experience by killing/dying and must go to where you died to retrieve your exp. This exp does start to disappear overtime though, and you're not likely to retrieve most of your exp if you're very far from a checkpoint.

The game's difficulty is not high, and most of the struggles you'll face are at the beginning, and very end of the game. The mid-game seems unbalanced and you will be mowing through most enemies.

The combat is much faster paced than the Souls games and I'd say it's about a mid-ground between that and Darksiders 2's combat. They did an excellent job of making each weapon type feel differently and I feel the physics here surpass the Souls series by far. The staff weapons were incredibly overpowered during the time I played the game due to it's fast attack speed and good scaling damage. This could always be fixed in balance patches or mods however.

The bosses were fairly underwhelming, but there are a good variety of enemy types which take different tactics in order to combat as opposed to the souls series (lock on and circle) method of killing just about everything which detracts from my enjoyment of that particular franchise. There were multiple ways to defeat a few of the bosses, and this allowed you to receieve special equipment upon killing them which I thought was a rather neat addition. Some of the weaker and early bosses become elite enemies that you will fight throughout the game as well, forcing you to adapt your combat style when fighting them as well as a group of lesser enemies at the same time.

There are many collectibles in the game, and while the lore is pretty generic, it's still interesting enough to warrant collecting all the scrolls and finding the secret equipment (which there is a good number of).

The games length was decent, and it could probably be played through 2-3 times in order to play different styles, and colelct the new game + gear, however, new game+ difficulty does not scale nearly fast enough in order for it to be a challenge.

As a final note, I do recommend the game, and while it's not anywhere near perfect, there are some innovative ideas here, and I'd like to see a sequel one day improve on what worked, and change what didn't. This is definitely the best game this particular studio has made to date, and I think they should be supported for adding some creativity to this genre which is pretty much dominated by a single franchise at this point.

reviewText:
I have to say this games has its pros and cons just like any other game but I'll just say what I've noticed and you can decide for yourself if you want to try it or not. As a whole, I recommend it if you can get passed the things that drag it down a bit, I personally am satisfied with my purchase but I'm not jumping for joy over the game because I expected a bit more out of it.

Some things I do like very much is that it has a good solid gameplay to it. The blocking in the game feels like actual blocking where you take no damage (if your energy is high enough to block the incoming attack). The weapon attacks are on the realistic side of the line as well; the heavier the weapon, the slower it swings. Even the dodging feels more realistic which could be good for some gamers and bad for others because you may end up dodging and still getting hit (e.g. the enemy swings at waist height and you dodge, the weapon might still hit you because it was low enough).

The targeting can go both ways in this game, in can be a plus in some cases and a detriment in others, you'll have to decide what you like or dislike about it. The targetting locks on to your enemy of choice and you can swap enemies with a quick tap of your camera controls (Right analog if you use a gamepad) in either direction. The problems I have found with it though is there is no quick way to switch targets if one runs behind you (Which they do as a combat technique). Another issue I have found with it is that you can't target unless you have near full view of the enemy which makes it harder on you when coming through a narrow corridor and, unfortunately, there are invisible objects that can get in your way as well (e.g. I found one enemy standing beside a fire brazier and I couldn't target him even though I could clearly see him).

Energy" is basically stamina. It is consumed by attacks (Both regular and power attacks though power attacks take more

reviewText:
This game is not dark souls, it takes some of the dark souls ideas and game play, makes it easier, simpler and more friendly for casual gamers.

if you are a hard core gamer or one that spent a lot of time on dark souls. this game will not last long as you soon realise what works best and will beat the game in a short period of time.

Mobs do not hit that hard and when you realise how each one moves you will soon take all of them down.

Even though the game offers a few different weapon and armour types, you will find that you go for a mid range weight encoumberment and a mid speed weapon. This is because high speed weapons do next to no damage to mobs/bosses, you will never be able to use a big weapon as they are far to slow also being to heavy ( fatman rolling ) doesnt work.
and it wont take long to realise that rolling is pritty much pointless bar a few mobs and side stepping is faster, you stay on your feet for that back stab kill.

The any mob will kill you aproach to dark souls is not needed to be taken on this game.

But the big downside to this game is there is no real replay worth,
As you can only get items that you havent picked up on your first run so if you explored really well you have already done most things.
Mobs are a little harder to kill as they have more hit points, you know how to kill them and it is so easy you will find that you will go as far as possible without spending exp just for a little bit of risk. so far im just past the 5th boss on the second run through and i havent banked once.

I have put recomended on this game as i have enjoyed playing it, all be that its a little to easy, some times hit reg is a bit dodgy, and there was a few crashes near the end of the game.

But......

if you are not a hardcore gamer, and you havent spent time on either dark souls game. This game is fun it will entertain and will pose a slight challenge to you, looks reasonably good, and after you have done this you might be tempted to really challenge yourself and buy the dark souls games. 10X longer but 10X the challange.

reviewText:
Epicure said that death is an absence of sensation that can't be feared, because when your dead, you're not here anymore to feel it. I suppose Lords of the Fallen defies that paradox, because I felt boredom at a level of near-death experience.

I play for so many years at video game, it never happened to me before that I felt such a boredom fighting that first boss. Sure graphics are supernice. Alright. Pilotwings's on SNES were wonderful too in their time.

It is very tough and punitive. I have never played Dark souls or games alike before. But this is clearly overrated and ten thousand leagues under Skyrim and Fable. There's no concrete plot, and ambiance fades as you try to reach your decreasing XP at each death. That fight seems like keep on repeating the fable of the lion and the gnat, and I suppose the whole game is of that stuff. There is more thrill at beginning a 1000 pages book, for you'll not be to reread a thousand times the same pages.

That clearly ain't worth the price, pows. Unless you're fan of the Darksouls-like genre.

reviewText:
This game... I really just... The game has potential. It does. When the game works well it's pretty fun, and there are some neat mechanics in the game. But it just isn't put together all that well. After one play through nothing really changes and I found myself speeding through content just because I didn't want to listen to it again.

Then there's the added problems of glitches, leveling, and really odd difficulty spikes.

The glitches are said to be improved from where they were originally. I played that game in patch 1.4 and it's still buggy as all get out. At one point the final boss walked through a wall, got stuck. I hit him a couple of times, he telleported, moonwalked for a little bit, and then insta-killed me with lord knows what. That's just one glitch there's plenty more to choose from.

The leveling system in this game is completely broken past the first play through. Once I got to about level 80 I stopped really being able to level through gathering experience. I had to go through all the secrets I already found to pick up attribute shards in order to level up because the experience needed was so high. By the end of my third play through to get one level I would have needed 1.5 million experience off of enemies that give about 2 throusand experience with a full multiplier. That's pretty crazy. I wouldn't mind if it weren't for the last problem.

Difficulty in this game makes no sense. It isn't a hard game, not even close. It's that some enemies are much much stronger than others and it doesn't always make sense. In NG+ and NG++ some of the most annoying enemies for my agility build were the zombies. The trash mobs that are everywhere. Nasty looking guy with a giant shield, no problem. Stupid puss zombie that can't even swing a sword well. Ya that thing will take three times as many hits to take down. Granted it has to do with my using the agility staff with three runes for most of the game and it being mostly poison damage, but even when I switched weapons those things were damage sponges. Then there's the bosses. In NG++ I was to the point where the second to last boss couldn't take off more than 5% of my health bar in an attack. I easily tanked through that fight and all the others. Then I got to the last boss and he damn near one shotted me. It didn't matter what armor I put on he still did it. And by then I couldn't do things like change my build to try different tactics. I was stuck trying to beat this guy when he would kill me that easily. It just felt unfair. Not even challenging, just unfair.

There are positives though. The game is pretty. Well not pretty so much as the graphics are nice on higher settings. And the combat, when it works correctly, is pretty fun. The positives just aren't that great though.

It's tempting to compare the game to Dark Souls, but it's really nothing like that game. This one is more like a game that started out that way and some one just get saying to extreme it up. There's armor in the game? Give him huge pointy shoulder pads with a fist on his chest! There's daggers in the game? Make some that have extra pointy bits and detailing all over the place. Put skulls on shields, put tatoos on the guy's face, put a giant hand in the background! EXTREME!

My first playthrough was fun, and if that's all you want go for it when it's on sale. If you're like me and you want to get all the stuff you might want to look else where. With the above mentioned stuff the experience is frustrating. Not difficult, not at all, just frustrating.

reviewText:
I beat this game just now, and am thinking of writing a reveiw. Overall, I would give a 6.5 out of 10 for this game.

If you have never played a similar genre before (like Dark Souls) , I recommend you pick this game up, as the first time  into such this game genre is definitely mindblowing; besides this game theoretically is 'lighter' than dark souls hence should be more 'friendly' to new player. This is generally true from my own experience.

However if you are a veteran from the Souls series, don't expect too much from it. The reasons are listed below:

0. combat-mechanics: the combat mechanics in this game genre is always entertaining. The credit however should go to the original Souls series.

1. Story-wise:  the plot of lords of the fallen is really lousy. Actually I prefer to say there is no story at all. The hero is a rather stale character. The final cutscene is lousy as well.

2. Mobs: only a handful type of mobs exist int the game . Some of the mobs has disgusting mechanics that makes  fighting with them feels more like chore than fun. Besides, most of the mobs are humanoids (Roghars) that lacks the disctinct feel as the enemies in dark souls. Another thing is, I think the designers have overly exploited some of the game mechanics, such as defense with a shield. In this game, there are simply too many mobs bearing shield playing turtle with you from start to the end.

3. Boss fight:  The difficulty of Boss fight is not much challenging for a venteran. but may prove a bit challenging for a newbie. Genreally the design of the bosses is ok, but but Some bosses have really ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ mechanics, including: many bosses bears shield, and too many of them summon minions during the fight, including the final boss. As said before, when these things are overly exploited by the developers, the boss fight does not feel distinct and some times feels annoying.

4. Map and level design: All the stages feels similar and everywhere looks the same color. And you really can get lost in those convoluted tunnels, especially in the 3rd scene. Yes you can argue that throughout the game Harkyn actually fight with a rather limited area,  but it doesn't justify the lack of creativily in level design of this game. This level of similarity makes the player extremely hard to find his/her way and sometimes get frustrated, it is good that the developers everntually release the maps online for free. But then it lost the whole point of the distinctive feature of this game genre: gaming without a map.  As it for the treasure chests, the mechanics is not that attractive as well: many chests are locked and requires a key to open when you initially find them, and sometimes the key has to be dropped randomly from the mobs you kill. Most of the time, by the time you got the key, you either already forgot where the orignal chest was or you are too annoyed to bother going back fighting through all the respawning mobs for a chest that may yield some crap.

5. Graphics: the engine they pick make the graphic looks good, but you have to have a relatively high-spec PC I'm afraid. In my case, I am playing on a middle-end gaming laptop I picked up mid-year 2013, which has 8G RAM and nVidia GT650M (2G graphic mem).  I can hardly play this game on 1600x900 resolution with a reasonable framerate. And We all know a good game is not always about graphics.

6. Bugs:  there are a lot of bugs ever since this game is released. Many of those are game-breaking. It's good that the developers tried to fix some of these by releasing patches, however, it is really unfortunate that up until now,  which is literally the start of a new year (Jan 2nd 2015), some of the game-breaking glitches are still left hanging around. For example, a glitched trinket may cause your mana become a negative value and never regenerate.

Generally speaking, Lords of the fallen a moderate piece of work, not too shabby, and not that fascinating. You can kill 30 hrs with it.

Stupid crashes. Patch fixed. I played this game a lot, don't know why. Maybe because fighting isn't clunky and frustrating as ♥♥♥♥ compared to Souls. Your choices just change the ending cinematic and gives you achievements (yay achievements!), and some of your choices can actually ♥♥♥♥ you (not cutting the dude's arm and helping him with potion will not let you get super potions near the end of the game). New Game + Is like Souls except we don't get new monsters, but we do get new lore (the lore is infinitely better than the game's main story). Also, not ALL monsters will get strong with the NG+ so you will get very confused most of the time, and will get one-shot without realzing. Warrior is easy as ♥♥♥♥, if you play this game as warrior you will have the worst experience, unless you don't upgrade your Faith for the absurd spells. Rogue gives the best experience, even though the i-frames are a joke. Cleric is fun as heck. You will have the worst time ever at the final battle, if you went full faith without using the gauntlet.

reviewText: While not leaving as strong an impact as Dark Souls did years ago, Lords of the Fallen has the same great Dark Souls combat, a brooding atmosphere, and truly spectacularly challenging boss fights. The only downside is the forgettable story and characters, but those are of little importance when the combat is weighty, precise, and rewarding. And being a single player game, you can't rely on that online co-operative crutch that can make Dark Souls boss fights incredibly trivial.\n\nMaybe a little too expensive to recommend at full price, but before you just pass it off as a Dark Souls rip-off, I implore you to give it a proper look. Because even if it has similarities, Lords of the Fallen is very much its own harrowing beast.

reviewText:
Background

At first i have to say, i own Dark souls I and II, and played boath games for more than 100+ hours. After I heared about this game, i was quit hyped and decided to give this game a go. I am german, but i try to write this review in english. If you find mistakes you are free to keep them ;)


Graphic

This games lookes really good. The armor and weapons look really cool. The enemys and enviroments are designed well and this game sets you up for its dark and grim world. But this game has a huge downside. This game runs really bad on most of the systems. I had to set all settings to medium, but can run Battlefield 4 on Ultra without problems.


Sound

The ingame sound suits the game well. The enemys you hear when you go through dungeons, the swing of heavy weapons, its really executed well. BUT the voicacting in this game is really bad. Most of the characters sound like they do not care about their situation at all. They fail to sell you the dark and grim situation they are in. Your maincharacter should not be part of this game, and also does not really care about the things happening around him

Story and Playtime

The Story really falls flat. Its the basic: The world is getting invaded and you are the only one to save it story. I stopped to care about the story quit early. You can read iteam descritions and listen to the NPCs you meet along the way. But there is not much lore behind the game, you really care about (there is a lot to read, but most of it falls short to games like Dark souls).
The playtime of the game is really short! When you are send out to kill the final bosses you have played for like 8-10 hours. I also did a lot of sidemissions and explored a lot. But thits game just feels short. You have dungeons you can explore that are more interesting than the main story, but eventually you will end up doing the main mission.

Gameplay

The good:
+ Weapons are balanced around their size. Daggers can be used to place fast hits in between your enemys attacks, and heavy swords need a setup time.
+ Easy to learn, hard to master. If you are new to games like this, you will go for the tank approch using heavy armor and a shild. You can also use light gear and try to parry enemy attacks and use your mobility to fight them
+ Risk reward mechanic. You can save your XP, or push on through the game trying to increase your multiplier. This gives you the chance to get more XP and better loot. Or to loose it all

The bad:
-The bosses. Most of the bosses(not all!) are really boring. The difficulty is mostly increased when they summon additions minions, which is really cheap. Attack patterns mostly focus in one direction, so after you doge the first hit, the boss continues to attack in the wrong direction. I killed most bosses on the first try without any problem.
- The lock on system. Its a JOKE! Most of the time the game will randomly lock on to an enmy infront of you no matter if another enemy (e.g. boss!) is directly infront of you

In review

This game is not perfect. The bosses are mostly push-overs and only some stand out. The gameplay itself is solid. You can challange yourself to play in a certain styl, that will increase the difficulty. I can not denie the fact, liking the game while playing it. If you are unsure, you can wait for the sale to pick it up.

This game gets a 7,5/10 for me. Solid but can be improved :)

reviewText:
This game cannot avoid being compared to the Souls series. So I'll split this review into two parts, first I'll describe it for those, who's not familiar with Souls games, the second part will be a comparison between LOTF and DS1+2

1. If you've never ever played Souls series, this part is for you.

LOTF is a strictly single player game where you most of the time you fight with enemies and spend the rest on rare cinematics, dialogs and playing around with your stats and equipment. Imagine a Diablo game with direct control over a character and you'll get the feeling of what this game consists of. Right, this is a melee-oriented action game, not an RPG.

A good news here is that the action part is great. It's not a Devil May Cry or Castlevania madness of endless combos and dashes, the fight here is much slower, but also more realistic. It requires (mostly) less reaction, but more thinking. The strategy depends greatly on a build you create (which can be changed relatively easy mid-game), but mostly relies on managing stamina and timings. Controls are good and the battles are satisfying. If not, just try another battle style, you can switch whenever you want.

Some claim this game to be hardcore. What this means in this game, is that generally your build and gear do not limit you much, though having higher stats and better equipment definitely helps. You can beat any situation you meet with anything you have. That's great. But the thing is that each time you meet something new it'll try to make you invent a new tactics to overcome it. Bosses have different mechanics. Regular enemies get new weapons with different movesets and defense tools, locations change from corridors to labyrinths, etc. If you can't beat something, you just need to make a stop and ask yourself a question How should I adapt to this using my resources?" The game is quite balanced in this aspect
date: even though it's not obvious from the first glance.\n\nThis lead to the next aspect - punishment. The game is planned in a way to kill you. Each time you meet a new type of enemy you could die due to your old tactics not working. Each new boss requires some new strategy to take on him
recommended: sometimes you'll not be able to adopt from the first attempt
hoursPlayed: etc. You'll die
voteText: and you'll loose some of the experience that you've gathered lately
helpfulPercent: and the mobs will respawn. Other than that you don't loose anything at all
votesHelpful: so that small piece of experience doesn't matter
votesTotal: you'll get it again from the same mobs.  The point is if something killed you
votesFunny: learn how to avoid it next time and then go kill it yourself. This is a point of the game.\n\nStory wise
commentsCount: it's average. It's enough to explain nicely why you go somewhere killing something

reviewText:
GOOD:
- The combat feels Dark Souls style, and it's pretty challenging, so if you wanted more Dark Souls, you should try this game.
- The story is interesting, though it's not as detailed as the devs promised it to be.
- Lots of different weapons and armor, and overall good loot will keep you interested in the game.
- It's good for you if you like Darksiders. You'll find lots of similar moods and design decisions in this game.
- Graphics are great. It's not Crysis 3, but lights and particle effects look stunning. Character models are also good.

BAD:
- PC version's optimization is AWFUL. Frequent crashes (especially last few hours of the game), FPS drops on the high-end PCs, and so on.
- Camera's behavior is really odd sometimes.
- Although Dark Souls style, combat is very slow. You may find yourself annoyed by how slow Harkyn's moves are. Especially his rolls.
- Locations often feel repetitive.
- Bosses aren't impressive, they're mostly humanoid, and bossfights are not as satisfying as they should be.
- Rogue style of playthrough is much more difficult than Warrior.
- The game's too short, I've completed it in 13 hours.
- Characters' lip-syncing looks incredibly stupid, lips' moves and voices don't match at all.

VERDICT
I liked the game, and I think it has lots of potential. However, first of all, the devs need to fix the PC version's issues (as I've heard, PS4 version has lots of bugs too) for the game to be playable and enjoyable. I'll be clearly doing a second run as a rogue or warrior after the game is fixed! I'm looking forward to that. As for now, the game is good, but it's not as good as I wanted it to be. And it's definitely not better than Dark Souls or Darksiders.

RATING: 68/100. The game is good. Just good, that's it.

If you want to read the thoroughly detailed version of this review, please visit:
http://alessusreviews.blogspot.com/2014/10/review-1-long-awaited-piece-of-art.html#more

- No pure magic character builds and the magic is included is a little lacking

reviewText:
I have to say this games has its pros and cons just like any other game but I'll just say what I've noticed and you can decide for yourself if you want to try it or not. As a whole, I recommend it if you can get passed the things that drag it down a bit, I personally am satisfied with my purchase but I'm not jumping for joy over the game because I expected a bit more out of it.

Some things I do like very much is that it has a good solid gameplay to it. The blocking in the game feels like actual blocking where you take no damage (if your energy is high enough to block the incoming attack). The weapon attacks are on the realistic side of the line as well; the heavier the weapon, the slower it swings. Even the dodging feels more realistic which could be good for some gamers and bad for others because you may end up dodging and still getting hit (e.g. the enemy swings at waist height and you dodge, the weapon might still hit you because it was low enough).

The targeting can go both ways in this game, in can be a plus in some cases and a detriment in others, you'll have to decide what you like or dislike about it. The targetting locks on to your enemy of choice and you can swap enemies with a quick tap of your camera controls (Right analog if you use a gamepad) in either direction. The problems I have found with it though is there is no quick way to switch targets if one runs behind you (Which they do as a combat technique). Another issue I have found with it is that you can't target unless you have near full view of the enemy which makes it harder on you when coming through a narrow corridor and, unfortunately, there are invisible objects that can get in your way as well (e.g. I found one enemy standing beside a fire brazier and I couldn't target him even though I could clearly see him).

Energy" is basically stamina. It is consumed by attacks (Both regular and power attacks though power attacks take more

reviewText:
This game is not dark souls, it takes some of the dark souls ideas and game play, makes it easier, simpler and more friendly for casual gamers.

if you are a hard core gamer or one that spent a lot of time on dark souls. this game will not last long as you soon realise what works best and will beat the game in a short period of time.

Mobs do not hit that hard and when you realise how each one moves you will soon take all of them down.

Even though the game offers a few different weapon and armour types, you will find that you go for a mid range weight encoumberment and a mid speed weapon. This is because high speed weapons do next to no damage to mobs/bosses, you will never be able to use a big weapon as they are far to slow also being to heavy ( fatman rolling ) doesnt work.
and it wont take long to realise that rolling is pritty much pointless bar a few mobs and side stepping is faster, you stay on your feet for that back stab kill.

The any mob will kill you aproach to dark souls is not needed to be taken on this game.

But the big downside to this game is there is no real replay worth,
As you can only get items that you havent picked up on your first run so if you explored really well you have already done most things.
Mobs are a little harder to kill as they have more hit points, you know how to kill them and it is so easy you will find that you will go as far as possible without spending exp just for a little bit of risk. so far im just past the 5th boss on the second run through and i havent banked once.

I have put recomended on this game as i have enjoyed playing it, all be that its a little to easy, some times hit reg is a bit dodgy, and there was a few crashes near the end of the game.

But......

if you are not a hardcore gamer, and you havent spent time on either dark souls game. This game is fun it will entertain and will pose a slight challenge to you, looks reasonably good, and after you have done this you might be tempted to really challenge yourself and buy the dark souls games. 10X longer but 10X the challange.

reviewText:
controls are not responsive enough to be a good action game, it has technical issues as well; for me i have to endure the pain to watch intro scene twice before being able to play the game every time i start the game.
random crashes...
very slow character but bosses are quite fast.
feels clunky and buggy..
movement is slow too.
im not a big fan of Dark Souls series, but it seems its even slower combat-wise and controls are not responsive at all. for instance, enemy is attacking and i need to dodge, i press the B button on my gamepad and nothing happens..! then i try to block the attack but Harkyn is too slow..
comparing this to Castlevania: Lords of Shadow where the combat was fluid and fast paced and you had the ability to quickly dodge and counter attack, this game is a mess.
bad voice acting, confusing menus, constant freezes and crashes.. difficult gameplay as your character is as useless as a sack of potato..
grab it on a sale, otherwise dont waste your money..
1/10

reviewText:
Runs mostly ok, though does have issues.

Had two CTD's so far.
My magic meter won't fully recharge (I think it's a bug from the greed amulet that I once equipped).

It would seem that the game was designed for the cleric class.
Theif type characters suck because sneaking is broken (no sneak mode, AI has tunnel vision, no indicators if you're in the right position for a sneak attack).
Using a sheild is highly recommended as some enemies are terrible to fight without one, and secret walls need to be sheild bashed.

No map/GPS and quest log make navigation difficult, and sometimes there's no clear direction for what you are meant to be doing which results in hours of wandering.

HOWEVER:
The graphics are highly polished, the environments well designed.
The combat is fun and skill based, though sometimes the game finds it difficult deciding what attack to do when you press a button.
The RPG elements are good, though very basic. Needs proper spell tress and specs.

A sequel that fixes all of this and has about 3 to 4 times the content of this game in all areas would make be epic.

It's a shame that the game is still rough around the edges.

IF YOU ARE AFRAID OF PLAYING DARK SOULS SERIES

PLAY THIS GAME!

There's a catch, in Dark Souls you may find your horror in the playthrough, you will feel fear and sometimes you will tremble yourself because of the atmosphere. But in Lords of The Fallen, you will not.

That doesn't mean that this game is bad, i'd say it's good and kinda immersive. I won't say anything about difficulty......okay it's hard, but it won't make you frustrated, the atmosphere are cozy too!

in short, if you want to play a game that kinda similiar to Dark Souls but have a brighter environment and won't strike you any fear (unless you afraid of cold), while fighting tough enemies and everchangin boss battle stances, this game is for you!

reviewText:
Now that my perfomance issue have been patched oput i can finally recommend this game.
It's a nice twist on the popular Souls sub-genre that's all the craze right now and is it punishing but fair.

Unlike Dark Souls 2, LoTF features a much more responsive combat that expand on the Dark Souls foundation and combined with an impressive moveset of hand-crafted weapon (which there are a lot) and a variety of weapons creates lots of tension and fun to the swordplay.

The game is beautiful and detailed, you can see that it's mainly a PC release, loading times are short and particle effects are damn impressive.

It is not awfully long, but if you want to do sidequests and clear out the treasures it can easily stretch a lot, not to mention all the fun challenges and New Game+ modes.

There's also seems to be a number of endings and the amount of secret sutff is refreshing. Weapons are damn sweet, and i must point out my favourite Stain"

reviewText: The game has so much potential and so much it could've done right, but did wrong. Not going to be a long review that way people looking to buy can skim through the mixed reviews. First off this game is fun, don't get me wrong, the main mechanics behind the game are good. The optimization is meh, the art style is good, and the gameplay is decent.\nWhere the game really fails is it's enemy design and how to counter these enemies. The game doesn't give you a choice on how to do something. For example early on in the game there's a shield enemy that can one or two shot you easily, break through your shield, and is IMPOSSIBLE to get around, the only way to kill him is to blast him with magic, there's no other way. The game itself is good but the bosses and enemies are too generic, the game needs artifical difficulty, not diffuculty that's going to ram you in the ♥♥♥. There's a difference between a game with good challange and a game with bad challange, this game tries to give you a challange, which it does, but goes about doing it incorrectly.

reviewText:
I didn't care about all the negative reviews and I gave this game a chance. And oh boy, I'm thankful that I did that. I was surprised on how good this game was, I couldn't stop playing until I completed it.

First let me say that while it has Dark Souls inspired combat, it has nothing to do with Dark Souls. It has its own ambience and its own way of dealing with the story. Regardless, if you liked Dark Souls you will surely love this game (like I did).

Pros:
Graphics (freaking amazing)
Combat
Secrets
Sound
Story (as opposed to most reviews, I really liked the story, except for the ending)
Cons:
Stupid ending (seriously, is that all???)
Too easy
Shallow level design
Little enemy variety
Too few boss mechanics
... AND I HAVEN'T FACED ANY CRASH.

If I recommend it? Absolutely.
Like Dark Souls? Buy it.
Like action games? Buy it.
Like The Witcher? Buy it.
Like Skyrim? Buy it.
Expect an Open World Game? Forget it.

reviewText:
First off, most of the reviews complaining about the optimization problems are no longer valid. That being said, there is no excuse for games these days especially non-indie titles, to be released as beta feeling as this game was. Unforunately that seems to be just par for the course these days in the industry and I won't let my personal feelings on that matter apply here.

This game is a third person action RPG that uses a similar control set-up to the dark souls games and leveling system, but that is where the similarities really end. You do gain and lose your experience by killing/dying and must go to where you died to retrieve your exp. This exp does start to disappear overtime though, and you're not likely to retrieve most of your exp if you're very far from a checkpoint.

The game's difficulty is not high, and most of the struggles you'll face are at the beginning, and very end of the game. The mid-game seems unbalanced and you will be mowing through most enemies.

The combat is much faster paced than the Souls games and I'd say it's about a mid-ground between that and Darksiders 2's combat. They did an excellent job of making each weapon type feel differently and I feel the physics here surpass the Souls series by far. The staff weapons were incredibly overpowered during the time I played the game due to it's fast attack speed and good scaling damage. This could always be fixed in balance patches or mods however.

The bosses were fairly underwhelming, but there are a good variety of enemy types which take different tactics in order to combat as opposed to the souls series (lock on and circle) method of killing just about everything which detracts from my enjoyment of that particular franchise. There were multiple ways to defeat a few of the bosses, and this allowed you to receieve special equipment upon killing them which I thought was a rather neat addition. Some of the weaker and early bosses become elite enemies that you will fight throughout the game as well, forcing you to adapt your combat style when fighting them as well as a group of lesser enemies at the same time.

There are many collectibles in the game, and while the lore is pretty generic, it's still interesting enough to warrant collecting all the scrolls and finding the secret equipment (which there is a good number of).

The games length was decent, and it could probably be played through 2-3 times in order to play different styles, and colelct the new game + gear, however, new game+ difficulty does not scale nearly fast enough in order for it to be a challenge.

As a final note, I do recommend the game, and while it's not anywhere near perfect, there are some innovative ideas here, and I'd like to see a sequel one day improve on what worked, and change what didn't. This is definitely the best game this particular studio has made to date, and I think they should be supported for adding some creativity to this genre which is pretty much dominated by a single franchise at this point.

reviewText:
A dark third-person action game that most gamers will find easier to get into than Dark Souls series, however, it doesn't quite have the depth of Dark Souls either.  There is less exploration, less variety int terms of builds and combat styles and no customization at all.

That said, it does deliver a good combat style focused on slow, armored melee combat with various large and intimidating bosses.

+Nice graphics
+Good melee centric combat
+Nice atmosphere and overall style
+Interesting bosses

-No customization
-Limited variety of play styles
-Some bugs, including crash bugs at launch that would stop play (mostly patched now)

reviewText:
I have been playing this game for about 8 hours. I will still play it for many hours because...well this game is awesome. From the outstanding and gritty voice acting, too the UI style and the graphics. I think it looks really well on my high end PC with everything set to max. Real eyecandy. The story so far is very immersive, the charachters are realistic and everything has a grim touch too it. Yes it looks like Dark Souls, yes its hard and you'll die a lot....like Dark Souls. But it still stands on its own legs because the battles, the bosses and the controls as well as charachter development are all really better then Dark Souls..in my opinion. This game makes the perfect combination of magic use, weapons and shields. Everything can be used instantly without going thought countless of menus and then selecting and equiping it.

Aside from that, there are a few sidequests, not too much but a few. The game offers a wide variety of weapons and...ARMOR. LOTS AND LOTS OF ARMOR. All the armors looks different and it really looks cool. Heavy armor makes you walk in a different and sluggish style, while light and medium armor makes you more flexible.

If you are a Dark Souls fan and you're looking for a game in a similair fashion..look no further.
Just buy the game and enjoy it. Im really looking forward too a sequel.
voteText: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
A more casual Souls-like game, clearly inspired by the franchise. The combat is also much more sluggish, and less fluid than that in Dark Souls or more recently Bloodborne.

The story isn't something to cheer for, but it is entertaining nevertheless. I personally enjoyed the game, the visuals were rather nice and beautiful at parts, especially when looking at the God Hand and snowy regions of the world, even if they're in the background.

The armour and weapon style is badass, though some of the later sets get recycled with just a switch in colour palette. All in all, if you want something to fill the spot for more Dark Souls with less difficulty and easier combat, Lords of the Fallen is something to consider.

7/10 needs more dark souls

reviewText:
Bottom line.....the game is great!
Those that didn't enjoy Dark Souls (like myself) can find somewhere to call home in a hardcore combat simulator.
Everything from level design to loot is really amazing and feels like a fresh breathe in the industry as it feels like its been too long since I have explored such beautiful enviroments in a third person adventure title.

Complaints?....idk.....maybe when making a game thats overly compared to another dont overpass it so hard that they cant even be compared to one another? lol
DONT compare DS and LotF......its like comparing Gretch's to Gibson's....they are both great games completely independent from one another

reviewText:
Lords of the Fallen is diet Dark Souls. It's not a bad thing, IMO. A lot of the same mechanics are employed but tweaked. One of the biggest tweaks is how XP stacks as you continue through the game without refilling your potions at checkpoints. The bigger the risks, the bigger the rewards.

Since patch 4 the game has been stable for me as long as I keep PhysX turned off. PhysX was causing random crashes.

Overall, if you like solo Dark Souls style combat but have been put off by the difficulty, then Lords of the Fallen is for you presuming your computer is up to spec.

reviewText:
Lords of the Fallen is a very fun game that has a lot to offer. It was a big underrated imo. Having said that though, it does suffer from a lot of problems. LotF is basically a Dark Souls clone, but that's not necessary a bad thing. It does bring its own flair to the series with additions like being healed by your fallen souls instead of just quickly retrieving them.

It also focuses on a more controlled class design than Dark Souls. In DS, your character can be all over the place with stats and gear, which isn't a bad thing, as it allows you to have complete control over your toon. But LotF has specific class abilities, which do play somewhat different from one another. All the armor and weapons can be used by all three classes, as long as you have the necessary stat requirements. It's much more simplified than DS, so it opens it up to more casual people.

One of the biggest changes from the DS series though is that bosses have stages. Each boss has three stages they go through depending on how much health they have left. For example, the first boss you fight will be wielding a greatsword and a shield. The more you fight him, he'll begin losing armor and eventually his shield. Then his tactics change and he just goes berserk with only the sword. It makes boss battle more challenging imo. Once you beat a boss, a rift gate opens up that offers an additional challenge. Sometimes it's just a loot rift, other times its a mob of enemies that you have to fight.

Pro:
Fun gameplay. Dark Souls like with good powers.
Difficult enemies: Bosses and regulars offer a decent challenge.
Great Visuals: Game looks really good.
Amazing Armor and Weapons: Both weapons and armor look really cool.

Cons:
Bad Optimization: The game has suffered from FPS drops since day one. Even with a powerful rig, you're still gonna get drops no matter what.
Bug: Lots of bugs in this game. It's nowhere near as bad as it was, but it needed more time for polish.
Pointless Story/Characters: The story and characters are pretty pointless. Not once did I care what happened to anyone in the game, and the story is very predictable.

Overall, I really enjoyed this game. I wouldn't tell anyone to pick it up at full price, but if you see it on a sale for $20 or less, its completely worth your time. The game was directed to be a more casual friendly DS-like game, but it still offers a good challenge. 7.5/10

reviewText:
I initially started this game expecting it to play like Darksiders however it was quite different.
In essence the combat is more like Monster Hunter. Especially when wearing heavy armor your character is quite slow which takes some time to get used to.

My first attempts failed miserably due to the fact that I wasn't accustomed to the game mechanics. Even the very first enemy took me considerable effort to defeat.
However, after you get past that 'hill' and start getting familiar with the controls and how the character behaves the game becomes incredibly fun!

The atmosphere of the game is awesome: a dark and gritty monastery in which you uncover one horror after the other. Throughout the game you'll find pieces of lore which help you put the puzzle of the story together. My only gripe here is that in the beginning you get dumped into the game without any hook into the story i.e. you have no clue what's going on.

You can find a huge amount of different weapons and armor, each with different stats and abilities and all of them look incredibly cool! The game is also loaded with many secrets which can be uncovered like special equipment, hidden treasure chests, special Portals after defeating bosses etc.

The boss fights (i.e. the Lords) are a mix: some of them are quite easy while others are extremely hard. It takes time to learn their attack patterns and to equip yourself appropriately. Especially the final boss was a tough nut to crack. However, I have to add it never felt impossible i.e. even for the difficult fights you will manage to do a substantial amount of damage so that gives hope that it can be pulled off on a next attempt.

Saving is done by means of checkpoints. So when you die you start back at a previous point and all enemies are back. Initially I didn't like this until I understood this is the core of the game: you have to redo parts in order to get more XP so you become more powerfull for the later game.

When the game is completed you can start a new game +. This allows you to carry over all equipment of your previous playthrough. In addition it allows you to select a new school of Magic. So in this way you can eventually level up in all three schools which is quite nice.

To conclude a couple of minor points which I found:
- There is no Quest log, so it's hard to keep track of some side Quests. Taking notes is required.
- There is no map, so you have to have a good memory where everything is located.
- Most of the secrets in the game are not hinted at by the in-game lore. So some you will find by chance while the rest you can only find by looking at forum posts or youtube vids. It would have been much nicer if this info could be gathered from the game itself.
- Even after finishing the game I'm still strugging sometimes with the controls (using Controller). In most cases this is caused by the fact that sprinting, rolling and jumping is one and the same button. So more often that not when I want to sprint to perform a heavy leap attack ... my character just rolls and bounces against the enemy only to get pounded. When wanting to jump over a gap ... my character just rolls and fall in the depths. These nuisances could have been avoided by a better control sheme.

My final verdict is that it's a great game. It takes some time getting into it, but when you remain persistent (and patient) it becomes an awesome game!

Note: After upgrading to Windows 10 I always got a crash when starting a new game. Disabling the NVidia Turbulence fixed this issue.

reviewText:
Aight.

Pros+Gameplay is fun and engaging for the first hour or so.
+It looks very nice and the physics everywhere adds to the immersion, that is until bodies start flying but that happens in every physics engine once in a while.
+Music is alright, nothing memorable but adds nice ambiance.
+Level design is decent. A lot of areas loop around without you even thinking about it.

Cons-The game is way too easy. And I mean WAYYYY too easy. I only died on one boss due to a instakill spell but as soon as you find out how to avoid it he goes down as easily as the rest. Even the final boss is a cakewalk, he went down in a couple of attacks and did hardly any damage to me.
-Some weapons are just blatently better than others.
-Not a fan of the armor design personally. Armor is 90% shoulderpads.
-Too short. I think I finished the game in about 10 hours or so. For a first run that is just way too short.

The game is too short and easy to justify the 50 dollar price tag. Wait for a sale or something and if you haven't already played it, I recommend picking up Dark Souls instead of this game. It's cheaper, more challenging and longer than Lords of the Fallen.

TL;DRToo short and easy.
Buy on sale.
Buy Dark Souls instead.

Pros; Absolutely amazing graphics, I mean truely, it feels like you are watching a movie while playing, the artwork really shines as well.

Cons; The game is damn near unplayable because you are constantly stuck in loooong animation sequences, so long it begins to feel like the baddies in the game could stop and unty your shoes with you being able to do nothing about it. The camera will also disappoint, it is a twitch/timing based game but in combat you are constantly blinded by the walls, objects and your own character.

reviewText:
LOTF is the first of a new genre called Souls-like, and it's doing an okay job at it. There are some stupid mechanics that shouldn't be in a game that follows in the foodsteps of a legend like Dark Souls. There seems to be only one solution to whatever problem you might encounter, and it gets quite boring after a while.

The best example I have is (spoilers!) the champion boss which does a charging attack where you have to either have a tower shield to cower behind or do a shield bash with a medium shield. This will result in you stunning the boss and you'll get a few hits in, then it's back to baiting out the charge attack. It gets old real quick.

All in all, LOTF has plenty of good things going and if future games learn from this game, they'll do great. LOTF, however, did not do that great and I don't recommend it.

How do I describe this game?  It is a horribly made game.  I know several people have called it a hidden gem" or "dark souls lite" but I would suggest you play dark souls instead.  Lets start off with a break down of pros and cons.

Pros
1.  Graphically better for the most part
2.  Sound is better
3.  It has voice acting and tries to flesh out its story more directly than a souls game.
4.  Linear for the most part
date:
save for a few areas it is hard to get lost.  You just keep going forward and you will eventually find your way through most roadblocks.

Cons
1.  Uninspired enviornments.  You will spend most of your time trudging through dark areas or fiery areas.  Do not expect vibrant areas with variety.  You are either in castles

Combat feels sluggish and can swing from boring to frustrating very quickly.  Once again I am viewing this from the warrior archtype

reviewText:
Lords of the Fallen is diet Dark Souls. It's not a bad thing, IMO. A lot of the same mechanics are employed but tweaked. One of the biggest tweaks is how XP stacks as you continue through the game without refilling your potions at checkpoints. The bigger the risks, the bigger the rewards.

Since patch 4 the game has been stable for me as long as I keep PhysX turned off. PhysX was causing random crashes.

Overall, if you like solo Dark Souls style combat but have been put off by the difficulty, then Lords of the Fallen is for you presuming your computer is up to spec.

reviewText:
Lords of the Fallen is a very fun game that has a lot to offer. It was a big underrated imo. Having said that though, it does suffer from a lot of problems. LotF is basically a Dark Souls clone, but that's not necessary a bad thing. It does bring its own flair to the series with additions like being healed by your fallen souls instead of just quickly retrieving them.

It also focuses on a more controlled class design than Dark Souls. In DS, your character can be all over the place with stats and gear, which isn't a bad thing, as it allows you to have complete control over your toon. But LotF has specific class abilities, which do play somewhat different from one another. All the armor and weapons can be used by all three classes, as long as you have the necessary stat requirements. It's much more simplified than DS, so it opens it up to more casual people.

One of the biggest changes from the DS series though is that bosses have stages. Each boss has three stages they go through depending on how much health they have left. For example, the first boss you fight will be wielding a greatsword and a shield. The more you fight him, he'll begin losing armor and eventually his shield. Then his tactics change and he just goes berserk with only the sword. It makes boss battle more challenging imo. Once you beat a boss, a rift gate opens up that offers an additional challenge. Sometimes it's just a loot rift, other times its a mob of enemies that you have to fight.

Pro:
Fun gameplay. Dark Souls like with good powers.
Difficult enemies: Bosses and regulars offer a decent challenge.
Great Visuals: Game looks really good.
Amazing Armor and Weapons: Both weapons and armor look really cool.

Cons:
Bad Optimization: The game has suffered from FPS drops since day one. Even with a powerful rig, you're still gonna get drops no matter what.
Bug: Lots of bugs in this game. It's nowhere near as bad as it was, but it needed more time for polish.
Pointless Story/Characters: The story and characters are pretty pointless. Not once did I care what happened to anyone in the game, and the story is very predictable.

Overall, I really enjoyed this game. I wouldn't tell anyone to pick it up at full price, but if you see it on a sale for $20 or less, its completely worth your time. The game was directed to be a more casual friendly DS-like game, but it still offers a good challenge. 7.5/10

reviewText:
I got the game in January 2015, after the initial disastrous launch with everyone having crashes at game launch etc.
The game actually played  nice for the first 30 mins , until after the first boss:
- I was running everything maxed out with Nvidia turbulence at 1080p, getting around 55-60 fps.
- my system specs are i7 4770k , 16 GB ram, 2x GTX770 evga  oc edition 2GB in SLi
After the bossfight and when the game transitions to the exterior, I started having huge random frame drops, going from 60 fps to 7-10 fps and the game became unplayable. This is unacceptable.
I had to disable nvidia turbulence, disable cromatic aberration (ugly and terrible decision to include this in the game) and disable most post processing options to get back to 50-80 fps.
Now my problem is that I get totally random crashes while playing (most of the time during boss fights, which is infuriating).
The game itself has decent story and good graphics but suffers from a problem: It wants to be a Dark Souls Clone". And it fails.
If the devs would give the player the ability to save at any point
date: the game would probably last 3-4 hours max with all sidequests done
recommended:
so this means the game is artificially lengthned by this gimmick saving point system.
Also the camera issues while fighting are real and most often than not responsible for ridiculous deaths of your char and more wasted time.
Fighting responsiveness is also close to none which on a fighting game really says it all. There will be plenty of times when your char will not respond accurately to the controls.
I would recommend this game ONLY if you get it on a sale around $10 (or lower)

reviewText:
From the authors of The Chickenator comes Lords of the Fallen, a game which is supposed to be a Dark Souls clone. Unfortunately the game fails to live up to the one it was based upon in every way, but most of all, the combat. The combat feels clunky, slow (even by Souls standards) and repetitive, with no rewarding and satysfying victories which feel rather hollow. The bosses have nothing to offer, all being virtually the same. The story is quite uninspiring and the main character is as generic as can be, with no option to create your own character at all.

It really isn't enough to take some elements from the Souls games to mae equally good game, the devs seem to have failed to understand what makes the Souls series so great...

Another disappointing release of 2014, which seems to be the trend. Maybe worth picking up for €15-20 to give it a try, but no more than that.

reviewText:
LOTF is the first of a new genre called Souls-like, and it's doing an okay job at it. There are some stupid mechanics that shouldn't be in a game that follows in the foodsteps of a legend like Dark Souls. There seems to be only one solution to whatever problem you might encounter, and it gets quite boring after a while.

The best example I have is (spoilers!) the champion boss which does a charging attack where you have to either have a tower shield to cower behind or do a shield bash with a medium shield. This will result in you stunning the boss and you'll get a few hits in, then it's back to baiting out the charge attack. It gets old real quick.

All in all, LOTF has plenty of good things going and if future games learn from this game, they'll do great. LOTF, however, did not do that great and I don't recommend it.

reviewText:
Despite being a very faithful Dark Souls-like game, the PC version is stricken with so many technical flaws that it is hard to recommend.

After pouring over 15 hours into the game, I arrived at the end-game - a long conversation with the main enemy I'd been hunting.  The in-game cinematic is long, lasting nearly 5 minutes, in which you are reminded of all the bosses you'd overcome before.  At the end of the cinematic, you speak with a figure who leads you to the end of the game.

Except, in all my experiences, each time I spoke with the figure the game would crash to desktop.  I attempted this scene almost 6 times, each time crashing to the desktop.  I altered my settings, restarted my computer.

This was the most glaring of numerous crashes that I experienced trying to enjoy this game.

I do not recommend it.  Not at the full price, at the very least.  Perhaps after a few patches, but in its current state, you'd be better off buying the games that it is trying so desperately to imitate.

reviewText:
Aight.

Pros+Gameplay is fun and engaging for the first hour or so.
+It looks very nice and the physics everywhere adds to the immersion, that is until bodies start flying but that happens in every physics engine once in a while.
+Music is alright, nothing memorable but adds nice ambiance.
+Level design is decent. A lot of areas loop around without you even thinking about it.

Cons-The game is way too easy. And I mean WAYYYY too easy. I only died on one boss due to a instakill spell but as soon as you find out how to avoid it he goes down as easily as the rest. Even the final boss is a cakewalk, he went down in a couple of attacks and did hardly any damage to me.
-Some weapons are just blatently better than others.
-Not a fan of the armor design personally. Armor is 90% shoulderpads.
-Too short. I think I finished the game in about 10 hours or so. For a first run that is just way too short.

The game is too short and easy to justify the 50 dollar price tag. Wait for a sale or something and if you haven't already played it, I recommend picking up Dark Souls instead of this game. It's cheaper, more challenging and longer than Lords of the Fallen.

TL;DRToo short and easy.
Buy on sale.
Buy Dark Souls instead.

reviewText:
This is not Dark Souls. This is not Dark Souls II. This is not a souls game at all.
In Dark Souls, you were to explore a huge world with a variety of enemies. The places were different from Leveldesign to appearance. In LOTF, you explore the same level over and over again. Its not changing much at all and gets repetetive very soon. So also are the enemies.
The boss fights aren't challenging at all, I would go so far and say some are really boring.

What bugs me the most is the playtime. In Dark Souls, I played 60+ hours on my first playthough. In LOTF, I finished the game after 15 hours. Yes, 15 hours for an ARPG is way too short.

In Dark Souls, you also have multiplayer gameplay, in LOTF you don't.

So if you think about buying this game. DONT DO IT. Buy dark Souls instead. It will give you a much deeper and richer experience.

reviewText:
I'd be lying if I said I don't find some enjoyment in this game, but every time I start to really get into it, something comes along and ruins it.

It starts out quite promising, but soon you realise that all 10 bosses are nothing but an exercise in your ability to strafe around the arena and be patient as you whittle down their unnecessarily hefty HP bars. There are only about 15-20 enemy types(not including bosses) in the 15 hour campaign, which start to get very stale. The game is also filled with technical problems ranging from minor annoyances to infuriating crashes and random alt+tabs in the middle of combat.

I would say pick this game up on sale, but it is definitely not worth full price. Dark Souls 1 and 2 have more content, and are better designed in general.

reviewText:
The game is really fun, what little I can play of it.  The combat is crisp and the customization is a blast.

The one, and MAJOR problem is that it absolutely crushes a system.  I had a pretty decent rig that can play most anything and I'm willing to turn down some features here and there to make the game go....but this is almost unplayable.  I will have good 5 to 7 second hang ups every time I have more than one or two items moving on screen.  This means that in an action game where timing and mobility is key, I end up dying or missing animations because the screen locks up.

Good game, but can't recommend it unless you have an absolute MONSTER of a machine, and even then, it may not work properly. This game needs optimized for the PC and I hope the developers are taking this into consideration.

reviewText:
The combat mechanics are wonky at best. Shield bash breaks the entire game (you can do damage as fast as you can click the bash button which trivializes everything). Playing without a shield, on the other hand, is unplayably annoying because the game loves enemies that block 95% of the time and you can't get past blocks without a shield (or at least I haven't figured out how, the kick is pathetic) - you have to wait until they charge, hit once, wait again, repeat. Boring.

FPS is terrible on my pretty high-ish-end system (your mileage might wary) until I turned most of the graphical fanciness off, and it still dips at times. Plot is awful and utterly nonsensical, feels like they cut most of it out and forgot to fill the blanks because the dialogue makes absolutely zero sense at some points.

It's not irredeemably bad - the combat has a great feeling of weight to it and is pretty fun-ish when you're not fighting shield enemies or bashing everything. Maybe they can build on the good parts on a later title. If it goes on sale for 5-10€ and you lust for a Dark Souls-clone and don't mind wonky mechanics, maybe.

reviewText:
(Before i start this review of my playthrough from start to finish please be aware that in no manner am i putting this game up as a contender to the soul's series and also in no way am i comparing it with it as well, please also be aware this is all my opinion yours will vary.  This review might also contain spoilers, so if you yourself have not done a playthrough please be aware of that as well.)

With that being said my first few moments within this game seemed rushed, from the forefront im already thrown right into a battle with a subpar and quite the low description of what (is) happening in the world around me.

The story starts off slow and bland at times and continues that trend till the ending credits, i don't know if the dev's intended this to keep you in combat at all times and steer their audience away from a linear story of sorts but i didn't enjoy that personally.

As the game progresses a repeat of NPC voices appears quite frequently along with the trend of demons being the same as well, although at times you face variations in sizes, strengths, weapons, and abilities it all contains the same handful.  The game itself is quite clunky at times with frequent screen tears and horrid camera angles that always seem to happen at the worst of times.

The (Lord's) presented quite the lower challenge than i had expected with this game being a Dark Fantary RPG of sorts i found myself breezing through the first couple not even breaking a sweat and at times just waiting for the fight to be over due to lack of boss mechanics.

Although i have logged only 9 hours at this time and have not touched NG+, i feel personally that i cannot recommend this game at this time, it feels way to rushed and the main story itself was very short.  This game in my opinion should have been listed for $30 not the bigger price tag that it holds at this moment.

PRO's:  Graphics were very nice when everything ran right, the ambience was lacking but the quality was there.
The amount of weapons and or armor in this game is staggering, so many different ways to customize your        character to your liking.

All in all i'd give this game 6/10, which is strictly my opinion.

reviewText:
Being a Dark Souls 1 & 2 player, this game definitely feels easier yet still somewhat challenging. The game is different compared to Dark Souls yet similar. Combat is slower and it really feels like your character is wielding a massive weapon. It really makes the hits you deal feel satisfying. I played as a pure wreckingball wearing the heaviest of armours and a masssive 2h greatsword/axe and I always enjoyed the fights. I didn't experience any clunkiness in contrary to other reviewers. I cannot really comment on the spells since I only used the projectile of the gauntlet to pull enemies.

I think the game felt a bit short, I spent 12.5 hours on my first playthrough although I didn't visited previously explored places to retrieve all treasure. I did enjoy every minute of it besides getting lost a couple of times. I also liked the music a lot in this game.

I would definitely pick this up when it's on discount if you're a fan of the genre!

reviewText:
I'm just going to be open right here - I LOVE this game.
I've just beaten it for the first time and I'm going to beat it agaIn and then again in NG+ and NG++.

So what's so good about it?
Well, a lot of people compare it to Dark Souls. And in some ways it's similar. It does have the same weighty combat system, where you have to commit to each and every one of your attacks, that have lengthy animations and can not be interrupted mid-swing by the player; hits received, however, will stop your attack. You need to know the attack patterns of all enemies you encounter to survive in the first half of the game, looking for opportunities to strike without losing precious HP.

HP in this game can be restored in 3 ways - by a trinket called Life Leech that I personally only got in the later part of the game, that gives you HP for every monster you kill; by casting a Prayer spell, that acts as a decoy for your enemies and also regenerates a little bit of your health; and, most efficiently, by drinking health potions. Your supply of potions is limited and can only be restored by using a Shard - a checkpoint, essentially - or by dying.

This works really well with another system in place - the XP modifier. The more monsters you kill without using a checkpoint or dying, the more XP you get for each consequent kill, up to 2.0 times more XP for kill. This is very handy, but forces you to refrain from healing and restocking at checkpoints for longer and longer. The game's progress still can be saved at a checkpoint without losing the modifier, but that will not restock your potions and health. It is also said that the more XP you have banked" - kept unspent with a risk of losing it - the better loot you can get.

This all makes for a thrilling experience

reviewText:
This game was inspired by Dark Souls, with emphasis on the combat execution, sharp controls and tough enemies. I liked that this game is fair, so whenever you got killed, you were aware why that happened. Also the game does reward the more curious and determined players by having plenty of secrets, or several tougher side-quests. Your choice of magic and weaponry does affect the gameplay significantly, I found myself testing out different weapons against different enemies, because the different weapons have different moves. Your agility is also affected by how much you are burdened, so playing as a dual-knife-wielding rogue in cloth armor feels very different from a steel-clad knight waving a giant polesword.

Graphics and enemy design are very satisfying, sometimes stepping into the grotesque, but nothing that breaks the atmosphere. Detailed textures, particle effects, good animations - all present. As you play along, you get to know each enemy type and how to beat them. But sometimes the bad guys synergize in a killer combinations and then you have to pull them from the pack and dispatch them one by one.

Level design is also inspired by Dark Souls, using a hub-like system with interconnected locations, where you unlock shortcuts as you progress, eliminating the need for fast travel system, as everything is relatively nearby. This can lead to confusion at times, because the in-game objectives are quite vague, so once or twice I needed to take a look at a guide to see what to do next.

Overall, I cannot avoid comparing Lords to the Souls. This feels like a love letter to Dark Souls, but is a good game on its own. The missing piece, why I won't be playing it over and over again, is the absence of multiplayer, which added so much to Dark Souls - observing, how others beat the boss, checking out different builds and movesets. Here you are all alone.

Yes, I would buy it again.

reviewText:
To give a bit of perspective, I picked up this game - sans DLC - for under 10 bucks, so this clearly influences my opinion of it. Also note that I have played over 300 h of Dark Souls and DSII combined, so whatever I say about the difficulty should be taken with a grain of salt.

I liked the game. If you can pick it up a good discount and you need your Souls fix then go for it. That being said, the game has it fair share of issues. I've had a bug where messages telling me a door or chest needed a key would stop appearing about halfway through my playthrough. Damage number also didn't show up any more. Other than that, I had a mostly bug-free experience, eventhough the camera can sometimes be finnicky, especially in tight quarters.

On my i7 5th Gen CPU and GTX 780 GPU the game ran smooth pretty much from start to finish. I've had FPS loss some times, but only ever for short periods of time and never below 30.
The game looks absolutely gorgeous, both in terms of the art design and the graphics themselves. I loved all the designs, from enemies to armor to the environment. Certain areas can look a bit too similar at times, which leads to a bit of confusion, but overall this game looks - and sounds - very good.

Talking about confusing, the layout of the game is very reminiscent of Dark Souls aswell, with a lot of play area in a rather small geographical space. Most areas are interconnected and exploring to find secret passages is a lot of fun.

The last point I wanna talk about is the game play itself. I'm not gonna tell you how it's a lot like Dark Souls, you probably already guessed that. I'd rather point out the for me biggest flaw with the gameplay.
The player is too slow. Not by much. But just enough to be frustrating in certain places. What I mean by that is that after you attack with most weapons you have a short downtime"

reviewText:
Excellent game; a lot of fun.

All in all, a solid action game that a skilled player can appreciate.

reviewText: Great game. Very well done implementation of secret locations, obtainable items, and achievements. Ninja Gaiden fans should like this. I was impressed from the moment the game started. There was nothing special about the story but I did not dislike it. Game suffers from the inclusion of certain moves such as the shield charge and also magic spells that remove the challenge of the base combat. I would suggest that the magic system be reworked or removed in favor of being replaced by the magical abilities of the weapons being augmented with the faith stat. The most difficult battle may be the first boss which may also be the most balanced, fun and challenging; this is how the whole game should remain. This problem arises in part due to stat leveling and equipment balancing. Having the player characters stats and equipment determine the scale of the challenge might solve this.

reviewText:
This is my first review but I just felt obligated to do a review on a game I passed up for so long.

So i'm sure you've read in just about EVERY review/comment/description of LotF that it draws heavy similarities to the Dark Souls series. And it definitely does. But a key point I've only seen one other reviewer make is that it also feels just as similair to Darksiders with a bit of Shadows of Mordor. If you enjoyed any 3 of those games you should pick this game up (preferably on sale!).

The Good, Neutral, and Bad

+ The difficulty curve is very well done, boss fights are about half as hard as Soulsborne bosses I'd say, but some of the regular enemies can be just as difficult and annoying.  Just make sure you're upgrading your weapons, armor, and stats as you go!

+ Really liked the XP multiplier mechanic, sometimes it's worth it to go big and not use a checkpoint since the XP can go all the way up to being doubled what you'd normally get.

+ I don't normally like using Magic all that much in 3rd Person Action RPGs, with the exception of Shadows of Mordor, but I really liked it here. You have regular spells which can buff/heal/distract and you also have what's called a Gauntlet, which is a cannon-like thing on your hand that shoots 3 different styles (Shotgun blast-like, Projectile, and Explosive/Grenade). More importantly you can imbue the different shot styles with elements (Poison, Fire, Magic, etc) which more likely than not will provide a great DoT. The fact that some of the Gauntlet shots go through shields of enemies sometimes proved INVALUABLE, as some of the Tower Shielded foes can be very hard to hit and provide a very small window to attack them after they do. Just imbue some fire to a projectile and watch those suckers burn behind their wall of wood.

= Generic fantasy medieval setting, but the graphics are above average

= Combat will be very familiar to any Souls vet, albeit a little clunkier, and without the fantastic multiple combos the series is known for.

- My biggest complaint is the fact that there is no multiplayer at all. At the very least I feel like the game could of excelled from having a designated phased area where players could PVP, there's a good enough diversity in builds and playstyles to support it staying relatively fresh. Co-Op could of worked well too.

- My second biggest complaint is just a personal one and it's more a QoL issue. There's no Fast Travel. You'll have to do a bit of backtracking in the game at some points (the game does provide numerous shortcuts though thankfully), and you might want to return to earlier levels to farm/hunt for items so the fact that there is no Fast Travel at any point in the game can be quite the bummer at times. I'm not asking for a Fast Travel for every checkpoint crystal, as there are numerous, but an option to port to the beginning of each major area would of been nice.

Overall I'd give it a solid 8/10. No more, no less.

If you've played the Soulsborne series to death and are itching for a fix before the GOTY 2016 holy grail masterpiece god-sent Dark Souls 3 comes out, pick this up.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Lords of the Fallen was quite hypnotizing experience.
Another game by Polish developers that came out in recent years that is of great quality and gameplay. Story isn’t too strong as this game focuses on fighting aspects and gameplay mechanics which were quite solid. I always wanted to go into Dark Souls series and knew that the gameplay there is brutal so I decided to try this game instead and was quite happy about it. It took a while to learn most of the fights especially with bosses and character build plays important role here. Initially I had tons of trouble with trash enemies until I started using magic together with the sword. The world is small but very beautiful and dark in its appearance. The save system is designed around checkpoints and game has great experience system.

Pros
+ Great boss fights that give achievements to drops if fought correctly
+ Great fighting mechanics where you feel you feel the weight of your weapon and armor
+ Great experience gaining system in which the more you kill without save the more rewarding it is
+ A ton of weapons and armor and run customization
+ Great soundtrack and sound effects
+ World is very beautiful

Cons
- Forgettable characters who really do not add too much to the weak story
- Some builds are very weak and you tend to spec character to one build only
- World has very narrow passages and progression through it is very linear

Even with some faults this game was difficult to put down even when I was playing titles like Fallout 4 at the same time.

reviewText: I Like Lords of the Fallen. It's got most of the ingredients for a fun game. It looks rather great, the sound design is passable and it runs pretty well. Despite its flaws, it's definitely worth a try. 7/10.

reviewText:
It's not Dark Souls but it shares a lot of similarities (combat, lore, xp loss from dying, etc).  I'm not too far in but the normal enemies seem easier.  There also seems to be a lot more lore, some actual quests, and more dialogue with NPCs.  I like the style of Bloodborne and Dark Souls 1+2 a bit more but I'd suggest it to other people like me that are looking for something similar.

You will still probably die and have fun in the process.

It's definitely a step in the right direction but if there is going to be more plot I'd prefer it to be more interesting plot.  Maybe convince the makers of Castlevania LoS (with Patrick Stewart as the narrator) to write the story and use LoF gameplay.
