reviewText:
Warning: Dark Souls comparisons ahead

PROS: It's not Dark Souls
CONS: It's not Dark Souls

A little more detail on the PROS:
The game is obviously inspired by Dark Souls and it can be felt in the difficult and tactical combat. There are, however, a few aspects where they chose to differ from the Souls formula which I appreciate:
The story is a lot easier to follow in LOTF. While it might not be as deep, it's not necessary to read through item descriptions to get any idea of what is actually happening in the story.
You know what you need to do next. It doesn't show you exactly where to go or how to do it, but you know what is the next step for the main quest. They don't track the sidequests though, so that is still the same, and I think its better that way.
It's not as difficult as Dark Souls. Yes, it is difficult, and you have to be tactical in your attacks, but it doesn't have that same difficult feel as Dark Souls, and therefore is a lot easier for people getting into this kind of combat. Looking at the difficulty, I would probably recommend playing this first, then moving on to Dark Souls (if you enjoy it). For more seasoned Dark Souls players (like myself) it's a great place to come and relax while experiencing that same tactical combat that has absolutely addicted you to Dark souls.
A little more detail on CONS:
For all the things LOTF does right, there are certain things that I miss from Dark Souls. Maybe they will expand this with the sequel, we can only hope:
Weapon crafting. Yes, I know you have the whole runes thing, but I genuinely miss picking a weapon and then building that weapon as I build my character. The closest I have gotten to that in LOTF is putting a Luck rune into a weapon so it scales with my stats.
The magic system and character development. These two goes hand in hand for me, because in LOTF your magic class limits how you play. I prefer the Dark Souls system where you can mould your character in any way you see fit. Your starting class only determines how you start, the rest is up to you. Would probably be better if the magic system in LOTF had a little more variety,.
Very little environment. You're in a castle. Then you go to a different realm, where you're basically in a castle. The world feels the same, no matter where you go. To it's credit, I think the level design is brilliant with everything interlinking, providing numerous shortcuts to different areas,
I've had many hours of enjoyment in this title, and still play it often. So despite all its shortcomings, I definitely recommend it.

A NOTE ON CRASHES: In all my time playing this, I've had only 1 major CTD (after playing for about 4 hours) and I used to have occasional issues when starting it up. This was all before patch 1.6 (the latest) and I have been playing happily ever since.

reviewText:
I really enjoyed this game. I actually played it back to back (two different play throughs) with using two different builds (Cleric then Rogue). If you are new to this type of game, i would recommend starting with a cleric build. These builds can take a beating and Protect spell will allow for ample healing later on the game. It plays like a Souls game (concept wise) but I don't think it is a fair comparison. I'm a huge Souls fan and appreciate the mechanics of the game genre.

Many reviews state the game play is slow for combat. This is somewhat true. Most of the weapons are heavy and require good timing to swing, but this adds the reality to the fighting. Two handed weapons would be this slow in true combat.

I think if you approach this game with the mindset of having a Souls experience, you may be disappointed, but if you keep in mind that this is more of a mechanics type of souls experience then you will enjoy the game. in my opinion the game starts off as hard as a Souls game but you eventually build your charactor high enough were you start dominating the game, unlike souls, no matter how high you level up you are still always vulnerable.

in any case. Great graphics, cool environment (levels do connect like the original Dark Souls 1 levels), fun fighting. Story is OK. But this is a fun play (while you are waiting for Souls III :) ).

My only complaint on the game would be the camera angle. At time during battle the camera will move to an angle where some part of the environment would block your view. This was annoying at times but only happened a handful of times throughout the game.

Enjoy

reviewText:
I have been playing this game for about 8 hours. I will still play it for many hours because...well this game is awesome. From the outstanding and gritty voice acting, too the UI style and the graphics. I think it looks really well on my high end PC with everything set to max. Real eyecandy. The story so far is very immersive, the charachters are realistic and everything has a grim touch too it. Yes it looks like Dark Souls, yes its hard and you'll die a lot....like Dark Souls. But it still stands on its own legs because the battles, the bosses and the controls as well as charachter development are all really better then Dark Souls..in my opinion. This game makes the perfect combination of magic use, weapons and shields. Everything can be used instantly without going thought countless of menus and then selecting and equiping it.

Aside from that, there are a few sidequests, not too much but a few. The game offers a wide variety of weapons and...ARMOR. LOTS AND LOTS OF ARMOR. All the armors looks different and it really looks cool. Heavy armor makes you walk in a different and sluggish style, while light and medium armor makes you more flexible.

If you are a Dark Souls fan and you're looking for a game in a similair fashion..look no further.
Just buy the game and enjoy it. Im really looking forward too a sequel.

reviewText:
A more casual Souls-like game, clearly inspired by the franchise. The combat is also much more sluggish, and less fluid than that in Dark Souls or more recently Bloodborne.

The story isn't something to cheer for, but it is entertaining nevertheless. I personally enjoyed the game, the visuals were rather nice and beautiful at parts, especially when looking at the God Hand and snowy regions of the world, even if they're in the background.

The armour and weapon style is badass, though some of the later sets get recycled with just a switch in colour palette. All in all, if you want something to fill the spot for more Dark Souls with less difficulty and easier combat, Lords of the Fallen is something to consider.

7/10 needs more dark souls

reviewText:
I initially started this game expecting it to play like Darksiders however it was quite different.
In essence the combat is more like Monster Hunter. Especially when wearing heavy armor your character is quite slow which takes some time to get used to.

My first attempts failed miserably due to the fact that I wasn't accustomed to the game mechanics. Even the very first enemy took me considerable effort to defeat.
However, after you get past that 'hill' and start getting familiar with the controls and how the character behaves the game becomes incredibly fun!

The atmosphere of the game is awesome: a dark and gritty monastery in which you uncover one horror after the other. Throughout the game you'll find pieces of lore which help you put the puzzle of the story together. My only gripe here is that in the beginning you get dumped into the game without any hook into the story i.e. you have no clue what's going on.

You can find a huge amount of different weapons and armor, each with different stats and abilities and all of them look incredibly cool! The game is also loaded with many secrets which can be uncovered like special equipment, hidden treasure chests, special Portals after defeating bosses etc.

The boss fights (i.e. the Lords) are a mix: some of them are quite easy while others are extremely hard. It takes time to learn their attack patterns and to equip yourself appropriately. Especially the final boss was a tough nut to crack. However, I have to add it never felt impossible i.e. even for the difficult fights you will manage to do a substantial amount of damage so that gives hope that it can be pulled off on a next attempt.

Saving is done by means of checkpoints. So when you die you start back at a previous point and all enemies are back. Initially I didn't like this until I understood this is the core of the game: you have to redo parts in order to get more XP so you become more powerfull for the later game.

When the game is completed you can start a new game +. This allows you to carry over all equipment of your previous playthrough. In addition it allows you to select a new school of Magic. So in this way you can eventually level up in all three schools which is quite nice.

To conclude a couple of minor points which I found:
- There is no Quest log, so it's hard to keep track of some side Quests. Taking notes is required.
- There is no map, so you have to have a good memory where everything is located.
- Most of the secrets in the game are not hinted at by the in-game lore. So some you will find by chance while the rest you can only find by looking at forum posts or youtube vids. It would have been much nicer if this info could be gathered from the game itself.
- Even after finishing the game I'm still strugging sometimes with the controls (using Controller). In most cases this is caused by the fact that sprinting, rolling and jumping is one and the same button. So more often that not when I want to sprint to perform a heavy leap attack ... my character just rolls and bounces against the enemy only to get pounded. When wanting to jump over a gap ... my character just rolls and fall in the depths. These nuisances could have been avoided by a better control sheme.

My final verdict is that it's a great game. It takes some time getting into it, but when you remain persistent (and patient) it becomes an awesome game!

Note: After upgrading to Windows 10 I always got a crash when starting a new game. Disabling the NVidia Turbulence fixed this issue.

reviewText:
1. MASSIVE framerate issues. R9 290x and frames still drop to below 20.
2. Boring and tedious enemy encounters. Blind guy, guy with big axe, guy with sword and shield, headcrab thing...GO!
3. Immutable enemy physics. Is he swinging at you? You'd better not be also swinging unless it's a killing blow! Enemies are wholly unlikely to stagger against even strong attacks, even when they're NOT attacking you!
4. Breakables breakables breakables aka roll over ALL the things. Not a fan of this at all. You'll spend minutes at a time just rolling around the room trying to break every object possible because it MIGHT have an item. Stop it, this is not fun. Even Zelda narrowed their list of rewarding breakables.
5. Incoherent enemy physics. Back to this again. This is EXTREMELY apparent with the First Warden (5 minutes in), enemies often exhibit motion that belies their skeletal structure. Try rolling behind an axe guy as he swings at you. Watch as he spins around on a dime mid-step and mid-swing to stay on target. The player cannot benefit from this level of precision homing.
6. Forgettable story and characters. Right from the start, I can't seem to care about even the hero, let alone the people he encounters. Maybe part of that is the terribly awful dialogue animations. Maybe they're just poorly written. Maybe both.

This game tries very hard to be Dark Souls with a Darksiders feel. It fails at both of these things significantly. I wouldn't recommend paying more than $15 for this game, if you're into that sort of thing.

reviewText:
If I could describe this game in one word, that word would be slow. My goodness, this is slow. The combat - which was clearly trying to imitate that of the Souls series - is painfully slow and difficult, and I don't mean that in a good way. The combat is passable when fighting one normal enemy at a time, but extremely tedious and frustrating when fighting more than one at once, and don't even think about fighting a boss. In the two I fought - one only just barely defeating, and this was the tutorial one - it was an agonizingly slow, tedious and frustrating experience. Every single swing is very, very slow, and don't even think about rolling, it takes several seconds, and you'll just end up getting hit. Everything feels like it's so weighed down and heavy it's almost impossible to move fluently or quickly.

Anyway, away from the combat. The graphics are alright, with the environments looking quite pretty at times, and some good lighting effects. The more stylistic approach to presentation means it isn't as murky and ugly as the graphics of the Souls series. The characters look acceptable, though lip movement is below average, and not really acceptable in this day and age of gaming. Faces are a bit bland and lifeless, too.

Story and characters, urgh... there isn't much. I'm aware I've only played a very limited amount of this game, but I feel no desire to continue. The story is very generic and takes itself way too seriously, with not a glimmer of humour in it. The characters spout generic and cliche fantasy dialogue that would not be considered above a B-grade fantasy novel. The Witcher, this is not.

In my 1 hour of play, I barely did anything, yet was bombared with heaps of weapons, armour and equipment, so much so that I didn't know what to do with it, what was good and what wasn't, and what I should keep, so I never changed from the generic start-off equipment I had. Balancing things out over time would have been appreciated.

I'm glad I didn't buy this game for myself - even on sale - as I just played it from my friend's shared library. The combat and gameplay range from passable Souls clone to downright bad in boss fights, the graphics are fine but nothing special, and the story and characters and bland, forgettable and generic. I'm being generous in giving this a 6/10.

reviewText:
I'm just going to be open right here - I LOVE this game.
I've just beaten it for the first time and I'm going to beat it agaIn and then again in NG+ and NG++.

So what's so good about it?
Well, a lot of people compare it to Dark Souls. And in some ways it's similar. It does have the same weighty combat system, where you have to commit to each and every one of your attacks, that have lengthy animations and can not be interrupted mid-swing by the player; hits received, however, will stop your attack. You need to know the attack patterns of all enemies you encounter to survive in the first half of the game, looking for opportunities to strike without losing precious HP.

HP in this game can be restored in 3 ways - by a trinket called Life Leech that I personally only got in the later part of the game, that gives you HP for every monster you kill; by casting a Prayer spell, that acts as a decoy for your enemies and also regenerates a little bit of your health; and, most efficiently, by drinking health potions. Your supply of potions is limited and can only be restored by using a Shard - a checkpoint, essentially - or by dying.

This works really well with another system in place - the XP modifier. The more monsters you kill without using a checkpoint or dying, the more XP you get for each consequent kill, up to 2.0 times more XP for kill. This is very handy, but forces you to refrain from healing and restocking at checkpoints for longer and longer. The game's progress still can be saved at a checkpoint without losing the modifier, but that will not restock your potions and health. It is also said that the more XP you have banked" - kept unspent with a risk of losing it - the better loot you can get.

This all makes for a thrilling experience

reviewText:
Two hours in and the second time i've crashed to desktop.

the first time, i lost half an hour of gameplay because i didn't realize that there is no auto-save. the game pressures you to go without saving in order to earn more experience, but that is an awful mechanic when the game can at any time crash.

especially when you are seconds away from killing a boss.

and to think i waited until i could play the (more or less) patched game.

also buggy framerate, and i am playing with a 780ti at 1080p with several settings turned low/off.

DO NOT BUY THIS GAME.

reviewText:
Avoid avoid avoid avoid this game!!!!
This game is ridiculously hard.
You'll come across a spider shortly after defeating the 1st boss; which is harder than the actual boss fight!!!!!
This game could have been so great if you had the option to lower the difficulty level.
The graphics are stunningly beautiful with great lighting effects.
I gave up on this game after 3hrs due to the difficulty level.
Some people may welcome the challenge, but not me!
If a game is too hard then I find it totally destroys the enjoyment.
I'm not saying games shouldn't be hard, but this hard? Surely not.
I would have gave this a 9 out of 10, but now it just gets a lowly 5.

reviewText: The game has so much potential and so much it could've done right, but did wrong. Not going to be a long review that way people looking to buy can skim through the mixed reviews. First off this game is fun, don't get me wrong, the main mechanics behind the game are good. The optimization is meh, the art style is good, and the gameplay is decent.\nWhere the game really fails is it's enemy design and how to counter these enemies. The game doesn't give you a choice on how to do something. For example early on in the game there's a shield enemy that can one or two shot you easily, break through your shield, and is IMPOSSIBLE to get around, the only way to kill him is to blast him with magic, there's no other way. The game itself is good but the bosses and enemies are too generic, the game needs artifical difficulty, not diffuculty that's going to ram you in the ♥♥♥. There's a difference between a game with good challange and a game with bad challange, this game tries to give you a challange, which it does, but goes about doing it incorrectly.

reviewText: Was never going to live up to the Dark Souls comparisons. In some ways it's a mix of Dark Souls and Dark Siders, which has really nice results at times. I had a lot of fun with this, and the game looks great - especially all the gear you find. Two major gripes: 1) some kind of control glitch meant that about half the time I wanted to do a leaping attack, simply jumped and rolled. Super annoying. 2) I don't have a problem with short games, and this one isn't, really, but on the other hand I still felt like the content was a bit skimpy. Most of the enemies get heavily reused, and much of the game is stretched out by having you go back through previous areas. I only remember there being 5 or 6 main areas to the game.\nIn all, it's a fun game, but certainly not worth full price. Worth grabbing if it's on sale for $5-10.\n7/10

reviewText:
I have this game a while and am only getting to play it now. I got it on bundlestars I think pretty cheap.

A game having so many negative reviews usually pushes it down the list a bit. I gave it a go and it was okay but not great, but sometimes you have to stick at it and not get frustrated and by the time I got to the first boss I was really getting into it.

What I've learnt is that the standard warrior tank class sucks because it's slow and boring to play. For my second game I rolled a rogue and the game was suddenly so much better. It's a much faster and slicker way to play the game. Also you need to get as much xp as possible gathered up early on as it makes things a little easier especially as a rogue. You are going to need play it for a while to settle in then start again when you know what you're doing so you have less chance of dying so you can build xp up.

Some say this game is like Dark Souls and some say not. After completing Dark Souls 3 I think they are the same type of game and I would make comparisons between the two. I didnt really play Dark Souls 1 & 2 so much though.

I feel a bit for the devs of this game with all negativity surrounding it because it's actually very good and very well done.

Anyway, in my opinion this game is definitely worth playing. The graphics are great, the fights are satisfying, the enimies have a great look and design, there is plenty to do and the boss fights are good.

To improve things I'd like to see things explained a bit better like a training mode or something that goes a bit deeper than the tutorial at the very start. Also, another couple of classes to choose from would be great as I honestly think the fun drops drastically playing anything other than the rogue.

reviewText:
oK... I'm not gonna lie... this game is very difficult... especially for people like me who have never played any of the Dark Souls games... However it CAN be done... It takes patience... lots and lots of patience! The combat system is quite elegant in its own right, a very well thought out and complex system where weight of armour slows you down, weight of the weapon and whether or not you are yet strong enough to be able to swing it with one hand while holding a shield in the other... Stamina every swing,  block, parry and riposte costs you stamina... As well as agility, faith and whatnot.

You cannot simply just run in to a group of Rhogar (the bad guys) and expect to win... Not even on easy difficulty setting. All the Lords and their warriors (although can eventually be slain with pure brute force), require different techniques into bringing them down... some techniques may take you a minute to learn, some may even take you 2 hours to learn... There has been times I have wanted to fist my monitor and throw my keyboard through the study window.

The graphics on Ultra setting are quite beautiful, the artwork is fantastic, Dark and Gothic environments with enemies that look like they have come straight from the lower depths of hell... The art team should be pleased with their work... although the cut scenes were a little on the crappy side. The soundtrack is awesome... dark music that helps you immerse into your environment and sets the mood. The story line is a little lacking not plot wise but it's just missing something.

The inventory and upgrading systems are very easy to deal with... you don't need to be some sort of mathematician to work it out...

Overall... I give this game an 8/10... it loses two points because:

1 - The easy difficulty setting should be way more easier than what it is... for new comers it should be much more forgiving because some people (like me) enjoy playing games at a consistent pace first and then increase the difficulty when we play again... But hey No big deal... just practice practice practice!!

2 - The story and cutscenes were a little lacking, but it wasn't too bad...

3 - Would like to be able to jump without rolling when landing... A few little spots to navigate which proved more difficult then they should have...

4 - A map in the menu screen would have been sensational... just coz sometimes I like to know where I'm going (especially the catacombs :/ )

reviewText:
Its a good game, but the difficulty is extremely high for really no reason. It feels like you are in an mmo raid instance and keep wiping on trash mobs over and over. Like no matter how much gear you get, you're constantly way undergeared for the place you are in, and it would be nice to have an option tone that down slightly. Most opponenets have a distinct weakness that you have to find on your own, and until you do you'll probably die several times. Quest objectives are very vague.

All that said, the combat is good and I like the idea of fighting only one or two enemies at a time, instead of a swarm. It gives combat a layer of depth and skill and timing that other games can't have. I'd like to see this concept implemented in other games now that engines support complex blocking mechanics.

3.5/5

reviewText:
TLDR:  Buy if you are desperate for a quick game that is heavily inspired by the souls series but BE prepared to be dissapointed because it is waaay shorter. AND NEVER BUY THIS GAME WITHOUT A DECENT STEAM DISCOUNT!
PROS :
-good graphics. waay better than the souls games ( other than bloodborne ofc),
- Great melee combat, more realistic version of souls melee. with actual weight behind attacks
-  great character design
-well designed levels
-Great armor and weapon design
CONS :
-WORTHLESS NEW game +!!!! AND THIS IS THE WORST OFFENCE. ONLY 1 new armor set in new game + Just ONE! ( if you guys find more equipment pls tell me. I for one cant find any )
-no gameplay outside of the main story.  No exploration.
-Flavour text makes no sense, I got a legendary sword that gets stronger with each kill and a weapon from another world.... both of them deals half as much damage as the weapon you get from frkn palace guards in the late game that in the lore , couldnt even kill 1 rhogar lord! but they wield weapons 3 times stronger!!! WTF
-SPOILER !!! ......A certain point in the game sets it up so that you get to choose sides, but you actualy dont!  Near the end of the game you find out that your true enemy is someone else from the god" you are supposed to kill. and instead of being given the choice whether to belive him or not harken belives him just like that! and procedes to fight against the entire human army! How does he know that the ghostly figure of his dead friend is not an illusion?
-Plot is barely explained. as detailed by my rant below
-World map size is small not even half of dark souls 1
- game length is short. I only got to 20 hours because I forced myself to get the secret weapons of the bosses. which by the way are all useless as they rarely deal more damage than the weapons you get before facing them.
- skills are there but barely needed for actual combat. I went warior but never and I mean NEVER needed to use my skills other than for solving an ocational puzzle. I got them just for the sake of being able to enjoy the warior class but I could and normaly dont use them anyway. they could have given skills more importance or impact in the game.
-weapons and armor are recolored and reused. at first you Apreciate the good looks of equipment. then you realize that the late game version is a recolored version of that same armor. hell even the kinks and scratches are in the same place! WTF

Long Rant version :
-Bought the game on sale and went in knowing that it is a  subpar dark souls. and despite that I enjoyed the game
date: that is untill I got to new game + Frgn new game plus barely has anything + about it. only I found only 1 new armor set! WTF Kind of new game + is that? Oh and the story is even more vague than Dark Souls. Why is Harken a prissoner? What the hell was the opening scene about?  What was the hammer that he got in the opening cutscene? Why did the final boss turn into that? And the world map is barely as big as half of the Dark souls original map. Probablt only as big as Anor Londo + sens fortress + Seaths  castle. And though the armors in the game do look cool the problem with them is that the late game armor is nothing more than a recolored version of earlier armor pieces. And the item descriptions are fckn dissapointing. You get a legendary weapon of some sort that has half the damage of the weapons you get from the palace soldiers late in the game? wtf .\n"

reviewText:
I want to reccomend this game to people, because the combat system is great, the art is great, the story is entertaining, and it really has potential to be a staple game. However,t he company just did not finish their product. The game itself has performance issues. No matter how low I turned the graphics down, the game had long loading times and would slide show occasionally. Putting it in borderless window mode helped this, but not completely. The also randomly crashes. Not frequent enough to be a huge issue, but enough to be annoying.

Furthermroe, the game not only refuses to hold your hand but flat out doesn't give any direction what so ever. I loved the souls series for their lack of hand holding, but i always coudl tell whether Iw as goign the right way or not and generally understood the direction I was heading. LotF felt like I was constantly stumbling around. So many times I'm just trying to find the right way and no sure if I'm even int he right area then bam boss fight out of no where. I can't count the amount of times I just sat there a moment wondering where I was.

Then there's the stat system which didn't make any sense no matter how you cut it. Most weapons had damage scaling. I put 3% on one weapon got a huge boost in damage, another weapon had a natural 9% and did half the damage. I don't even know what the percentages mean. percetnage of what? 3% of 29 strength isn't 40, so it can't be that. I have no idea.


TL;DR I'm about to fight the last boss and: I don't know where I am, I hav eno idea how the stat systems work, despite having a solid gaming PC I'm playing on pretty low graphic settings, and I jsut saw a blue screen of death for the first time in ten years.

reviewText:
One of the most frustrating games I have played in years. Annoying camera movements. Slow restrictive character moves. Some nice combo moves but largely just leave you open to attack.
Near impossible to avoid boss attacks and the need to repeat it all again if you die just to get your lost xp back.

It looks stylish on the preview videos but you soon find it's very repetative attacks and dodges.

In over 30 years of gaming experiance this is one of the few that will push you to the point of wanting to put your keyboard through the monitor.

Looks good, had real potential. Sadly didn't deliver. Not recommended.

reviewText:
If you'd like to see my (very condensed) stream-through of this game for the first time, feel free to click on the link below.  WARNING:  I swear frequently.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=a8q_tSOD2ow&list=PLklrkLw7j3VTq02g1ZnLXgD9oh1Ao5Qsw&index=1

I'll preface this by saying that I'm a huge Dark Souls fan.  However, I'm extremely critical of all games that I play, including those dear to my heart like the Souls series.  All of my experiences playing this game are as a lightly armoured Rogue.  Apparently, the game is much different (easier) for heavily armoured Warriors, but I lack the experience to comment on that.  Scroll to the very bottom for the TLDR-style conclusion.

REVIEW

This game is the only one in several years to crash on me.  My PC should be able to handle it without a hitch on High, maybe even Ultra settings, yet I was forced to turn off all the extra effects and go Medium just to make it playable.

I don't remember anything about the soundtrack.  Voice acting is stiff, but sometimes to comical effect.

The story is dull, the characters are forgettable and the writing is flat out bad.  I for one can actually appreciate the comedic potential of bad writing, but most people won't be so forgiving.  The majority of the story is told through collecting Audio Logs.  This is a nice touch, as it lets you understand the setting while you continue exploring.

Combat is... all over the place.  Sometimes combat is fluid and makes sense.  Other times enemies will immediately counterattack and stun you without an animation, making you sit through free damage.  Many enemies have giant shields, and just like in a Souls game, they're extremely monotonous to fight.

The pacing of combat is very slow compared to either Souls game, where your fast roll feels like something between a medium and fat roll from DS1.  I wouldn't say the change in pace is a good or bad thing, just different, and Souls vets will definitely take time to adjust.

Boss fights drag on with huge health bars and little variance in attacks, making them a chore after the first few moments.  They do, however, use a 'phase' system similar to bosses in MMOs, which can make the fights more interesting.

The game uses a combo system that encourages you to chain attacks together for increased damage and poise breaking.  This sounds great on paper, but in practice, you'll rarely be given an opportunity to use them because...

...poise is an absolute mess in this game.  When staggered, enemies will often break out of the stun to continue attacking you, which defies any sense of game logic.

I didn't use magic to comment, but the gauntlet - a ranged magic weapon - feels extremely forced into the game, as if it was something for the devs to tick off their checklist.  Same thing with destructable items.

While the graphics are very good and well detailed, the game world is tiny and forces you to backtrack so much that one can only assume there were budget restraints.  The game tries to emulate the joy of Souls shortcuts, but for every one that makes sense, there are ten that don't... or ask you to come back much later in the game.  On foot.

There's really not much selection in weapon types, especially considering you'll be locked to your stat of choice.  Agility, for example, has daggers, shortswords and staves, along with one axe that feels slow and heavy like a Strength weapon.  You can socket items similar to Diablo games, but in similar fashion you'll be using the exact same gems every time to min/max.

Finally, let's talk about bugs.  Crashes.  Animations being skipped.  Enemies standing still and attacking you from bizarre angles.  Invisible enemies.  Frequently absurd hitboxes.  And yes... this game has almost been out for a year.

CONCLUSION

Lords of the Fallen is a shorter, buggier and often nonsensical version of Dark Souls 2 but with superior graphics and an art style reminiscent of Warhammer.  While I wouldn't call it a terrible game and did enjoy my playthrough at least somewhat, there's a lot of barriers blocking the way for 'fun'.  Impatient players and Souls players in particular will be rubbed the wrong way by this game.  I cannot recommend this game in good faith simply because you can buy Dark Souls 2: Scholar of the First Sin for the same price, a game that is superior in almost every way.  Only consider this game if you can get it at a very reduced price and are prepared to muscle through bugs and poor optimization.  What I will say, however, is that it's very important that this game exists, because it shows that companies other than From are willing to take a shot at Souls-likes.  Let's hope the next attempt is a better one.

reviewText:
This Game reminds me strongly on the Dark Souls Series only with a Tutorial and sluggish working controls. The Atmosphere seems nice, the graphics seem gorgeous too! One of the bigger problems is getting this game to run, after multiple crashes and other probelms such as never ending spinning camera, you might finally managed to get this game to work without any problems (until the next start up).

To the Actual Game, you get only 3 different classes with 3 different armor sets. Every Character seems to have an ultra heavy weapon that he can't swing proper, which means you have to time against your own reaction times and might react 30 seconds before the enemy puts its shield up. Whilst this is not a big problem against small enemies, it its an awfully big problem against Bosses & Bigger Enemys. A Dodge funktion and/or attack funktion should work immediatly and not half a minute after its being pressedn, which means you get hit 99.9% of the time.

If you are searching for a game like this only with better optimazation and fair gameplay than I would recommend you to go and play Dark Souls Prepare to die Edition (+free mod support) as it is the best one they ever made so far. But for this one AVOID!

reviewText: As someone who liked the idea of the Souls games, but not the execution, I've been enjoying this game. It has the weighty, punishing combat but manages to not feel cheap. You're punished for making mistakes, but rarely killed outright, giving you some time to learn enemies' patterns. There are usually checkpoints a short distance before boss fights, so you don't have to spend hours upon hours just fighting your way back to them only to be killed again in 3 seconds. Speaking of bosses, I was able to explore and find a boss that seemed way too hard for my current level - I could barely scratch him. Satisfyingly, with some persistence and a total change of strategy, I wore him down in an epic, edge of seat, half-hour long battle and won the day.\n\nMy (fairly minor) gripes so far are a slight lack of enemy variety and that the spells seem a bit limited and shoehorned in.

reviewText: The game's good, it plays well and it's a lot of fun: it is has a souls like gameplay but with more emphasys and realism on the physics and weight of your equipment and also great graphic. Unfortunately it's not perfect and it has some flaws, i.e. the map is not very large and there's a lot of backtracking. Also, it lacks on variety of enemies, but at least there are a lot of weapons and armors, which all look cool. The main story and side quests are not that great, standard fantasy stuff.\nThe campaign lasts about 15 hours...provided that you can finish it because the game is affected by constant crashes which can make the experience sometimes very frustrating.\nimho it's not worth a full price,  if the crashes persist you even may not be able to finish the game so i suggest to wait for patches and for a price drop, because for 25€ it's almost a must buy for whom likes Souls games of action game in general.

reviewText:
Completely misses the point of the Souls series.

- Combat is unfair, tedious, badly designed.
- Enemies are uninspired and have gimpy attacks. Example: Fat enemy with crossbow/traps/fire grenades with 1 inch long legs moves faster and hits harder in melee than your ironclad knight character. He also seems to have no problem leaping 20 meters back the moment you start to swing your weapon (which takes 5 hours to complete). He can also do this consecutively without getting tired. Ever. And then he smashes your face in while you're recovering. Twice.
- Backstabbing mechanic is clunky and rarely works when it should.
- Objectives are unclear.
- You have no idea where you need to go (mapping isn't done well).
- You can't distinguish anything, everything looks too similar, too much of the same debris everywhere.
- Side quests are vague and simply badly designed.
- Voice acting seems robotic. Pre-recorded text and slapped here and there, no 'emotion' or 'reactive' dialogue whatsoever.
- Characters are bland and one dimensional.
- Skills are uninspiring.
- Casting skills takes a ridiculous amount of time.
- Casting a skill and getting hit during bugs things out. You sometimes get the benefit of the skill without triggering it's Cooldown or using Mana. Unintended bug, but is actually really useful for the player when it happens.
- Fighting the simplest enemy can take 5 minutes because of the way combat is designed.
- Company intro cinematics take a very long time.
- In fact, everything takes a ridiculous amount of time.
- Company intro cinematics cannot be skipped nor disabled.
- Weapons / gear seem bland. They feel very similar to eachother, no real variety.
- Difficulty curve is all over the place. Sometimes you get roflstomped by the simplest mobs, but the boss's heaviest attack does only 10 damage against you.
About the controller:
- Cannot disable controller vibration.
- Control schemes are unintuitive.
- Cannot set your own control scheme, and there are only 2 to choose from.
- Made me spent my time to write a negative review.

On to the good things:
+ Looks quite good graphically.
+ Another contestor for Souls like gameplay.
+ Greatly displays how much Dark Souls could have sucked, but didn't.
+ Makes you appreciate the Souls series even more.
+ They tried.
Did they? With a few changes in design this game could already have been so much better than it is now, so I'm not even entirely sure.

reviewText:
This game on the surface looks beautiful, but unfortunitly it has at least three major flaws (besides the known technical issues) that really take the fun out of the game.

1) The big issue for me was the combat. In Lords of the Fallen, all, and I do mean ALL of the combat is based off of timing. This means that combat moves pretty slow and feels clunky and one tries to position the enemy into just the right spot and then waits to swing the weapon. Weapons are fairly heavy in this game and so they take a good amount of time to swing, which means one has to mentaly calculate how long it is going to take you to swing your weapon, how long your enemy is going to take to swing his, and then determine the window of oppertunity. This leads to an awkward period in which on is trying to judge all of these things...in really slow time since the weapons are heavy. I know other games do similar things to this, but once agian the apparent weight of the weapons makes this feel like it is going on forever.

2) The second big issue for me was the weapon leveling system (and really the whole leveling system in general). The only way to improve a weapon in this game is to add a ruin to it, and hope that the weapon you want to add the ruin to is one that you can add a ruin to. See why this is annoying yet? What makes it worse is that the ruins only add special effects, and don't really do much to the damamge base damage of the weapon. My problem with this, other than it being anoying, is that it doesn't really allow you any good or even decent way to grind, work, or attempt to make personal approvements to gear up for a boss or tough enemy. The leveling system doesn't help either as the complex load out and multitude of essentialy useless options means there are plenty of places to put skill points but very few that seem to help.

3) The story. Its just bland and at times can be a bit hard to follow. I know I didn't get terrebly far into the game, but after three bosses, you would think one would at least have a vegue idea as to why one is trying to fight these bosses. Or at least why one fought the bosses I did fight. I watched the cut scenes and all I know is that nobody likes monks and demons are bad. The story just bores me.

Despite the beauty and great graphics of this game I just can't recomend it. I should also not that I never experianced any of the technical issues many other users have, but I'm using an MSI GT72 Dominator Pro so...that may be something to think about. Anyway, I just don't think its worth the hassle.

reviewText:
Some dark forces invade, again. Some guy is released from prison to fight the aforementioned dark forces, again. We don't know what exactly is happening, again. We have to fight an kill every one, again. We die, the sector is repopulated and we try to kill everyone, again. You probably see where I'm getting at, the game is a pretty and somewhat polished collection of clichés  with an emphasis on 1 on 1 (maximum 1 on 3) sword/axe/hammer/etc fight and some magic.

The game is similar to the Dark Souls series, with an emphasis on combat and loss of experience in case if you die (no quick saves here). It is a nice action RPG based in a citadel and *drum roll* dimension of the evil invaders. The game will also take some time to get used to controls and some glitches.

Pros:
•	Sometimes interesting battles
•	Reflexes are important
•	Audio/video quality of the game is 9/9
•	some battle realism

Cons:
•	somewhat glitchy controls and camera
•	no map (yep, you have to memorise the locations)
•	battles become systematic once you learn the enemy types
•	boss fight are often frustrating because of controls, and become easy once you figure out bosses' fight pattern

All in all this is a solid mid-tier action RPG, it is not worth the full price, so I can only recommend it for $20-25 if you have 12-20 hours to kill.

One Grumpy Russian score: 6 out of 10 - not as tempting as vodka, but an a nice alternative when you have none and have no mood for Dark Souls.

For more reviews join: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/ogrreview/

reviewText:
It's Dark Souls with a graphical overhaul.
Nice, fluid gameplay, a true sense of weight in movement and a few neat little twists on the Dark Souls mechanics that this game undeniably got inspired by, which is perfectly fine by me. It's challenging, it's insanely pretty and it feels good...

...if it runs for more than 20 minutes without crashing.


I've got a rather high-end system. No current game on ultra settings makes my computer break a sweat, yet Lords of the Fallen significally drops in FPS upon knocking it up to ultra. However, that'd be okay, I can live with HIGH settings, it still looks great, however what ultimately kills any enjoyment one might have from the title is the fact that it crashes constantly and without any recognizeable pattern. Sometimes it crashes mid-fight. Sometimes it crashes upon dying or respawning. Sometimes it crashes when entering a door. Sometimes it crashes after 5 minutes, sometimes after 20, but never later. And I'm not the only one with issues like this. Check the forums. Check the community hub or other sites.

Countless people report similar problems, and have reported them since launch, however the Devs have yet to fix the issue. Whether that is through lazyness or incompetence I don't know, but the fact stands that if you buy this game, you're wagering your money on whether or not you may be able to actually play it, as there is no demo available with which you could see if your system is one of the few random ones that can run the game without issues.

If the crashes were fixed, I would immediately recommend this game to anyone who enjoyed Dark Souls, or who simply enjoys a bit of spice in their RPGs. As it stands, however, you might want to wait until a reliable fix is up.

reviewText: I am really enjoying this game so far. The first thing I noticed is how well polished it is. The controls feel smooth and the UI is very intuitive. I so wanted to get into Dark souls 2, but I just couldn't. This game takes a lot from Dark Souls and, imo, does it better. It's beautiful and can be brutally challenging at times. Unlike Dark Souls, the controls for mouse and keyboard work well. I tried both a controller and M+k and I personally prefer M+K better. The sounds are well done and help to create an immersive experience. All in all I would recommend this game to anyone looking for a challenging and rewarding experience.

reviewText: The path for your redemption is drenched in the blood of your enemies. Lords of the fallen delivers smooth combat, diverse arsenal and supports many different playstyles. Visually, it is an eye candy (and a very tasty looking one, too). With different enviroments, enemies and side missions, it keeps things enteresting and immersive. The problem is that it constantly kept crashing on me in multiple locations and on vastly different settings (ranging from ulra high to low), which is strange considering I have a GTX 780, i7 processor @3.6Hz and 16gb of RAM. In the end, I do recommend this game but would advise to wait a bit for some patches and slight AI fixes.

reviewText: The path for your redemption is drenched in the blood of your enemies. Lords of the fallen delivers smooth combat, diverse arsenal and supports many different playstyles. Visually, it is an eye candy (and a very tasty looking one, too). With different enviroments, enemies and side missions, it keeps things enteresting and immersive. The problem is that it constantly kept crashing on me in multiple locations and on vastly different settings (ranging from ulra high to low), which is strange considering I have a GTX 780, i7 processor @3.6Hz and 16gb of RAM. In the end, I do recommend this game but would advise to wait a bit for some patches and slight AI fixes.

reviewText:
TL;DR - too many shields/10


If you're like me, you played and enjoyed the souls games and are looking for something similar but with a new take. Keep looking this game is not for you.


This game is not for anyone. It's not that it's too easy,  or nothing but a souls clone because it does add to the souls formula in good ways (I like the faith/magic system for example). The biggest, most glaring problem is the enemy design and boss design. The first boss is okay - not much too him but he's the first boss so w/e. The second boss is where you see the problem: f****ing shields. The entire fight is walking around him until he decides to do something because blocking negates 99.9% of all your damage. Who the hell thought this was a good boss design!? You wait. And then you deal about 1/15th his health, then wait some more. Then kill some adds, and repeat. It's embarrassingly bad.

I killed him twice because the first time the damn game crashed on me during the cutscene and there's no autosave. I figured if this was the worst there was that's okay, I'll keep playing. OH BUT THEN. MORE. F***KING. SHIELDS. I do not feel like spending 5 minutes circling shield enemies waiting for a small opening to deal a small amount of damage to. This is BAD DESIGN.

Don't buy it. Don't consider it. Move along.

reviewText: The game is simply broken. Even now, after 6 (?) patches, on a perfectly capable system (i5@4.50GHz + 970 OC) drops to 30 fps on lowest details in 1080p. Yes for the most time it stays smooth but the drops are always there around the corner and those drops will make your boss fights a mess, and you can imagine how a boss fight can be challenging and frustrating at times.\n\nThe game is not as difficult as dark souls, it is similar in some ways but to sum it up it is the 'bad copy' of the Dark Souls games. I bought the game for 10 euros and I still regret it. If it were running smooth I may have wanted to go on and play the whole game....but the framerate problems (luckily, no crashes) + extremely boring maps (it looks always the same....Dark Souls has a magic feeling whenever you enter a new location) and so - so fights make me want to just quit the game and not go back to it.

reviewText:
I am not quite sure what this game is trying to be. It is kind of like Dark Souls, but not really, which is not exactly a bad thing. It is not like Dragon Age at all which is a bit of a dissapointment. And it is not like Kingdoms of Amalur either, even though I have heard it compariered to all three. However, this is one of the most boring, monotonus, and overrated games I have seen in years. And here are three reasons as to why.

1 The Basics: gameplay, graphics, mechanics ect.

For starters, it is a hack and slash job, meaning that the gameplay is going to be a johnny one note eventually once you hit a stride. This is not always that bad, Dragon Age could be argued as a hack and slash but it is so good that it over comes that querk. What lets this down for me on that end is the way you fight. Once you figure it out, combat is down to this formula, block, stab, dodge, counter attack, rinse and repeat, rinse and repeat, rinse and Zzzz, Zzzz. There is not other truely effective tactic regardless of class used, not that the classes are all that different mind you. It will not matter which you choose, I will get into this later but it is quite bland. To make things worse, you cannot choose what your character will look like so you are stuck with one ugly SOB with a shaved head, bad beard, and stupid tattoos all over his face. Give up any asperations of running for government office. Not that you ever see it that much, the camera control is pretty much locked up to you rear end both in and out of combat, the only time you can ever see what you look like is in conversation, which is only marginaly better than the one found in Kingdoms of Amalur. Not that this matters either because the graphics are a big let down for a title of this price and rating, and this only came out a little over a year back.

2 There is no F***ing castor class!!!!!!!!

In Dragon Age, I prefer mage, Mass Effect, Sheperd is a Sentinel, and I go full Battlemage in Kingdoms. Three guesses which class I like, hint it sure as little green apples ain't here. The class system here is a little confusing, you begin by choosing three magics" that have nothing to do with magic in any respect with the exaption of prayer

reviewText:
Very good graphic and atmostphere.

However, it contain a few questionable problem.

1.Player's attack motion
Player's chatacter attack is rather too short or too slow. For example, short sword attack speed is alright BUT the range is super short EVEN you use the stab attack.  2 hand weapon such as great sword or great axe, doing better damage but the attack motion is unreasonablely slow.

2.Shield system
mostly the shield work like darksoul style. However, this system might not work properly sometimes. for example, in some area, you will encounter some enemy with fire arrow, you can't block it like the normal arrow EVEN with a tower shield. on top of that, when you blocking the melee attack, only the weak enemy will got stagger some special enemy like the thief or the archer, they can break your tower shield guard with a little knife.

Not only that, when you try to attack the shield enemy, it will cause a great problem to you beacuse the enemy's recovery are too fast.  for example, when you tried to fight a shield thief, sometimes he will just hold his small shield and run in circle and waiting for you to attack, you cannot break his guard easily even with a heavy weapon. all you can do is wait for his move. of cause you can use  kick attack to break his guard and attack BUT it is ONLY for fast weapon, heavy weapon is way tooooooo slow to catch up the guard break. however, the enemy can easily break your guard and finish you off.

3. special enemy
In this game, it contain quite a lots special enemy(e.g: fatty archer. fatty Knight)like darksoul style, they are cheaty and hard to kill. Some of them you only need to fight it once and it won't respawn. BUT lots of them WILL respawn everytime you died or re-enter the area.

reviewText: I've tried two separate times to enjoy this game, but it's just too slow and boring. The game is desperately trying to ape Dark Souls, and you should really just play any of those games instead. Unlike Lords of the Fallen, their combat feels responsive, their worlds are worth exploring, and there is variety to the roleplaying you can do. In Lords of the Fallen, even wearing the lightest armor, you feel clunky and slow.\nThe best way to illustrate how annoying I found the combat in this game is when fighting against enenies using shields. When not attacking, these enemies always keep their guard up, and take no damage. As in Dark Souls, against enemies like this the best strategy is to break their guard, or circle around them and attack from behind. In Lords of the Fallen, breaking the guard of a shield enemy is so worthless, they regain their composure and are blocking again before I can land 1 hit from my slow weapon. Same with circling around, the time it takes for me to roll out of the way of an attack is enough time for the enemy to put their shield back up again. Fighting enemies like this was so beyond entertaing that I am ready to stop trying to enjoy this game.

reviewText:
Lords of the Fallen is a gem of a punishing Action-RPG with alot of replayability and an interesting story with alot of discoverable groundwork for it's lore through audio-notes and hidden areas. Although many people have given this a negative review based on their issues with its stability, I can honestly and shamelessly tell you that I have played this game through twice with an Nvidia 660 Ti and I have NEVER experienced a crash once.

It saddens me greatly that people flay the game with their issues running it instead of focusing on the gameplay itself. If someone is unable to run it smoothly it is acceptable and understandable to make its stability a major negative point, but I feel this drastically overshadows the game itself and its amount of negative reviews do NOT reflect its worth in my eyes.

On to the review:

PROs:

-Easy to pick up and play, a challenging yet simple introduction to its genre. A game equally providing the footwork for Dark Souls-esque games to newcomers with a slightly more adaptable learning curve and a challenge for veterans of the genre such as players of Demon's Souls, Dark Souls and Dark Souls 2 (I have played all three).

-Great story with titbits of collectable lore. The story is not over the top and hard to follow but is fairly involved if you choose to collect the audio-notes. It gives its players a choice to skip the notes and focus more on the gameplay, leaving the story more of a vanilla 'Knight-kills-monsters' type deal, which is fine too.

-Smooth and responsive combat feel. The games core mechanics reflect your combat style through the gear you use and the weapons you wield, much like the Dark Souls series. If you wear light armor and use daggers, you will be alot more fragile but can potentially land a hit with each button press and have a light and nimble roll. If you wear the heaviest of attires, you will have a clunky roll and your hits will have more of a delay and wind-up to them, reflecting the feel of bearing such a burden, however, you can take alot more punishment before dropping and can hit like a truck. Play your way.

CONs:

-Voice acting and lip sync. Some of the dialogue between the essential NPCs feels almost forced. They play a preset animation loop whilst their dialogue plays over the top. Whilst this doesn't bother some players, such as myself, if you have a strict immersion policy this will be a bother, but is by no means game-breaking.

-Noticeable difficulty drop-off point. After you've been playing for a while and grinding away with those big enchanted weapons and armors of yours, you will start to notice a point where things are dying a bit too quickly. This is mainly an issue if you choose a heavily armored, warrior-type class, where endlessly pouring your points into vitality and strength starts working a little TOO well. On my NG+ of my warrior, I was so big and angry that I only died once, and it was falling off a cliff... you get the point. Whilst this is much less of an issue with rogue-like characters, it should be pointed out. Furthermore, if you are looking for a challenge or are more accustomed to Dark Souls like me, you should definately go for a rogue, as it will provide consistent difficulty, even through your NG+.

-Loot variation system. Whilst the game uses a system where you cannot get the same piece of loot twice, which is a brilliant idea, it simply does not have enough variation in it's gear to support it. All the weapons and armor scale with your attributes so you can potentially keep your favourite sword or helmet forever and all of the equipment is very well modelled and aesthetically pleasing. However, once you find a supreme piece of gear, you spend the rest of the game picking up pennies and belly button lint by comparison. For example, once I got my full 'Lords' set of heavy armor, even in NG+ I couldn't find anything that even came CLOSE to it in comparison, and I am a man who loves his loot.

Conclusion:

In short, I had ALOT of fun with this game and its a surefire candidate for my GOTY, I would recommend it to anyone looking for a fun and involved challenge without diving head first into the Souls series. It has alot of solid gameplay hours, beautiful environments and gear, an interesting and involved story and a very 'play-your-way' attitude.

9/10

reviewText:
I would have to give this a recommend for a few reasons and some accompanying caveats.

Combat:  The combat was awesome for me.  This is one of the best aspects of the game.  It really felt that like that good precise Dark Souls style combat.

Caveat:  The combat, so long as you were playing a warrior, was great.  I really liked playing as fast rogue like characters, but I had a hard time pulling this off, personally.  The weapon combo system was great, but enemies reacted way to fast to make good use of Rogue type weapons.  I did not however play as a magic user.  I don't usually like that in games like this.

Graphics: They are really well done.  The details of the world were really really good.  I also overall like the graphic designs in the game.

Caveat: There were some complaints about it being too WoW like".  Big shoulder pads
hoursPlayed: but these things didn't bother me.  Some of the armors and weapons in this game were truly awesome to see.\n\nSound:  I don't know if this was a bug that was not fixed before I beat the game but:  The enemies often times made sounds from their deaths several seconds after I killed them

reviewText:
Lords of the Fallen is a gem of a punishing Action-RPG with alot of replayability and an interesting story with alot of discoverable groundwork for it's lore through audio-notes and hidden areas. Although many people have given this a negative review based on their issues with its stability, I can honestly and shamelessly tell you that I have played this game through twice with an Nvidia 660 Ti and I have NEVER experienced a crash once.

It saddens me greatly that people flay the game with their issues running it instead of focusing on the gameplay itself. If someone is unable to run it smoothly it is acceptable and understandable to make its stability a major negative point, but I feel this drastically overshadows the game itself and its amount of negative reviews do NOT reflect its worth in my eyes.

On to the review:

PROs:

-Easy to pick up and play, a challenging yet simple introduction to its genre. A game equally providing the footwork for Dark Souls-esque games to newcomers with a slightly more adaptable learning curve and a challenge for veterans of the genre such as players of Demon's Souls, Dark Souls and Dark Souls 2 (I have played all three).

-Great story with titbits of collectable lore. The story is not over the top and hard to follow but is fairly involved if you choose to collect the audio-notes. It gives its players a choice to skip the notes and focus more on the gameplay, leaving the story more of a vanilla 'Knight-kills-monsters' type deal, which is fine too.

-Smooth and responsive combat feel. The games core mechanics reflect your combat style through the gear you use and the weapons you wield, much like the Dark Souls series. If you wear light armor and use daggers, you will be alot more fragile but can potentially land a hit with each button press and have a light and nimble roll. If you wear the heaviest of attires, you will have a clunky roll and your hits will have more of a delay and wind-up to them, reflecting the feel of bearing such a burden, however, you can take alot more punishment before dropping and can hit like a truck. Play your way.

CONs:

-Voice acting and lip sync. Some of the dialogue between the essential NPCs feels almost forced. They play a preset animation loop whilst their dialogue plays over the top. Whilst this doesn't bother some players, such as myself, if you have a strict immersion policy this will be a bother, but is by no means game-breaking.

-Noticeable difficulty drop-off point. After you've been playing for a while and grinding away with those big enchanted weapons and armors of yours, you will start to notice a point where things are dying a bit too quickly. This is mainly an issue if you choose a heavily armored, warrior-type class, where endlessly pouring your points into vitality and strength starts working a little TOO well. On my NG+ of my warrior, I was so big and angry that I only died once, and it was falling off a cliff... you get the point. Whilst this is much less of an issue with rogue-like characters, it should be pointed out. Furthermore, if you are looking for a challenge or are more accustomed to Dark Souls like me, you should definately go for a rogue, as it will provide consistent difficulty, even through your NG+.

-Loot variation system. Whilst the game uses a system where you cannot get the same piece of loot twice, which is a brilliant idea, it simply does not have enough variation in it's gear to support it. All the weapons and armor scale with your attributes so you can potentially keep your favourite sword or helmet forever and all of the equipment is very well modelled and aesthetically pleasing. However, once you find a supreme piece of gear, you spend the rest of the game picking up pennies and belly button lint by comparison. For example, once I got my full 'Lords' set of heavy armor, even in NG+ I couldn't find anything that even came CLOSE to it in comparison, and I am a man who loves his loot.

Conclusion:

In short, I had ALOT of fun with this game and its a surefire candidate for my GOTY, I would recommend it to anyone looking for a fun and involved challenge without diving head first into the Souls series. It has alot of solid gameplay hours, beautiful environments and gear, an interesting and involved story and a very 'play-your-way' attitude.

9/10

reviewText:
It's hard to recommend this game in its current state.  It's an incredibly buggy and unoptimized game.  Until the developers make serious strides in fixing these issues, I'd say hold onto your money.  This is mainly a consequence of the game's qualities just barely overcoming its shortcomings.  When the technical difficulties are thrown into the mix, those qualities have just that much more to contend with.
First, this game is very much in the line of Souls games.  The similarities between the two are numerous: no map, tough enemies, nebulous story, a weight-based movement system, and a leveling/checkpoint system very similar to Dark Soul’s bonfire-based system.  The similarities don’t end there but this game’s status as a “Souls clone” has been well-established.

With that said, the game does many things well.  The art direction, while it has proven to be somewhat divisive, is quite good.  While some armor has been recycled, the sets look good and fit the world they inhabit.  The animations are fluid.  Hitboxes are generally well done.  Enemies are far more likely to hit you on the back end of their swings than in any of the Souls game.  Whereas in Dark Souls, many encounters could be beaten by simply rolling into enemies, the same cannot be said for Lords of the Fallen.  One must think about his rolls and the direction they will take.  The weight system is practically a copy-pasted system from Dark Souls—a system I’m much more partial to than the system in Dark Souls 2.  On the whole, the game is generally enjoyable to play.

Unfortunately, there are various issues that make it difficult to appreciate the game’s qualities.  Technically, the game is prone to crashes, the framerate is atrocious, and bugs run rampant.  I won’t spend time much time on the technical issues, though.  As for the game, frankly it’s too easy.  Most bosses are easily beaten on the first attempt.  Enemies aren’t too varied which affords the player enough experience within the first handful of hours to breeze through the rest of the game.  The developers try to curb this ease by throwing in, seemingly random, enemies that, while looking like typical enemies, have more health and do a great deal of damage.  Entire sections of the game, especially toward the end, feature enemies that do more damage than any boss in the game does while having a substantial amount of health.  This is fairly frustrating and inconsistent with the world the game is building.  Other issues include the targeting system, which is barely functional.  The magic system is poorly implemented.  Some spells are either poorly designed (Mimic which obscures your character and the enemy), only function a handful of times (Stab, which misses seemingly a third of the time), or are simply not useful (Prayer).  All of these spells also cost a great deal of mana.  My faith build (essentially a magic build) could get off maybe 2-3 spells before going OOM.  Add in the ridiculous cooldown that all spells have and one can hardly be faulted in wondering why magic exists at all.

I’m going to stop here.  The bottom line: the cons outweigh the pros in this offering.  Perhaps a few patches from now and a Steam sale later this game might be worth picking up.
voteText: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I really want to recommend this game, since I like the Dark Souls formula. But the more I play this particular game, the more I'm convinced nobody else can get it right.

This game is difficult, but in all the wrong ways. The controls are awkward no matter what configuration you use, enemies will almost always break your attacks even if you wear the heaviest armor, and sometimes areas become impossible due to the sheer volume of damage you can experience from even one enemy by itself.

Like I said, I wish more games would adopt the Dark Souls method of fighting, but that game punishes you based on whether or not you become skilled and able to utilize your abilities and equipment. This game is simply a grindfest where it's all about luck whether or not an enemy will go down in two hits or overhwelm you with an unlimited hit combo.

I do not recommend this game.

reviewText: I bought this game thinking it was like the soul series. And in a way it is. But at the same time this game is so poorly balanced that its become impossible to enjoy. Im only several hours into the game and standard enemies can take up to 5-10 minutes to kill, and thats only if im hiding behind a shield and spamming spells while waiting for my magic meter to slowly refill. The enemies are INCREDIBLY powerful. I get that this is supposed to be difficuilt. I played through every soul game with no problem and really enjoyed it. I cant even play this game because of how strong the enemies are. One example is fairly early on, after the second boss there is one enemy RIGHT next to a checkpoint/health crystal thing. You cant kill him. He does over a third of your hp with one attack, which he spams in a 3 hit combo. One attack from him completely drains your energy if your behind a shield. He has an attack where he knocks your shield away and then immedietly attacks for over 3/4 of your hp. No way to dodge it its incredibly fast. And dont even think about hurting him.  Literally whenever hes not doing insane amounts of damage, hes hiding behind his shield. If you attack him here you do ONE point of damage and your weapon bounces off. Doesnt matter if its a light attack, heavy attack, one handed or two handed. Always one point. Always bounce off. And you cant get around him because the ♥♥♥♥er spins like hes in a roller disco. I thought this game was going to be good. And it would be with some more balance. But holy ♥♥♥♥ the enemies do way too much damage and take hardly any damage in return. Your also slow as ♥♥♥♥ing hell. Any weapon that isnt the monk staff has the slowest ♥♥♥♥ing attack animation in the history of video games.

reviewText:
After many many patches the game appears to be functioning finally. Staying solid 60 fps with a 970 GTX. There are still performance issues; I doubt they will ever be fixed given the nature of the dev response to on the community hub.

There is also the pervasive issue of the presence of Denuvo. While no solid evidence have been presented regarding the assertion it had negative effect on hardware (damaging SSDs) and/or reducing the games performance, it is still a unecessary bloatware and affects only legitimate paying costumers.

I bought this on release and was only able to actually play it now; thus the release price was not justified.

Best buy it on sale.

reviewText:
First away: I recommend you do NOT spend the full price. I have several dozen hours in Demon Souls and Dark Souls 1, over 200h on Dark Souls 2 and about 100 in Bloodborne on record. The game is simply not worth 50€/$ even if someone likes it. It's to poorly executed in gameplay.

First the Pros:

Graphics an Art Style are pretty neat. The game looks really good but that takes a lot of hardware. Still, looks better than Dark Souls 2 Sotfs or even Bloodborne in my opinion (only graphic wise, not atmospheric). The armors and weapons have a nice design and destinct look each, sharp textures as far as i could tell (playing on 1920x1080).

They have some nice ideas gameplay wise like the reduced stamina cost for the next attack when you time it right or the exp multiplier. I like that and would appreciate it in future Souls games.

And... thats it.

The Cons:

If you expect a precise battle system like the ones from Dark Souls or Bloodborne you will be very disappointed. The attacks of nearly all enemies hit you even if they are already finished an the hit zones are much to large compared to the looks of the attacks. You take damage even if you are way away from an enemy.

You can't trick" them by learning their patterns and use fast weapon swings in between to stagger them - apparently the don't have poise. They only get staggered by really hard hits like the strong sprint attack
date: but you can't combo after those attacks an you are completely open for a hit and take guaranteed damage. Enemies aren't really "open" after an attack

reviewText:
It's a shame that what could have been a great game is a broken program full of bugs.

It's locked at 30fps by default. This is by design. If you unlock the fps you can expect even more bugs, broken combat and unexpected character behaviour.

It randomly crashes, this is a known issue since release (9 months ago,,). Tried most fixes out there, still crashes. If you spend hours trying to kill a boss the last thing you expect is for a game like this to crash just when you're about to deal the final blow.

It's shame cus the graphics are great and was enjoying the story line but with such a challenging and ruthless kind of game you can't have the mechanics/software against you, it ruins the whole concept.

tl dr: don't buy console scraps

reviewText:
The Good:
- very nice music
- very nice lightings
- very nice atmosphere
- very nice general design
- good ideas improved from the Dark Souls games

The Bad:
- flawed and bugged combat system, resulting in unfair defeats
- tedious, overlong (10 to 25 mins) and infuriatingly marred boss fights

When a game wants to copy and improve on Dark Souls, the LEAST it MUST do is to give the player an absolutely perfect and flawless combat system.
LotF fails to deliver such a combat system, which is a pity because there are very good ideas in the game.

Too much grief playing this game.

The total lack of quest indication and summary is also idiotic and a part left out for no reason what-so-ever.

reviewText:
My review recommends against this game at it's default price. You decide what % off is appropriate based on my below comments.

Pros
This is a more forgiving Dark Souls, well executed art and decent sound work. Control is snappy, overall gameplay feel is good.

Cons
Stability was my biggest issue and the one keeping me from playing further. In the first 15 seconds of starting a game I got a black screen lockup I could alt tab out of and restart the game.

Then I had a hard freeze mid swing in combat that I couldnt get out of and was about to hold my power button after about 10 minutes when the game shut and my system accepted all the input id been trying to give it.

**Unfortunately for me, a big part of this game is centered around NOT SAVING. Seriously, how long can you go without dying or using a save crystal, the longer you go the bigger an xp/loot multiplier you build up, if you save/heal up at a save point your multiplier resets.**

My second fatal crash/lockup came about 2 hours into a streak. Lost all of that progress. You know that feel, I know you do.

TLDR: Game with core mechanic tempting the player not to save progress, crashes frequently on current hardware. Dare you risk losing hours of progress? (Tested with Win 7, 32gb ram, GTX980)

reviewText:
Not bad for a Soul's-like. Of course people will compare to it as it is its main inspiration, Though i think the title is a little weaker in many points, starting with the level design and the sense of freedom and exploration. In fact, most of the game (at least what i've seen so far) resolve around corridors that leads to enemies that open doors to another corridors bound together by cutscenes and so it can feels slightly brainless.
Also, the lore and story aren't a big suprise even if quite decent, but it might sounds dull if you grew bored of that sort of, like, regular heroic fantasy with muscles and big boobs. Characters are a bit cliché when not completly blank...

Yet it's not a bad game. Combats are fun and the game does a pretty good job at giving you reason to just go through the corridors. At least if you're a bit curious.

So yeah, i'd recommand it. Not at full price though. I think the game would be better at around 35$ or something.

reviewText:
I generally do not give negative reviews to games but this game was not good ( atleast it is not what i expected).  Lets discuss some pros and cons of the game .
Pros -
1) The depth of the world introduced is good
2)Graphics
3)Level design

Con's-
1)I hated weapon system of this game . If you want to atleast complete the game , invest in agility points . Strength points are total waste ! (Which i will discuss why in further con's)
2)Enemies with huge ♥♥♥ shields which they only lower when you either strike at there shield or your back is turned (in both cases you are open for a hit)
3)Most of the strength weapons are slow as ♥♥♥♥ , even the ones with 100% attack rate is slow ? wtf ? (And good luck defeating fast agile or enemies with shields) .
4)Not much variety of enemies
5)Bosses are not difficult and not memorable
6)Storyline will probably not get you hooked until the end of the game

Seriously , there are better titles than this to play and if you want to give it a try , purchase it on sale

reviewText:
General GameplayLords Of The Fallen is a third-person action RPG where we play as Harkyn a convicted criminal to save the world from the Rhogar threat.

Both the character and weapons feel extremelly heavy in the beginning, but with proper gear and weight management this is easielly fixed.

We are limited in terms of classes (warrior, cleric and rogue), but makes total sense considering the narrative of the game.

Much like Dark Souls, this is a game that requires patiente to study the enemies and exploit their weaknesses

Gameplay Rating: 3/5

EngineFledge

Graphics Options
The game has all the options we could have asked for.

Graphics Quality
One of the first next-gen games that hit the market, and lives up to it.

Performance
It's cursed with performance problems due to NVidia (Gameworks), the game forces PhysX that cripples performance on both AMD (specially) and NVidia builds.

Even though it was stated by the developers you can disable PhysX, this is a lie. PhysX is coded deep into the game engine, and even with PhysX disabled the particles show traces of PhysX rendering.

Engine Rating: 3/5

Overall Rating: 6/10

NotesOverall rating is a combination of the gameplay (mechanics and story) and engine (how the game looks and runs). If you disagree with my take on the game or if something is factually incorrect, please leave a comment below!
