reviewText:
The game (w/o Ancient Labyrinth DLC) took me about 15 hours to beat. Having freshly beat it and played about 30 minutes into my New Game +, here is what I have to say.

Lords of the Fallen got a bad rep on release for being a Souls rip-off. This is, to some extent, true. However, the formula has been boiled down to its most basic components and new usability features added, resulting in a much more accessible game.

The game has a story. It's not brilliant, and on the first playthrough it's not actually possible to get all of the lore, but it was interesting enough to keep me hooked and playing the game.

The game also has a dialogue system. You won't use it a whole lot and npc interactions are fairly scarce, but it exists and contributes to some of the game's more poignant moments.

The game is bloody beautiful. Apart from lacking character customization, the weapons and armor are well designed and detailed, the enemies and environments are detailed, and the particle effects are well done. Props to the developers on that.

The game is responsive. People complaining about long lag times between input and action are *probably* running a sword and board strength build. Dual-wielding while wearing light armor is much faster, but an unpopular choice because of the inability to block. Don't listen to people wielding greathammers with one hand and a tower shield with the other.

Quests are vague af. I only barely registered the planetarium quest's existence despite clearing almost all the other ones, and by the time I had the items I went into the room and couldn't find anything to activate due to how far I was in the story, but the ending told me that yes it was possible and I was a dumb.

Occasional steam controller sync bugs, and the quest prompt occasionally would reset for no reason or display the incorrect objective.

The game is $20. The DLC is $8... Buy the game. If you like it and care about achievements get the DLC, otherwise ignore it as it's not brilliant. Even if you're a souls fan, buy the game. It's shorter and easier than most of the souls titles, but still an engaging experience that doesn't deserve to be maligned by people who haven't bothered to try it. I loved every minute of my first playthrough, and will definitely be back for more.

reviewText: I know how people say its Darksider 2 for the cheap and are scepticle about this game but im here to give my first thoughts and personal opinion on this game. Lords of the Fallen is a very unique game even though it carries many of dakrsiders qualities. DarkSiders 2 is more of a death simulator and This game is somewhat a hack and slash. I mean its not entirely lets rush in and spam left mouse but it is a lot more of you being involved and attacking rather then waiting and watching your enemies attack patterns. Even though its more hack and slash like its not more forgiving. When you die you leave the white mist like object behind you and it gives you a certain amount of time to grab it. It starts from 100% and works its way down. Even though this seems easy the fact that the enemy will still be there makes you think if you would rather fetch it or attempt to kill the enemy first. Many people said it was a pushover but for me this was not the case since i didnt play darksouls or darksouls 2 before this game. Think of it as a kind of tutorial game for people who havent played Darksouls. Since i have spoken about my personal experience i will now tell you about graphics gameplay and issues. At this moment in time even though i have played 2.4 hours i have not had one single issue with this game. It has ran smoothly except for the second boss where it dropped fps for about 1 second. Graphic wise this game is beautiful. The beautiful environment and the way everything works with one another can change it from being peacful to a bloodbath in an instant without feeling clunky and all over the place. The voice used for the main character suits him but he lacks in personality which makes it quite difficult to fall in love with the characters so you feel connected. I rate it 8-10 and if anyone needs a game reviewed that i have add me and ill write you one\n

reviewText:
The game is unfortunately a little bit of a bumpy ride in terms of graphics and just keeping it from crashing!

Since 1.4 it has seemed alot more stable, though I do have the odd crash to desktop.

If only they spent a little more time on this game, it could easily be a 9/10 for me, its got a good gothic style atmosphere going on and the graphics are solid.

What I loved about the combat in this game over Dark Souls, was the weight of the weapons and how it felt like you were really smashing emenies with them. Which I didnt feel in Souls. Also liked the amount of weapons, and how easy and accessible it felt customising the main character!

Overall, I would say its a definite purchase for £15 or under. That way the odd crash may not bother you, but if you spent £30 or so, you might feel a very little bit disappointed with it.

In its current state, its a 7/10

reviewText:
Pretty underrated game.
The combat system and the overall gameplay is great (it's not linear, you have to figure out where to go, explore carefully to find secrets, ect..), awesome graphics, and it's pretty atmospheric in my opinion, even if not as dark and bleak as Dark Souls.
Not as challenging as DS, but I play as a rouge character (light armor and weapons) and it's not easy at all (I soloed DS and DS2)
Slight fps drops here and there, but no crashes for me.
As a DS fan I'm having a lot of fun with this game, highly recommended!

reviewText:
If you liked Dark Souls 1/2, this game is for you.

The story is a bit crappy, but the combat is really fun, and the graphics are amazing. It's a lot easier and shorter, but there is a replayability, new game+, similar as in the DS series.

I did not have a single technical issue at very high settings @1080p with FX6300, 8 gigs of ram, and a R9 280 (although I bought the 1.4 version, idk how was the game at release).

Definitely worth buying if it's on a sale.

reviewText:
My thumbs down is not an hard one i had fun playing lotf, but when i was comparing this to the DS franchise, and they are just better in every aspect but the graphic.
I was able to finish the game the fist time with no difficulty at all. The game was easy, shield are OP, the animations of attack were slow (probabily more realistic, but waiting 1 second to deliver a blow could be a bit frustrating. This might be a fault of Souls game that get us used to see the berserk's sword swinged easly as longsword).
The game got some balance issues with pacemaker you can easly achive 5XX dmg, comboing 2k dmg. That damage is insane!!! (socketing the ENDGAME rune give you ~16 damage, the luck give you ~200). Trading blow with bosses is efficent, imho it SHOULD NOT BE efficent, you got tons of pots, they can just repeat the attacks.
Spells are game breaking, creating a clone of you that taunt the enemy is broken.(i didn't tested other spells, didn't needed to).
To find the game a bit more challenging i dropped the shield and the spell and used only slow 2h weapon, maybe i'll try again with a stealth/agy class and the game will be really hard, i hope so!!

reviewText:
My first note is that the game is very short. I beat it in 8 hours of playtime. No multiplayer, limited sidequests that are very vague and confusing levels had me getting mixed up all over the place. There were not very many bosses and they were all pretty easy. Only two bosses actually killed me.
This game is NOT Dark Souls. Not even close. It uses dark souls combat mechanics like health potions that refill at checkpoints, dodge rolls, and left hand/right hand on LB/LT and RB/RT. The same mechanics are in it but the feel is much different. Everything in Dark Souls is very thoughtful and you can learn your opponents moves and such to make it a lot easier, but even as a magic build I found myself just smacking everything in the face with my hammer and ignoring damage.
It was a very easy game, the only challenging part was that the level layouts are confusing and mazelike. I did enjoy the game, but it felt like it could have been so much more. I will probably do the NG+ but I don't recommend it for $50. Get it on sale and it will be fun for a while.
TL:DR Fun but too short and no multiplayer. Do not expect it to be like Dark Souls. Mechanics are similar, but the game is way different.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
From the first time that we saw the Lords of the Fallen videos we could not help our­selves but com­pare it to the Dark Souls games. Even though the game does fol­low the Souls game mechan­ics, it does offer an inter­est­ing and some­what eas­ier gam­ing experience.

Lords of the Fallen tells the story of Harkyn, an impris­oned crim­i­nal who is set free in order to save the world from the inter-dimensional Rhogar and their Lords. The story tries to keep things inter­est­ing through cutscenes and var­i­ous moments where the player is allowed to choose a spe­cific course of action. Unfor­tu­nately, the choices do not seem to be of any sig­nif­i­cance towards the pro­gres­sion of the game; their exis­tence how­ever does make things more interesting.
Read the rest of my review here: http://www.blowsomesteam.com/lords-of-the-fallen/

reviewText:
The Game itself is great! I love the Dark Souls series and since this game is basically a easier version i like this too.
BUT!  It seems like it still has a ton of problems. In my case it would be the constant crashes. I mean 6 crashes in under an hour? I'm patient but that is kind of awful. And before anyone asks, i did update my graphics card drivers.
Since the reviews split into 2 camps, meaning those who have the crashes and the those who dont, there is no accurate way to tell if you should recommend it or not. But right now, i do get the crashes and i think i should have waited to purchase this. So recommend it or not?
Not right now. Will change if something changes or if there is a resolution to fix it.
If you still buy it you probably have a 50/50 chance it does work. Do you feel lucky?


EDIT: So i may have judged this problem too fast before really looking into it. It works fine for me now and another 2 hours into the game i do think have an explanation.

So it seems like the Nvidia Trubulance feature caused the constant crashes, which is kind of weird because i have n Nvidia GTX 970. So by deactivating the feature it didnt crash on me again. So basically what the problem seems to be for Nvidia card owner is that the function itself causes some kind of problem and thus creating the crashes. And i guess alot of ppl don't have that problem because the have AMD card's and this feature is in general turned off? I don't really know, that is just my guess.

Anyways.....having a lot of fun playing it. For Dark Souls fans a nice  treat ;)

reviewText: While the game has some potential, poor level design and constant crashes make this a game to avoid. Yet another game sadly ruined by an extemely buggy release! Even after supposedly patching to improve stability the game still crashes to desktop roughly every 5 minutes if i'm lucky, making it almost unplayable. The combat system is very good and for the most part feels pretty fair, though unless you want to add misery onto the already frustrating bug filled experience that is Lords of the fallen stay away from the rogue until you really know the game. The story, while a little thin so far at least makes an attempt at a story, though the over-use of copy paste makes for some very average level design. The voice acting is pretty bad as is the lip-syncing for the characters as is the in-scene animation, which feels comically wooden. I want to like this game, I really do, but sadly the game feels rushed to release and incomplete. Maybe when the stability problems are fixed I may revisit this game but at the moment I don't think so. My advice, wait until it's been patched... A LOT and wait till it is in a sale if you really want a fix while waiting for Bloodborne.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
At first it was medicore, not knowing the timings and such. I actually died on tutorial enemy from not knowing the key padding (i thought that it's the same as in Souls). As someone who 100% both souls i didn't have much struggle with the bosses, however i still enjoyed them quite a lot. From the boss pool there are some typical humanoid-type, leaving less room for unconvetional ones.
Equipment is nice, you can feel the weight of the blow as you strike. Enviroment and level design are one of my favourite things in the game. I got lost sometimes, which is also good for me. Some enemies require cheezy strategies at first until:
a) you git gud and do it normal way
b)you're so op that they shatter under your gaze alone.
Opponents very rarely use cheese strategies, only like once or twice in the game.
Overall i can give it 8.5/10 NG alone with +/- 0.5 depending on the part of the game.
